C as in C () C is the third letter of the English alphabet. It is from the Latin letter C, which in old Latin represented the sounds of k, and g (in go); its original value being the latter. In Anglo-Saxon words, or Old English before the Norman Conquest, it always has the sound of k. The Latin C was the same letter as the Greek /, /, and came from the Greek alphabet. The Greeks got it from the Ph/nicians. The English name of C is from the Latin name ce, and was derived, probably, through the French. Etymologically C is related to g, h, k, q, s (and other sibilant sounds). Examples of these relations are in L. acutus, E. acute, ague; E. acrid, eager, vinegar; L. cornu, E. horn; E. cat, kitten; E. coy, quiet; L. circare, OF. cerchier, E. search.,
C as in C () The keynote of the normal or "natural" scale, which has neither flats nor sharps in its signature; also, the third note of the relative minor scale of the same.,
C as in C () C after the clef is the mark of common time, in which each measure is a semibreve (four fourths or crotchets); for alla breve time it is written /.,
C as in C () The "C clef," a modification of the letter C, placed on any line of the staff, shows that line to be middle C.,
C as in C () As a numeral, C stands for Latin centum or 100, CC for 200, etc.,
C as in Caaba (n.) The small and nearly cubical stone building, toward which all Mohammedans must pray.,
C as in Caas (n. sing. & pl.) Case.,
C as in Cab (n.) A kind of close carriage with two or four wheels, usually a public vehicle.,
C as in Cab (n.) The covered part of a locomotive, in which the engineer has his station.,
C as in Cab (n.) A Hebrew dry measure, containing a little over two (2.37) pints.,
C as in Cabal (n.) Tradition; occult doctrine. See Cabala,
C as in Cabal (n.) A secret.,
C as in Cabal (n.) A number of persons united in some close design, usually to promote their private views and interests in church or state by intrigue; a secret association composed of a few designing persons; a junto.,
C as in Cabal (n.) The secret artifices or machinations of a few persons united in a close design; intrigue.,
C as in Caballed (imp. & p. p.) of Cabal,
C as in Caballing (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Cabal,
C as in Cabal (v. i.) To unite in a small party to promote private views and interests by intrigue; to intrigue; to plot.,
C as in Cabala (n.) A kind of occult theosophy or traditional interpretation of the Scriptures among Jewish rabbis and certain mediaeval Christians, which treats of the nature of god and the mystery of human existence. It assumes that every letter, word, number, and accent of Scripture contains a hidden sense; and it teaches the methods of interpretation for ascertaining these occult meanings. The cabalists pretend even to foretell events by this means.,
C as in Cabala (n.) Secret science in general; mystic art; mystery.,
C as in Cabalism (n.) The secret science of the cabalists.,
C as in Cabalism (n.) A superstitious devotion to the mysteries of the religion which one professes.,
C as in Cabalist (n.) One versed in the cabala, or the mysteries of Jewish traditions.,
C as in Cabalistic (a.) Alt. of Cabalistical,
C as in Cabalistical (a.) Of or pertaining to the cabala; containing or conveying an occult meaning; mystic.,
C as in Cabalistically (adv.) In a cabalistic manner.,
C as in Cabalize (v. i.) To use cabalistic language.,
C as in Caballer (n.) One who cabals.,
C as in Caballine (a.) Of or pertaining to a horse.,
C as in Caballine (n.) Caballine aloes.,
C as in Cabaret (n.) A tavern; a house where liquors are retailed.,
C as in Cabaret (n.) a type of restaurant where liquor and dinner is served, and entertainment is provided, as by musicians, dancers, or comedians, and providing space for dancing by the patrons; -- similar to a nightclub. The term cabaret is often used in the names of such an establishment.,
C as in Cabaret (n.) the type of entertainment provided in a cabaret{2}.,
C as in Cabas (n.) A flat basket or frail for figs, etc.; hence, a lady's flat workbasket, reticule, or hand bag; -- often written caba.,
C as in Cabassou (n.) A species of armadillo of the genus Xenurus (X. unicinctus and X. hispidus); the tatouay.,
C as in Cabbage (n.) An esculent vegetable of many varieties, derived from the wild Brassica oleracea of Europe. The common cabbage has a compact head of leaves. The cauliflower, Brussels sprouts, etc., are sometimes classed as cabbages.,
C as in Cabbage (n.) The terminal bud of certain palm trees, used, like, cabbage, for food. See Cabbage tree, below.,
C as in Cabbage (n.) The cabbage palmetto. See below.,
C as in Cabbage (v. i.) To form a head like that the cabbage; as, to make lettuce cabbage.,

C as in Cable (n.) A large, strong rope or chain, of considerable length, used to retain a vessel at anchor, and for other purposes. It is made of hemp, of steel wire, or of iron links.,
C as in Cable (n.) A rope of steel wire, or copper wire, usually covered with some protecting or insulating substance; as, the cable of a suspension bridge; a telegraphic cable.,
C as in Cable (n.) A molding, shaft of a column, or any other member of convex, rounded section, made to resemble the spiral twist of a rope; -- called also cable molding.,
C as in Cable (v. t.) To fasten with a cable.,
C as in Cable (v. t.) To ornament with cabling. See Cabling.,

C as in Cablelaid (a.) Composed of three three-stranded ropes, or hawsers, twisted together to form a cable.,
C as in Cablelaid (a.) Twisted after the manner of a cable; as, a cable-laid gold chain.,
C as in Cablet (n.) A little cable less than ten inches in circumference.,
C as in Cabling (n.) The decoration of a fluted shaft of a column or of a pilaster with reeds, or rounded moldings, which seem to be laid in the hollows of the fluting. These are limited in length to about one third of the height of the shaft.,

C as in Cacao (n.) A small evergreen tree (Theobroma Cacao) of South America and the West Indies. Its fruit contains an edible pulp, inclosing seeds about the size of an almond, from which cocoa, chocolate, and broma are prepared.,
C as in Cachalot (n.) The sperm whale (Physeter macrocephalus). It has in the top of its head a large cavity, containing an oily fluid, which, after death, concretes into a whitish crystalline substance called spermaceti. See Sperm whale.,

C as in Cadmia (n.) An oxide of zinc which collects on the sides of furnaces where zinc is sublimed. Formerly applied to the mineral calamine.,
C as in Cadmian (a.) See Cadmean.,
C as in Cadmic (a.) Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, cadmium; as, cadmic sulphide.,
C as in Cadmium (n.) A comparatively rare element related to zinc, and occurring in some zinc ores. It is a white metal, both ductile and malleable. Symbol Cd. Atomic weight 111.8. It was discovered by Stromeyer in 1817, who named it from its association with zinc or zinc ore.,
C as in Cadrans (n.) An instrument with a graduated disk by means of which the angles of gems are measured in the process of cutting and polishing.,
C as in Cadre (n.) The framework or skeleton upon which a regiment is to be formed; the officers of a regiment forming the staff.,
C as in Caducary (a.) Relating to escheat, forfeiture, or confiscation.,
C as in Caducean (a.) Of or belonging to Mercury's caduceus, or wand.,
C as in Caduceus (n.) The official staff or wand of Hermes or Mercury, the messenger of the gods. It was originally said to be a herald's staff of olive wood, but was afterwards fabled to have two serpents coiled about it, and two wings at the top.,
C as in Caducibranchiate (a.) With temporary gills: -- applied to those Amphibia in which the gills do not remain in adult life.,

C as in Caenozoic (a.) See Cenozoic.,
C as in Caen stone () A cream-colored limestone for building, found near Caen, France.,
C as in Caesar (n.) A Roman emperor, as being the successor of Augustus Caesar. Hence, a kaiser, or emperor of Germany, or any emperor or powerful ruler. See Kaiser, Kesar.,
C as in Caesarean (a.) Alt. of Caesarian,
C as in Caesarian (a.) Of or pertaining to Caesar or the Caesars; imperial.,
C as in Caesarism (n.) A system of government in which unrestricted power is exercised by a single person, to whom, as Caesar or emperor, it has been committed by the popular will; imperialism; also, advocacy or support of such a system of government.,
C as in Caesious (a.) Of the color of lavender; pale blue with a slight mixture of gray.,
C as in Caesium (n.) A rare alkaline metal found in mineral water; -- so called from the two characteristic blue lines in its spectrum. It was the first element discovered by spectrum analysis, and is the most strongly basic and electro-positive substance known. Symbol Cs. Atomic weight 132.6.,
C as in Caespitose (a.) Same as Cespitose.,
C as in Caesuras (pl. ) of Caesura,
C as in Caesurae (pl. ) of Caesura,
C as in Caesura (n.) A metrical break in a verse, occurring in the middle of a foot and commonly near the middle of the verse; a sense pause in the middle of a foot. Also, a long syllable on which the caesural accent rests, or which is used as a foot.,
C as in Caesural (a.) Of or pertaining to a caesura.,
C as in Cafe (n.) A coffeehouse; a restaurant; also, a room in a hotel or restaurant where coffee and liquors are served.,
C as in Cafenet (n.) Alt. of Cafeneh,
C as in Cafeneh (n.) A humble inn or house of rest for travelers, where coffee is sold.,
C as in Caffeic (a.) Pertaining to, or obtained from, coffee.,
C as in Caffeine (n.) A white, bitter, crystallizable substance, obtained from coffee. It is identical with the alkaloid theine from tea leaves, and with guaranine from guarana.,
C as in Caffetannic (a.) Pertaining to, or derived from, the tannin of coffee.,
C as in Caffila (n.) See Cafila.,

C as in Cafila (n.) Alt. of Cafileh,

C as in Caisson (n.) A chest to hold ammunition.,
C as in Caisson (n.) A four-wheeled carriage for conveying ammunition, consisting of two parts, a body and a limber. In light field batteries there is one caisson to each piece, having two ammunition boxes on the body, and one on the limber.,

C as in Calamander wood () A valuable furniture wood from India and Ceylon, of a hazel-brown color, with black stripes, very hard in texture. It is a species of ebony, and is obtained from the Diospyros quaesita. Called also Coromandel wood.,
C as in Calamar (n.) Alt. of Calamary,
C as in Calamary (n.) A cephalopod, belonging to the genus Loligo and related genera. There are many species. They have a sack of inklike fluid which they discharge from the siphon tube, when pursued or alarmed, in order to confuse their enemies. Their shell is a thin horny plate, within the flesh of the back, shaped very much like a quill pen. In America they are called squids. See Squid.,

C as in Calamite (n.) A fossil plant of the coal formation, having the general form of plants of the modern Equiseta (the Horsetail or Scouring Rush family) but sometimes attaining the height of trees, and having the stem more or less woody within. See Acrogen, and Asterophyllite.,

C as in Calamus (n.) The indian cane, a plant of the Palm family. It furnishes the common rattan. See Rattan, and Dragon's blood.,
C as in Calamus (n.) A species of Acorus (A. calamus), commonly called calamus, or sweet flag. The root has a pungent, aromatic taste, and is used in medicine as a stomachic; the leaves have an aromatic odor, and were formerly used instead of rushes to strew on floors.,

C as in Calender (n.) A machine, used for the purpose of giving cloth, paper, etc., a smooth, even, and glossy or glazed surface, by cold or hot pressure, or for watering them and giving them a wavy appearance. It consists of two or more cylinders revolving nearly in contact, with the necessary apparatus for moving and regulating.,

C as in Calin (n.) An alloy of lead and tin, of which the Chinese make tea canisters.,
C as in Calipash (n.) A part of a turtle which is next to the upper shell. It contains a fatty and gelatinous substance of a dull greenish tinge, much esteemed as a delicacy in preparations of turtle.,
C as in Calipee (n.) A part of a turtle which is attached to the lower shell. It contains a fatty and gelatinous substance of a light yellowish color, much esteemed as a delicacy.,
C as in Calipers (n. pl.) An instrument, usually resembling a pair of dividers or compasses with curved legs, for measuring the diameter or thickness of bodies, as of work shaped in a lathe or planer, timber, masts, shot, etc.; or the bore of firearms, tubes, etc.; -- called also caliper compasses, or caliber compasses.,
C as in Caliph (n.) Successor or vicar; -- a title of the successors of Mohammed both as temporal and spiritual rulers, now used by the sultans of Turkey.,
C as in Caliphate (n.) The office, dignity, or government of a caliph or of the caliphs.,
C as in Calippic (a.) Of or pertaining to Calippus, an Athenian astronomer.,
C as in Calisaya bark () A valuable kind of Peruvian bark obtained from the Cinchona Calisaya, and other closely related species.,

C as in Calisthenics (n.) The science, art, or practice of healthful exercise of the body and limbs, to promote strength and gracefulness; light gymnastics.,

C as in Calk (v. t.) To drive tarred oakum into the seams between the planks of (a ship, boat, etc.), to prevent leaking. The calking is completed by smearing the seams with melted pitch.,
C as in Calk (v. t.) To make an indentation in the edge of a metal plate, as along a seam in a steam boiler or an iron ship, to force the edge of the upper plate hard against the lower and so fill the crevice.,
C as in Calk (v. t.) To copy, as a drawing, by rubbing the back of it with red or black chalk, and then passing a blunt style or needle over the lines, so as to leave a tracing on the paper or other thing against which it is laid or held.,
C as in Calk (n.) A sharp-pointed piece of iron or steel projecting downward on the shoe of a horse or an ox, to prevent the animal from slipping; -- called also calker, calkin.,
C as in Calk (n.) An instrument with sharp points, worn on the sole of a shoe or boot, to prevent slipping.,
C as in Calk (v. i.) To furnish with calks, to prevent slipping on ice; as, to calk the shoes of a horse or an ox.,
C as in Calk (v. i.) To wound with a calk; as when a horse injures a leg or a foot with a calk on one of the other feet.,

C as in Caloricity (n.) A faculty in animals of developing and preserving the heat necessary to life, that is, the animal heat.,
C as in Caloriduct (n.) A tube or duct for conducting heat; a caliduct.,
C as in Calorie (n.) The unit of heat according to the French standard; the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of one kilogram (sometimes, one gram) of water one degree centigrade, or from 0 to 1. Compare the English standard unit, Foot pound.,

C as in Caltrop (n.) Alt. of Caltrap,
C as in Caltrap (n.) A genus of herbaceous plants (Tribulus) of the order Zygophylleae, having a hard several-celled fruit, armed with stout spines, and resembling the military instrument of the same name. The species grow in warm countries, and are often very annoying to cattle.,
C as in Caltrap (n.) An instrument with four iron points, so disposed that, any three of them being on the ground, the other projects upward. They are scattered on the ground where an enemy's cavalry are to pass, to impede their progress by endangering the horses' feet.,
C as in Calumba (n.) The root of a plant (Jateorrhiza Calumba, and probably Cocculus palmatus), indigenous in Mozambique. It has an unpleasantly bitter taste, and is used as a tonic and antiseptic.,
C as in Calumbin (n.) A bitter principle extracted as a white crystalline substance from the calumba root.,
C as in Calumet (n.) A kind of pipe, used by the North American Indians for smoking tobacco. The bowl is usually made of soft red stone, and the tube is a long reed often ornamented with feathers.,

C as in Calypso (n.) A small and beautiful species of orchid, having a flower variegated with purple, pink, and yellow. It grows in cold and wet localities in the northern part of the United States. The Calypso borealis is the only orchid which reaches 68 N.,

C as in Cambria (n.) The ancient Latin name of Wales. It is used by modern poets.,
C as in Cambrian (a.) Of or pertaining to Cambria or Wales.,
C as in Cambrian (a.) Of or pertaining to the lowest subdivision of the rocks of the Silurian or Molluscan age; -- sometimes described as inferior to the Silurian. It is named from its development in Cambria or Wales. See the Diagram under Geology.,
C as in Cambrian (n.) A native of Cambria or Wales.,
C as in Cambrian (n.) The Cambrian formation.,
C as in Cambric (n.) A fine, thin, and white fabric made of flax or linen.,
C as in Cambric (n.) A fabric made, in imitation of linen cambric, of fine, hardspun cotton, often with figures of various colors; -- also called cotton cambric, and cambric muslin.,
C as in Cambro-Briton (n.) A Welshman.,
C as in Came () imp. of Come.,
C as in Came (n.) A slender rod of cast lead, with or without grooves, used, in casements and stained-glass windows, to hold together the panes or pieces of glass.,
C as in Camel (n.) A large ruminant used in Asia and Africa for carrying burdens and for riding. The camel is remarkable for its ability to go a long time without drinking. Its hoofs are small, and situated at the extremities of the toes, and the weight of the animal rests on the callous. The dromedary (Camelus dromedarius) has one bunch on the back, while the Bactrian camel (C. Bactrianus) has two. The llama, alpaca, and vicua, of South America, belong to a related genus (Auchenia).,
C as in Camel (n.) A water-tight structure (as a large box or boxes) used to assist a vessel in passing over a shoal or bar or in navigating shallow water. By admitting water, the camel or camels may be sunk and attached beneath or at the sides of a vessel, and when the water is pumped out the vessel is lifted.,
C as in Camel-backed (a.) Having a back like a camel; humpbacked.,
C as in Cameleon (n.) See Chaceleon.,
C as in Camellia (n.) An Asiatic genus of small shrubs, often with shining leaves and showy flowers. Camellia Japonica is much cultivated for ornament, and C. Sassanqua and C. oleifera are grown in China for the oil which is pressed from their seeds. The tea plant is now referred to this genus under the name of Camellia Thea.,
C as in Camelopard (n.) An African ruminant; the giraffe. See Giraffe.,
C as in Camelot (n.) See Camelet.,
C as in Camelshair (a.) Of camel's hair.,
C as in Cameos (pl. ) of Cameo,
C as in Cameo (n.) A carving in relief, esp. one on a small scale used as a jewel for personal adornment, or like.,
C as in Cameras (pl. ) of Camera,
C as in Camerae (pl. ) of Camera,
C as in Camera (n.) A chamber, or instrument having a chamber. Specifically: The camera obscura when used in photography. See Camera, and Camera obscura.,
C as in Camerade (n.) See Comrade.,
C as in Cameralistic (a.) Of or pertaining to finance and public revenue.,
C as in Cameralistics (n.) The science of finance or public revenue.,
C as in Camera lucida () An instrument which by means of a prism of a peculiar form, or an arrangement of mirrors, causes an apparent image of an external object or objects to appear as if projected upon a plane surface, as of paper or canvas, so that the outlines may conveniently traced. It is generally used with the microscope.,
C as in Camera obscura () An apparatus in which the images of external objects, formed by a convex lens or a concave mirror, are thrown on a paper or other white surface placed in the focus of the lens or mirror within a darkened chamber, or box, so that the outlines may be traced.,
C as in Camera obscura () An apparatus in which the image of an external object or objects is, by means of lenses, thrown upon a sensitized plate or surface placed at the back of an extensible darkened box or chamber variously modified; -- commonly called simply the camera.,
C as in Camerated (imp. & p. p.) of Camerate,
C as in Camerzting (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Camerate,
C as in Camerate (v. i.) To build in the form of a vault; to arch over.,
C as in Camerate (v. i.) To divide into chambers.,
C as in Cameration (n.) A vaulting or arching over.,
C as in Camerlingo (n.) The papal chamberlain; the cardinal who presides over the pope's household. He has at times possessed great power.,
C as in Cameronian (n.) A follower of the Rev. Richard Cameron, a Scotch Covenanter of the time of Charles II.,
C as in Camis (n.) A light, loose dress or robe.,
C as in Camisade (n.) Alt. of Camisado,
C as in Camisado (n.) A shirt worn by soldiers over their uniform, in order to be able to recognize one another in a night attack.,
C as in Camisado (n.) An attack by surprise by soldiers wearing the camisado.,
C as in Camisard (n.) One of the French Protestant insurgents who rebelled against Louis XIV, after the revocation of the edict of Nates; -- so called from the peasant's smock (camise) which they wore.,
C as in Camisated (a.) Dressed with a shirt over the other garments.,
C as in Camisole (n.) A short dressing jacket for women.,
C as in Camisole (n.) A kind of straitjacket.,
C as in Camlet (n.) A woven fabric originally made of camel's hair, now chiefly of goat's hair and silk, or of wool and cotton.,
C as in Camleted (a.) Wavy or undulating like camlet; veined.,
C as in Cammas (n.) See Camass.,
C as in Cammock (n.) A plant having long hard, crooked roots, the Ononis spinosa; -- called also rest-harrow. The Scandix Pecten-Veneris is also called cammock.,
C as in Camomile (n.) Alt. of Chamomile,
C as in Chamomile (n.) A genus of herbs (Anthemis) of the Composite family. The common camomile, A. nobilis, is used as a popular remedy. Its flowers have a strong and fragrant and a bitter, aromatic taste. They are tonic, febrifugal, and in large doses emetic, and the volatile oil is carminative.,
C as in Camonflet (n.) A small mine, sometimes formed in the wall or side of an enemy's gallery, to blow in the earth and cut off the retreat of the miners.,
C as in Camous (a.) Alt. of Camoys,
C as in Camoys (a.) Flat; depressed; crooked; -- said only of the nose.,
C as in Camoused (a.) Depressed; flattened.,
C as in Camously (adv.) Awry.,

C as in Camp (n.) A collection of tents, huts, etc., for shelter, commonly arranged in an orderly manner.,
C as in Camp (n.) A single hut or shelter; as, a hunter's camp.,
C as in Camp (n.) The company or body of persons encamped, as of soldiers, of surveyors, of lumbermen, etc.,
C as in Camp (n.) A mound of earth in which potatoes and other vegetables are stored for protection against frost; -- called also burrow and pie.,
C as in Camp (n.) An ancient game of football, played in some parts of England.,
C as in Camped (imp. & p. p.) of Camp,
C as in Camping (p. pr. & vb n.) of Camp,
C as in Camp (v. t.) To afford rest or lodging for, as an army or travelers.,
C as in Camp (v. i.) To pitch or prepare a camp; to encamp; to lodge in a camp; -- often with out.,
C as in Camp (n.) To play the game called camp.,
C as in Campagna (n.) An open level tract of country; especially "Campagna di Roma." The extensive undulating plain which surrounds Rome.,
C as in Campagnol (n.) A mouse (Arvicala agrestis), called also meadow mouse, which often does great damage in fields and gardens, by feeding on roots and seeds.,
C as in Campaign (n.) An open field; a large, open plain without considerable hills. SeeChampaign.,

C as in Campaign (n.) Political operations preceding an election; a canvass.,
C as in Campaign (n.) The period during which a blast furnace is continuously in operation.,
C as in Campaign (v. i.) To serve in a campaign.,
C as in Campaigner (n.) One who has served in an army in several campaigns; an old soldier; a veteran.,

C as in Campana (n.) Same as Gutta.,

C as in Campanula (n.) A large genus of plants bearing bell-shaped flowers, often of great beauty; -- also called bellflower.,
C as in Campanulaceous (a.) Of pertaining to, or resembling, the family of plants (Camponulaceae) of which Campanula is the type, and which includes the Canterbury bell, the harebell, and the Venus's looking-glass.,
C as in Campanularian (n.) A hydroid of the family ampanularidae, characterized by having the polyps or zooids inclosed in bell-shaped calicles or hydrothecae.,
C as in Campanulate (a.) Bell-shaped.,
C as in Campbellite (n.) A member of the denomination called Christians or Disciples of Christ. They themselves repudiate the term Campbellite as a nickname. See Christian, 3.,
C as in Campeachy Wood () Logwood.,
C as in Camper (n.) One who lodges temporarily in a hut or camp.,
C as in Campestral (a.) Alt. of Campestrian,
C as in Campestrian (a.) Relating to an open fields; drowing in a field; growing in a field, or open ground.,
C as in Camptight (n.) A duel; the decision of a case by a duel.,
C as in Camphene (n.) One of a series of substances C10H16, resembling camphor, regarded as modified terpenes.,
C as in Camphine (n.) Rectified oil of turpentine, used for burning in lamps, and as a common solvent in varnishes.,
C as in Camphire (n.) An old spelling of Camphor.,
C as in Camphogen (n.) See Cymene.,
C as in Camphol (n.) See Borneol.,
C as in Camphor (n.) A tough, white, aromatic resin, or gum, obtained from different species of the Laurus family, esp. from Cinnamomum camphara (the Laurus camphara of Linnaeus.). Camphor, C10H16O, is volatile and fragrant, and is used in medicine as a diaphoretic, a stimulant, or sedative.,
C as in Camphor (n.) A gum resembling ordinary camphor, obtained from a tree (Dryobalanops camphora) growing in Sumatra and Borneo; -- called also Malay camphor, camphor of Borneo, or borneol. See Borneol.,

C as in Canary bird () A small singing bird of the Finch family (Serinus Canarius), a native of the Canary Islands. It was brought to Europe in the 16th century, and made a household pet. It generally has a yellowish body with the wings and tail greenish, but in its wild state it is more frequently of gray or brown color. It is sometimes called canary finch.,
C as in Canaster (n.) A kind of tobacco for smoking, made of the dried leaves, coarsely broken; -- so called from the rush baskets in which it is packed in South America.,

C as in Cancer (n.) A genus of decapod Crustacea, including some of the most common shore crabs of Europe and North America, as the rock crab, Jonah crab, etc. See Crab.,
C as in Cancer (n.) The fourth of the twelve signs of the zodiac. The first point is the northern limit of the sun's course in summer; hence, the sign of the summer solstice. See Tropic.,
C as in Cancer (n.) A northern constellation between Gemini and Leo.,
C as in Cancer (n.) Formerly, any malignant growth, esp. one attended with great pain and ulceration, with cachexia and progressive emaciation. It was so called, perhaps, from the great veins which surround it, compared by the ancients to the claws of a crab. The term is now restricted to such a growth made up of aggregations of epithelial cells, either without support or embedded in the meshes of a trabecular framework.,

C as in Canceration (n.) The act or state of becoming cancerous or growing into a cancer.,
C as in Cancerite (n.) Like a cancer; having the qualities or virulence of a cancer; affected with cancer.,

C as in Candleberry tree () A shrub (the Myrica cerifera, or wax-bearing myrtle), common in North America, the little nuts of which are covered with a greenish white wax, which was formerly, used for hardening candles; -- also called bayberry tree, bayberry, or candleberry.,
C as in Candlebomb (n.) A small glass bubble, filled with water, which, if placed in the flame of a candle, bursts by expansion of steam.,
C as in Candlebomb (n.) A pasteboard shell used in signaling. It is filled with a composition which makes a brilliant light when it explodes.,

C as in Candlefish (n.) A marine fish (Thaleichthys Pacificus), allied to the smelt, found on the north Pacific coast; -- called also eulachon. It is so oily that, when dried, it may be used as a candle, by drawing a wick through it,
C as in Candlefish (n.) The beshow.,

C as in Canker rash () A form of scarlet fever characterized by ulcerated or putrid sore throat.,
C as in Cankerworm (n.) The larva of two species of geometrid moths which are very injurious to fruit and shade trees by eating, and often entirely destroying, the foliage. Other similar larvae are also called cankerworms.,
C as in Cankery (a.) Like a canker; full of canker.,
C as in Cankery (a.) Surly; sore; malignant.,
C as in Canna (n.) A measure of length in Italy, varying from six to seven feet. See Cane, 4.,
C as in Canna (n.) A genus of tropical plants, with large leaves and often with showy flowers. The Indian shot (C. Indica) is found in gardens of the northern United States.,
C as in Cannabene (n.) A colorless oil obtained from hemp by distillation, and possessing its intoxicating properties.,
C as in Cannabin (n.) A poisonous resin extracted from hemp (Cannabis sativa, variety Indica). The narcotic effects of hasheesh are due to this resin.,
C as in Cannabine (a.) Pertaining to hemp; hempen.,
C as in Cannabis (n.) A genus of a single species belonging to the order Uricaceae; hemp.,
C as in Cannel coal () A kind of mineral coal of a black color, sufficiently hard and solid to be cut and polished. It burns readily, with a clear, yellow flame, and on this account has been used as a substitute for candles.,
C as in Cannery (n.) A place where the business of canning fruit, meat, etc., is carried on.,
C as in Cannibal (n.) A human being that eats human flesh; hence, any that devours its own kind.,
C as in Cannibal (a.) Relating to cannibals or cannibalism.,
C as in Cannibalism (n.) The act or practice of eating human flesh by mankind. Hence; Murderous cruelty; barbarity.,
C as in Cannibally (adv.) In the manner of cannibal.,
C as in Cannikin (n.) A small can or drinking vessel.,
C as in Cannily (adv.) In a canny manner.,

C as in Cannonade (n.) The act of discharging cannon and throwing ball, shell, etc., for the purpose of destroying an army, or battering a town, ship, or fort; -- usually, an attack of some continuance.,
C as in Cannonade (n.) Fig.; A loud noise like a cannonade; a booming.,

C as in Cannulated (a.) Hollow; affording a passage through its interior length for wire, thread, etc.; as, a cannulated (suture) needle.,

C as in Canoe (n.) A boat used by rude nations, formed of trunk of a tree, excavated, by cutting of burning, into a suitable shape. It is propelled by a paddle or paddles, or sometimes by sail, and has no rudder.,
C as in Canoe (n.) A boat made of bark or skins, used by savages.,
C as in Canoe (n.) A light pleasure boat, especially designed for use by one who goes alone upon long excursions, including portage. It it propelled by a paddle, or by a small sail attached to a temporary mast.,

C as in Canon (n.) A law or rule.,
C as in Canon (n.) A law, or rule of doctrine or discipline, enacted by a council and confirmed by the pope or the sovereign; a decision, regulation, code, or constitution made by ecclesiastical authority.,
C as in Canon (n.) The collection of books received as genuine Holy Scriptures, called the sacred canon, or general rule of moral and religious duty, given by inspiration; the Bible; also, any one of the canonical Scriptures. See Canonical books, under Canonical, a.,
C as in Canon (n.) In monasteries, a book containing the rules of a religious order.,
C as in Canon (n.) A catalogue of saints acknowledged and canonized in the Roman Catholic Church.,
C as in Canon (n.) A member of a cathedral chapter; a person who possesses a prebend in a cathedral or collegiate church.,
C as in Canon (n.) A musical composition in which the voices begin one after another, at regular intervals, successively taking up the same subject. It either winds up with a coda (tailpiece), or, as each voice finishes, commences anew, thus forming a perpetual fugue or round. It is the strictest form of imitation. See Imitation.,
C as in Canon (n.) The largest size of type having a specific name; -- so called from having been used for printing the canons of the church.,
C as in Canon (n.) The part of a bell by which it is suspended; -- called also ear and shank.,
C as in Canon (n.) See Carom.,
C as in Caon (n.) A deep gorge, ravine, or gulch, between high and steep banks, worn by water courses.,
C as in Canon bit () That part of a bit which is put in a horse's mouth.,
C as in Canon bone () The shank bone, or great bone above the fetlock, in the fore and hind legs of the horse and allied animals, corresponding to the middle metacarpal or metatarsal bone of most mammals. See Horse.,
C as in Canoness (n.) A woman who holds a canonry in a conventual chapter.,

C as in Canonicity (n.) The state or quality of being canonical; agreement with the canon.,

C as in Canonization (n.) The final process or decree (following beatifacation) by which the name of a deceased person is placed in the catalogue (canon) of saints and commended to perpetual veneration and invocation.,

C as in Cantarro (n.) A weight used in southern Europe and East for heavy articles. It varies in different localities; thus, at Rome it is nearly 75 pounds, in Sardinia nearly 94 pounds, in Cairo it is 95 pounds, in Syria about 503 pounds.,
C as in Cantarro (n.) A liquid measure in Spain, ranging from two and a half to four gallons.,

C as in Cantharides (pl. ) of Cantharis,
C as in Cantharis (n.) A beetle (Lytta, / Cantharis, vesicatoria), havin1g an elongated cylindrical body of a brilliant green color, and a nauseous odor; the blister fly or blister beetle, of the apothecary; -- also called Spanish fly. Many other species of Lytta, used for the same purpose, take the same name. See Blister beetle, under Blister. The plural form in usually applied to the dried insects used in medicine.,

C as in Caoutchin (n.) An inflammable, volatile, oily, liquid hydrocarbon, obtained by the destructive distillation of caoutchouc.,
C as in Caoutchouc (n.) A tenacious, elastic, gummy substance obtained from the milky sap of several plants of tropical South America (esp. the euphorbiaceous tree Siphonia elastica or Hevea caoutchouc), Asia, and Africa. Being impermeable to liquids and gases, and not readly affected by exposure to air, acids, and alkalies, it is used, especially when vulcanized, for many purposes in the arts and in manufactures. Also called India rubber (because it was first brought from India, and was formerly used chiefly for erasing pencil marks) and gum elastic. See Vulcanization.,
C as in Caoutchoucin (n.) See Caoutchin.,

C as in Capelin (n.) A small marine fish (Mallotus villosus) of the family Salmonidae, very abundant on the coasts of Greenland, Iceland, Newfoundland, and Alaska. It is used as a bait for the cod.,

C as in Capstan (n.) A vertical cleated drum or cylinder, revolving on an upright spindle, and surmounted by a drumhead with sockets for bars or levers. It is much used, especially on shipboard, for moving or raising heavy weights or exerting great power by traction upon a rope or cable, passing around the drum. It is operated either by steam power or by a number of men walking around the capstan, each pushing on the end of a lever fixed in its socket.,

C as in Capybara (n.) A large South American rodent (Hydrochaerus capybara) Living on the margins of lakes and rivers. It is the largest extant rodent, being about three feet long, and half that in height. It somewhat resembles the Guinea pig, to which it is related; -- called also cabiai and water hog.,

C as in Caracal (n.) A lynx (Felis, or Lynx, caracal.) It is a native of Africa and Asia. Its ears are black externally, and tipped with long black hairs.,
C as in Caracara (n.) A south American bird of several species and genera, resembling both the eagles and the vultures. The caracaras act as scavengers, and are also called carrion buzzards.,

C as in Caramel (n.) A kind of confectionery, usually a small cube or square of tenacious paste, or candy, of varying composition and flavor.,
C as in Carangoid (a.) Belonging to the Carangidae, a family of fishes allied to the mackerels, and including the caranx, American bluefish, and the pilot fish.,
C as in Caranx (n.) A genus of fishes, common on the Atlantic coast, including the yellow or golden mackerel.,
C as in Carapace (n.) The thick shell or shield which covers the back of the tortoise, or turtle, the crab, and other crustaceous animals.,
C as in Carapato (n.) A south American tick of the genus Amblyomma. There are several species, very troublesome to man and beast.,
C as in Carapax (n.) See Carapace.,
C as in Carat (n.) The weight by which precious stones and pearls are weighed.,
C as in Carat (n.) A twenty-fourth part; -- a term used in estimating the proportionate fineness of gold.,
C as in Caravan (n.) A company of travelers, pilgrims, or merchants, organized and equipped for a long journey, or marching or traveling together, esp. through deserts and countries infested by robbers or hostile tribes, as in Asia or Africa.,
C as in Caravan (n.) A large, covered wagon, or a train of such wagons, for conveying wild beasts, etc., for exhibition; an itinerant show, as of wild beasts.,
C as in Caravan (n.) A covered vehicle for carrying passengers or for moving furniture, etc.; -- sometimes shorted into van.,
C as in Caravaneer (n.) The leader or driver of the camels in caravan.,
C as in Caravansaries (pl. ) of Caravansary,
C as in Caravansary (n.) A kind of inn, in the East, where caravans rest at night, being a large, rude, unfurnished building, surrounding a court.,
C as in Caravel (n.) A name given to several kinds of vessels.,
C as in Caravel (n.) The caravel of the 16th century was a small vessel with broad bows, high, narrow poop, four masts, and lateen sails. Columbus commanded three caravels on his great voyage.,
C as in Caravel (n.) A Portuguese vessel of 100 or 150 tons burden.,
C as in Caravel (n.) A small fishing boat used on the French coast.,
C as in Caravel (n.) A Turkish man-of-war.,
C as in Caraway (n.) A biennial plant of the Parsley family (Carum Carui). The seeds have an aromatic smell, and a warm, pungent taste. They are used in cookery and confectionery, and also in medicine as a carminative.,
C as in Caraway (n.) A cake or sweetmeat containing caraway seeds.,
C as in Carbamic (a.) Pertaining to an acid so called.,
C as in Carbamide (n.) The technical name for urea.,
C as in Carbamine (n.) An isocyanide of a hydrocarbon radical. The carbamines are liquids, usually colorless, and of unendurable odor.,
C as in Carbanil (n.) A mobile liquid, CO.N.C6H5, of pungent odor. It is the phenyl salt of isocyanic acid.,
C as in Carbazol (n.) A white crystallized substance, C12H8NH, derived from aniline and other amines.,
C as in Carbazotate (n.) A salt of carbazotic or picric acid; a picrate.,
C as in Carbazotic (a.) Containing, or derived from, carbon and nitrogen.,
C as in Carbide (n.) A binary compound of carbon with some other element or radical, in which the carbon plays the part of a negative; -- formerly termed carburet.,
C as in Carbimide (n.) The technical name for isocyanic acid. See under Isocyanic.,
C as in Carbine (n.) A short, light musket or rifle, esp. one used by mounted soldiers or cavalry.,
C as in Carbineer (n.) A soldier armed with a carbine.,
C as in Carbinol (n.) Methyl alcohol, CH3OH; -- also, by extension, any one in the homologous series of paraffine alcohols of which methyl alcohol is the type.,
C as in Carbohydrate (n.) One of a group of compounds including the sugars, starches, and gums, which contain six (or some multiple of six) carbon atoms, united with a variable number of hydrogen and oxygen atoms, but with the two latter always in proportion as to form water; as dextrose, C6H12O6.,
C as in Carbohydride (n.) A hydrocarbon.,
C as in Carbolic (a.) Pertaining to, or designating, an acid derived from coal tar and other sources; as, carbolic acid (called also phenic acid, and phenol). See Phenol.,
C as in Carbolize (v. t.) To apply carbolic acid to; to wash or treat with carbolic acid.,
C as in Carbon (n.) An elementary substance, not metallic in its nature, which is present in all organic compounds. Atomic weight 11.97. Symbol C. it is combustible, and forms the base of lampblack and charcoal, and enters largely into mineral coals. In its pure crystallized state it constitutes the diamond, the hardest of known substances, occuring in monometric crystals like the octahedron, etc. Another modification is graphite, or blacklead, and in this it is soft, and occurs in hexagonal prisms or tables. When united with oxygen it forms carbon dioxide, commonly called carbonic acid, or carbonic oxide, according to the proportions of the oxygen; when united with hydrogen, it forms various compounds called hydrocarbons. Compare Diamond, and Graphite.,
C as in Carbonaceous (a.) Pertaining to, containing, or composed of, carbon.,
C as in Carbonade (n.) Alt. of Carbonado,
C as in Carbonado (n.) Flesh, fowl, etc., cut across, seasoned, and broiled on coals; a chop.,
C as in Carbonadoed (imp. & p. p.) of Carbonade,
C as in Carbonadoing (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Carbonade,
C as in Carbonado (v. t.) Alt. of Carbonade,
C as in Carbonade (v. t.) To cut (meat) across for frying or broiling; to cut or slice and broil.,
C as in Carbonade (v. t.) To cut or hack, as in fighting.,
C as in Carbonadoes (pl. ) of Carbonado,
C as in Carbonado (n.) A black variety of diamond, found in Brazil, and used for diamond drills. It occurs in irregular or rounded fragments, rarely distinctly crystallized, with a texture varying from compact to porous.,

C as in Carbonari (pl. ) of Carbonaro,
C as in Carbonaro (n.) A member of a secret political association in Italy, organized in the early part of the nineteenth centry for the purpose of changing the government into a republic.,

C as in Carbonize (v. t.) To convert (an animal or vegetable substance) into a residue of carbon by the action of fire or some corrosive agent; to char.,
C as in Carbonize (v. t.) To impregnate or combine with carbon, as in making steel by cementation.,
C as in Carbonometer (n.) An instrument for detecting and measuring the amount of carbon which is present, or more esp. the amount of carbon dioxide, by its action on limewater or by other means.,
C as in Carbonyl (n.) The radical (CO)'', occuring, always combined, in many compounds, as the aldehydes, the ketones, urea, carbonyl chloride, etc.,
C as in Carbostyril (n.) A white crystalline substance, C9H6N.OH, of acid properties derived from one of the amido cinnamic acids.,
C as in Carboxide (n.) A compound of carbon and oxygen, as carbonyl, with some element or radical; as, potassium carboxide.,
C as in Carboxyl (n.) The complex radical, CO.OH, regarded as the essential and characteristic constituent which all oxygen acids of carbon (as formic, acetic, benzoic acids, etc.) have in common; -- called also oxatyl.,
C as in Carboy (n.) A large, globular glass bottle, esp. one of green glass, inclosed in basket work or in a box, for protection; -- used commonly for carrying corrosive liquids; as sulphuric acid, etc.,
C as in Carbuncle (n.) A beautiful gem of a deep red color (with a mixture of scarlet) called by the Greeks anthrax; found in the East Indies. When held up to the sun, it loses its deep tinge, and becomes of the color of burning coal. The name belongs for the most part to ruby sapphire, though it has been also given to red spinel and garnet.,
C as in Carbuncle (n.) A very painful acute local inflammation of the subcutaneous tissue, esp. of the trunk or back of the neck, characterized by brawny hardness of the affected parts, sloughing of the skin and deeper tissues, and marked constitutional depression. It differs from a boil in size, tendency to spread, and the absence of a central core, and is frequently fatal. It is also called anthrax.,
C as in Carbuncle (n.) A charge or bearing supposed to represent the precious stone. It has eight scepters or staves radiating from a common center. Called also escarbuncle.,
C as in Carbuncled (a.) Set with carbuncles.,
C as in Carbuncled (a.) Affected with a carbuncle or carbuncles; marked with red sores; pimpled and blotched.,
C as in Carbuncular (a.) Belonging to a carbuncle; resembling a carbuncle; red; inflamed.,
C as in Carbunculation (n.) The blasting of the young buds of trees or plants, by excessive heat or cold.,

C as in Carnauba (n.) The Brazilian wax palm. See Wax palm.,
C as in Carnelian (n.) A variety of chalcedony, of a clear, deep red, flesh red, or reddish white color. It is moderately hard, capable of a good polish, and often used for seals.,
C as in Carneous (a.) Consisting of, or like, flesh; carnous; fleshy.,
C as in Carney (n.) A disease of horses, in which the mouth is so furred that the afflicted animal can not eat.,
C as in Carnifex (n.) The public executioner at Rome, who executed persons of the lowest rank; hence, an executioner or hangman.,
C as in Carnification (n.) The act or process of turning to flesh, or to a substance resembling flesh.,
C as in Carnify (v. i.) To form flesh; to become like flesh.,
C as in Carnin (n.) A white crystalline nitrogenous substance, found in extract of meat, and related to xanthin.,
C as in Carnival (n.) A festival celebrated with merriment and revelry in Roman Gatholic countries during the week before Lent, esp. at Rome and Naples, during a few days (three to ten) before Lent, ending with Shrove Tuesday.,
C as in Carnival (n.) Any merrymaking, feasting, or masquerading, especially when overstepping the bounds of decorum; a time of riotous excess.,
C as in Carnivora (n. pl.) An order of Mammallia including the lion, tiger, wolf bear, seal, etc. They are adapted by their structure to feed upon flesh, though some of them, as the bears, also eat vegetable food. The teeth are large and sharp, suitable for cutting flesh, and the jaws powerful.,
C as in Carnivoracity (n.) Greediness of appetite for flesh.,
C as in Carnivore (n.) One of the Carnivora.,
C as in Carnivorous (a.) Eating or feeding on flesh. The term is applied: (a) to animals which naturally seek flesh for food, as the tiger, dog, etc.; (b) to plants which are supposed to absorb animal food; (c) to substances which destroy animal tissue, as caustics.,
C as in Carnose (a.) Alt. of Carnous,
C as in Carnous (a.) Of or pertaining to flesh; fleshy.,
C as in Carnous (a.) Of a fleshy consistence; -- applied to succulent leaves, stems, etc.,
C as in Carnosity (n.) A fleshy excrescence; esp. a small excrescence or fungous growth.,
C as in Carnosity (n.) Fleshy substance or quality; fleshy covering.,
C as in Carob (n.) An evergreen leguminous tree (Ceratania Siliqua) found in the countries bordering the Mediterranean; the St. John's bread; -- called also carob tree.,
C as in Carob (n.) One of the long, sweet, succulent, pods of the carob tree, which are used as food for animals and sometimes eaten by man; -- called also St. John's bread, carob bean, and algaroba bean.,

C as in Carolus (n.) An English gold coin of the value of twenty or twenty-three shillings. It was first struck in the reign of Charles I.,
C as in Carom (n.) A shot in which the ball struck with the cue comes in contact with two or more balls on the table; a hitting of two or more balls with the player's ball. In England it is called cannon.,

C as in Carpet (n.) A heavy woven or felted fabric, usually of wool, but also of cotton, hemp, straw, etc.; esp. a floor covering made in breadths to be sewed together and nailed to the floor, as distinguished from a rug or mat; originally, also, a wrought cover for tables.,

C as in Carpetbag (n.) A portable bag for travelers; -- so called because originally made of carpet.,
C as in Carpetbagger (n.) An adventurer; -- a term of contempt for a Northern man seeking private gain or political advancement in the southern part of the United States after the Civil War (1865).,
C as in Carpeting (n.) The act of covering with carpets.,
C as in Carpeting (n.) Cloth or materials for carpets; carpets, in general.,

C as in Carpintero (n.) A california woodpecker (Melanerpes formicivorus), noted for its habit of inserting acorns in holes which it drills in trees. The acorns become infested by insect larvae, which, when grown, are extracted for food by the bird.,
C as in Carpogenic (a.) Productive of fruit, or causing fruit to be developed.,

C as in Carpology (n.) That branch of botany which relates to the structure of seeds and fruit.,
C as in Carpophagous (a.) Living on fruits; fruit-consuming.,
C as in Carpophore (n.) A slender prolongation of the receptacle as an axis between the carpels, as in Geranium and many umbelliferous plants.,
C as in Carpophyll (n.) A leaf converted into a fruit or a constituent portion of a fruit; a carpel. [See Illust. of Gymnospermous.],
C as in Carpophyte (n.) A flowerless plant which forms a true fruit as the result of fertilization, as the red seaweeds, the Ascomycetes, etc.,

(b) A spool holder or bobbin holder in a braiding machine. (c) A movable piece in magazine guns which transfers the cartridge to a position from which it can be thrust into the barrel.,

C as in Carronade (n.) A kind of short cannon, formerly in use, designed to throw a large projectile with small velocity, used for the purpose of breaking or smashing in, rather than piercing, the object aimed at, as the side of a ship. It has no trunnions, but is supported on its carriage by a bolt passing through a loop on its under side.,
C as in Carron oil () A lotion of linseed oil and lime water, used as an application to burns and scalds; -- first used at the Carron iron works in Scotland.,

C as in Caseic (a.) Of or pertaining to cheese; as, caseic acid.,
C as in Casein (n.) A proteid substance present in both the animal and the vegetable kingdom. In the animal kingdom it is chiefly found in milk, and constitutes the main part of the curd separated by rennet; in the vegetable kingdom it is found more or less abundantly in the seeds of leguminous plants. Its reactions resemble those of alkali albumin.,
C as in Case knife () A knife carried in a sheath or case.,
C as in Case knife () A large table knife; -- so called from being formerly kept in a case.,
C as in Casemate (n.) A bombproof chamber, usually of masonry, in which cannon may be placed, to be fired through embrasures; or one capable of being used as a magazine, or for quartering troops.,
C as in Casemate (n.) A hollow molding, chiefly in cornices.,
C as in Casemated (a.) Furnished with, protected by, or built like, a casemate.,
C as in Casement (n.) A window sash opening on hinges affixed to the upright side of the frame into which it is fitted. (Poetically) A window.,
C as in Casemented (a.) Having a casement or casements.,
C as in Caseous (a.) Of, pertaining to, or resembling, cheese; having the qualities of cheese; cheesy.,

C as in Cashbook (n.) A book in which is kept a register of money received or paid out.,
C as in Cashew (n.) A tree (Anacardium occidentale) of the same family which the sumac. It is native in tropical America, but is now naturalized in all tropical countries. Its fruit, a kidney-shaped nut, grows at the extremity of an edible, pear-shaped hypocarp, about three inches long.,
C as in Cashier (n.) One who has charge of money; a cash keeper; the officer who has charge of the payments and receipts (moneys, checks, notes), of a bank or a mercantile company.,
C as in Cahiered (imp. & p. p.) of Cashier,

C as in Cashier (v. t.) To put away or reject; to disregard.,
C as in Cashierer (n.) One who rejects, discards, or dismisses; as, a cashierer of monarchs.,
C as in Cashmere (n.) A rich stuff for shawls, scarfs, etc., originally made in Cashmere from the soft wool found beneath the hair of the goats of Cashmere, Thibet, and the Himalayas. Some cashmere, of fine quality, is richly embroidered for sale to Europeans.,
C as in Cashmere (n.) A dress fabric made of fine wool, or of fine wool and cotton, in imitation of the original cashmere.,
C as in Cashmerette (n.) A kind of dress goods, made with a soft and glossy surface like cashmere.,
C as in Cashoo (n.) See Catechu.,

C as in Casserole (n.) A small round dish with a handle, usually of porcelain.,
C as in Casserole (n.) A mold (in the shape of a hollow vessel or incasement) of boiled rice, mashed potato or paste, baked, and afterwards filled with vegetables or meat.,
C as in Cassia (n.) A genus of leguminous plants (herbs, shrubs, or trees) of many species, most of which have purgative qualities. The leaves of several species furnish the senna used in medicine.,
C as in Cassia (n.) The bark of several species of Cinnamomum grown in China, etc.; Chinese cinnamon. It is imported as cassia, but commonly sold as cinnamon, from which it differs more or less in strength and flavor, and the amount of outer bark attached.,
C as in Cassican (n.) An American bird of the genus Cassicus, allied to the starlings and orioles, remarkable for its skillfully constructed and suspended nest; the crested oriole. The name is also sometimes given to the piping crow, an Australian bird.,
C as in Cassideous (a.) Helmet-shaped; -- applied to a corolla having a broad, helmet-shaped upper petal, as in aconite.,
C as in Cassidony (n.) The French lavender (Lavandula Stoechas),
C as in Cassidony (n.) The goldilocks (Chrysocoma Linosyris) and perhaps other plants related to the genus Gnaphalium or cudweed.,
C as in Cassimere (n.) A thin, twilled, woolen cloth, used for men's garments.,
C as in Cassinette (n.) A cloth with a cotton warp, and a woof of very fine wool, or wool and silk.,
C as in Cassinian ovals () See under Oval.,
C as in Cassino (n.) A game at cards, played by two or more persons, usually for twenty-one points.,
C as in Cassioberry (n.) The fruit of the Viburnum obovatum, a shrub which grows from Virginia to Florida.,
C as in Cassiopeia (n.) A constellation of the northern hemisphere, situated between Cepheus and Perseus; -- so called in honor of the wife of Cepheus, a fabulous king of Ethiopia.,
C as in Cassiterite (n.) Native tin dioxide; tin stone; a mineral occurring in tetragonal crystals of reddish brown color, and brilliant adamantine luster; also massive, sometimes in compact forms with concentric fibrous structure resembling wood (wood tin), also in rolled fragments or pebbly (Stream tin). It is the chief source of metallic tin. See Black tin, under Black.,
C as in Cassius (n.) A brownish purple pigment, obtained by the action of some compounds of tin upon certain salts of gold. It is used in painting and staining porcelain and glass to give a beautiful purple color. Commonly called Purple of Cassius.,
C as in Cassock (n.) A long outer garment formerly worn by men and women, as well as by soldiers as part of their uniform.,
C as in Cassock (n.) A garment resembling a long frock coat worn by the clergy of certain churches when officiating, and by others as the usually outer garment.,
C as in Cassocked (a.) Clothed with a cassock.,
C as in Cassolette (n.) a box, or vase, with a perforated cover to emit perfumes.,
C as in Cassonade (n.) Raw sugar; sugar not refined.,
C as in Cassowaries (pl. ) of Cassowary,
C as in Cassowary (n.) A large bird, of the genus Casuarius, found in the east Indies. It is smaller and stouter than the ostrich. Its head is armed with a kind of helmet of horny substance, consisting of plates overlapping each other, and it has a group of long sharp spines on each wing which are used as defensive organs. It is a shy bird, and runs with great rapidity. Other species inhabit New Guinea, Australia, etc.,
C as in Cassumunar (n.) Alt. of Cassumuniar,
C as in Cassumuniar (n.) A pungent, bitter, aromatic, gingerlike root, obtained from the East Indies.,

C as in Cast iron () Highly carbonized iron, the direct product of the blast furnace; -- used for making castings, and for conversion into wrought iron and steel. It can not be welded or forged, is brittle, and sometimes very hard. Besides carbon, it contains sulphur, phosphorus, silica, etc.,
C as in Cast-iron (a.) Made of cast iron. Hence, Fig.: like cast iron; hardy; unyielding.,

C as in Casualty (n.) Numerical loss caused by death, wounds, discharge, or desertion.,
C as in Casuarina (n.) A genus of leafless trees or shrubs, with drooping branchlets of a rushlike appearance, mostly natives of Australia. Some of them are large, producing hard and heavy timber of excellent quality, called beefwood from its color.,

C as in Casuistieal (a.) Of or pertaining to casuists or casuistry.,
C as in Casuistry (a.) The science or doctrine of dealing with cases of conscience, of resolving questions of right or wrong in conduct, or determining the lawfulness or unlawfulness of what a man may do by rules and principles drawn from the Scriptures, from the laws of society or the church, or from equity and natural reason; the application of general moral rules to particular cases.,
C as in Casuistry (a.) Sophistical, equivocal, or false reasoning or teaching in regard to duties, obligations, and morals.,
C as in Casus (n.) An event; an occurrence; an occasion; a combination of circumstances; a case; an act of God. See the Note under Accident.,
C as in Cat (n.) An animal of various species of the genera Felis and Lynx. The domestic cat is Felis domestica. The European wild cat (Felis catus) is much larger than the domestic cat. In the United States the name wild cat is commonly applied to the bay lynx (Lynx rufus) See Wild cat, and Tiger cat.,
C as in Cat (n.) A strong vessel with a narrow stern, projecting quarters, and deep waist. It is employed in the coal and timber trade.,
C as in Cat (n.) A strong tackle used to draw an anchor up to the cathead of a ship.,
C as in Cat (n.) A double tripod (for holding a plate, etc.), having six feet, of which three rest on the ground, in whatever position in is placed.,
C as in Cat (n.) An old game; (a) The game of tipcat and the implement with which it is played. See Tipcat. (c) A game of ball, called, according to the number of batters, one old cat, two old cat, etc.,

C as in Catting (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Cat,
C as in Cat (v. t.) To bring to the cathead; as, to cat an anchor. See Anchor.,
C as in Cata () The Latin and English form of a Greek preposition, used as a prefix to signify down, downward, under, against, contrary or opposed to, wholly, completely; as in cataclysm, catarrh. It sometimes drops the final vowel, as in catoptric; and is sometimes changed to cath, as in cathartic, catholic.,
C as in Catabaptist (n.) One who opposes baptism, especially of infants.,
C as in Catabasion (n.) A vault under altar of a Greek church.,

C as in Catacaustic (a.) Relating to, or having the properties of, a caustic curve formed by reflection. See Caustic, a.,
C as in Catacaustic (n.) A caustic curve formed by reflection of light.,
C as in Catachresis (n.) A figure by which one word is wrongly put for another, or by which a word is wrested from its true signification; as, "To take arms against a sea of troubles". Shak. "Her voice was but the shadow of a sound." Young.,
C as in Catachrestic (a.) Alt. of Catachrestical,
C as in Catachrestical (a.) Belonging to, or in the manner of, a catachresis; wrested from its natural sense or form; forced; far-fetched.,
C as in Cataclysm (n.) An extensive overflow or sweeping flood of water; a deluge.,
C as in Cataclysm (n.) Any violent catastrophe, involving sudden and extensive changes of the earth's surface.,
C as in Cataclysmal (a.) Alt. of Cataclysmic,
C as in Cataclysmic (a.) Of or pertaining to a cataclysm.,
C as in Cataclysmist (n.) One who believes that the most important geological phenomena have been produced by cataclysms.,
C as in Catacomb (n.) A cave, grotto, or subterraneous place of large extent used for the burial of the dead; -- commonly in the plural.,
C as in Catacoustic (n.) That part of acoustics which treats of reflected sounds or echoes See Acoustics.,
C as in Catadioptric (a.) Alt. of Catadioptrical,
C as in Catadioptrical (a.) Pertaining to, produced by, or involving, both the reflection and refraction of light; as, a catadioptric light.,
C as in Catadioptrics (n.) The science which treats of catadioptric phenomena, or of the used of catadioptric instruments.,
C as in Catadrome (n.) A race course.,
C as in Catadrome (n.) A machine for raising or lowering heavy weights.,
C as in Catadromous (a.) Having the lowest inferior segment of a pinna nearer the rachis than the lowest superior one; -- said of a mode of branching in ferns, and opposed to anadromous.,
C as in Catadromous (a.) Living in fresh water, and going to the sea to spawn; -- opposed to anadromous, and said of the eel.,
C as in Catafalco (n.) See Catafalque.,
C as in Catafalque (n.) A temporary structure sometimes used in the funeral solemnities of eminent persons, for the public exhibition of the remains, or their conveyance to the place of burial.,
C as in Catagmatic (a.) Having the quality of consolidating broken bones.,
C as in Cataian (n.) A native of Cathay or China; a foreigner; -- formerly a term of reproach.,
C as in Catalan (a.) Of or pertaining to Catalonia.,
C as in Catalan (n.) A native or inhabitant of Catalonia; also, the language of Catalonia.,
C as in Catalectic (a.) Wanting a syllable at the end, or terminating in an imperfect foot; as, a catalectic verse.,
C as in Catalectic (a.) Incomplete; partial; not affecting the whole of a substance.,
C as in Catalepsy (n.) Alt. of Catalepsis,
C as in Catalepsis (n.) A sudden suspension of sensation and volition, the body and limbs preserving the position that may be given them, while the action of the heart and lungs continues.,
C as in Cataleptic (a.) Pertaining to, or resembling, catalepsy; affected with catalepsy; as, a cataleptic fit.,
C as in Catallacta (n. pl.) A division of Protozoa, of which Magosphaera is the type. They exist both in a myxopod state, with branched pseudopodia, and in the form of ciliated bodies united in free, spherical colonies.,
C as in Catallactics (n.) The science of exchanges, a branch of political economy.,
C as in Catalog (n. & v.) Catalogue.,
C as in Catalogize (v. t.) To insert in a catalogue; to register; to catalogue.,
C as in Catalogue (n.) A list or enumeration of names, or articles arranged methodically, often in alphabetical order; as, a catalogue of the students of a college, or of books, or of the stars.,
C as in Catalogued (imp. & p. p.) of Catalogue,
C as in Cataloguing (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Catalogue,
C as in Catalogue (v. t.) To make a list or catalogue; to insert in a catalogue.,
C as in Cataloguer (n.) A maker of catalogues; esp. one skilled in the making of catalogues.,
C as in Catalpa (n.) A genus of American and East Indian trees, of which the best know species are the Catalpa bignonioides, a large, ornamental North American tree, with spotted white flowers and long cylindrical pods, and the C. speciosa, of the Mississipi valley; -- called also Indian bean.,
C as in Catalyse (pl. ) of Catalysis,
C as in Catalysis (n.) Dissolution; degeneration; decay.,
C as in Catalysis (n.) A process by which reaction occurs in the presence of certain agents which were formerly believed to exert an influence by mere contact. It is now believed that such reactions are attended with the formation of an intermediate compound or compounds, so that by alternate composition and decomposition the agent is apparenty left unchanged; as, the catalysis of making ether from alcohol by means of sulphuric acid; or catalysis in the action of soluble ferments (as diastase, or ptyalin) on starch.,
C as in Catalysis (n.) The catalytic force.,
C as in Catalytic (a.) Relating to, or causing, catalysis.,
C as in Catalytic (n.) An agent employed in catalysis, as platinum black, aluminium chloride, etc.,
C as in Catamaran (n.) A kind of raft or float, consisting of two or more logs or pieces of wood lashed together, and moved by paddles or sail; -- used as a surf boat and for other purposes on the coasts of the East and West Indies and South America. Modified forms are much used in the lumber regions of North America, and at life-saving stations.,
C as in Catamaran (n.) Any vessel with twin hulls, whether propelled by sails or by steam; esp., one of a class of double-hulled pleasure boats remarkable for speed.,
C as in Catamaran (n.) A kind of fire raft or torpedo bat.,
C as in Catamaran (n.) A quarrelsome woman; a scold.,
C as in Catamenia (n. pl.) The monthly courses of women; menstrual discharges; menses.,
C as in Catamenial (a.) Pertaining to the catamenia, or menstrual discharges.,
C as in Catamite (n.) A boy kept for unnatural purposes.,
C as in Catamount (n.) The cougar. Applied also, in some parts of the United States, to the lynx.,
C as in Catanadromous (a.) Ascending and descending fresh streams from and to the sea, as the salmon; anadromous.,
C as in Catapasm (n.) A compound medicinal powder, used by the ancients to sprinkle on ulcers, to absorb perspiration, etc.,
C as in Catapeltic (a.) Of or pertaining to a catapult.,
C as in Catapetalous (a.) Having the petals held together by stamens, which grow to their bases, as in the mallow.,

C as in Catapult (n.) A forked stick with elastic band for throwing small stones, etc.,
C as in Cataract (n.) A great fall of water over a precipice; a large waterfall.,
C as in Cataract (n.) An opacity of the crystalline lens, or of its capsule, which prevents the passage of the rays of light and impairs or destroys the sight.,
C as in Cataract (n.) A kind of hydraulic brake for regulating the action of pumping engines and other machines; -- sometimes called dashpot.,
C as in Cataractous (a.) Of the nature of a cataract in the eye; affected with cataract.,
C as in Catarrh (n.) An inflammatory affection of any mucous membrane, in which there are congestion, swelling, and an altertion in the quantity and quality of mucus secreted; as, catarrh of the stomach; catarrh of the bladder.,
C as in Catarrhal (a.) Pertaining to, produced by, or attending, catarrh; of the nature of catarrh.,
C as in Catarrhine (n.) One of the Catarrhina, a division of Quadrumana, including the Old World monkeys and apes which have the nostrils close together and turned downward. See Monkey.,
C as in Catarrhous (a.) Catarrhal.,
C as in Catastaltic (a.) Checking evacuations through astringent or styptic qualities.,
C as in Catastasis (n.) That part of a speech, usually the exordium, in which the orator sets forth the subject matter to be discussed.,
C as in Catastasis (n.) The state, or condition of anything; constitution; habit of body.,
C as in Catasterism (n.) A placing among the stars; a catalogue of stars.,
C as in Catastrophe (n.) An event producing a subversion of the order or system of things; a final event, usually of a calamitous or disastrous nature; hence, sudden calamity; great misfortune.,
C as in Catastrophe (n.) The final event in a romance or a dramatic piece; a denouement, as a death in a tragedy, or a marriage in a comedy.,
C as in Catastrophe (n.) A violent and widely extended change in the surface of the earth, as, an elevation or subsidence of some part of it, effected by internal causes.,
C as in Catastrophic (a.) Of a pertaining to a catastrophe.,
C as in Catastrophism (n.) The doctrine that the geological changes in the earth's crust have been caused by the sudden action of violent physical causes; -- opposed to the doctrine of uniformism.,
C as in Catastrophist (n.) One who holds the theory or catastrophism.,
C as in Catawba (n.) A well known light red variety of American grape.,
C as in Catawba (n.) A light-colored, sprightly American wine from the Catawba grape.,
C as in Catawbas (n. pl.) An Appalachian tribe of Indians which originally inhabited the regions near the Catawba river and the head waters of the Santee.,
C as in Catbird (n.) An American bird (Galeoscoptes Carolinensis), allied to the mocking bird, and like it capable of imitating the notes of other birds, but less perfectly. Its note resembles at times the mewing of a cat.,
C as in Catboat (n.) A small sailboat, with a single mast placed as far forward as possible, carring a sail extended by a gaff and long boom. See Illustration in Appendix.,
C as in Catcall (n.) A sound like the cry of a cat, such as is made in playhouses to express dissatisfaction with a play; also, a small shrill instrument for making such a noise.,

C as in Catch (v. t.) To lay hold on; to seize, especially with the hand; to grasp (anything) in motion, with the effect of holding; as, to catch a ball.,

C as in Catch (v. t.) To seize with the senses or the mind; to apprehend; as, to catch a melody.,
C as in Catch (v. t.) To communicate to; to fasten upon; as, the fire caught the adjoining building.,
C as in Catch (v. t.) To engage and attach; to please; to charm.,
C as in Catch (v. t.) To get possession of; to attain.,
C as in Catch (v. t.) To take or receive; esp. to take by sympathy, contagion, infection, or exposure; as, to catch the spirit of an occasion; to catch the measles or smallpox; to catch cold; the house caught fire.,
C as in Catch (v. t.) To come upon unexpectedly or by surprise; to find; as, to catch one in the act of stealing.,
C as in Catch (v. t.) To reach in time; to come up with; as, to catch a train.,
C as in Catch (v. i.) To attain possession.,
C as in Catch (v. i.) To be held or impeded by entanglement or a light obstruction; as, a kite catches in a tree; a door catches so as not to open.,
C as in Catch (v. i.) To take hold; as, the bolt does not catch.,

It contains a large portion of tannin or tannic acid, and is used in medicine and in the arts. It is also known by the names terra japonica, cutch, gambier, etc.,

C as in Caterpillar (n.) The larval state of a butterfly or any lepidopterous insect; sometimes, but less commonly, the larval state of other insects, as the sawflies, which are also called false caterpillars. The true caterpillars have three pairs of true legs, and several pairs of abdominal fleshy legs (prolegs) armed with hooks. Some are hairy, others naked. They usually feed on leaves, fruit, and succulent vegetables, being often very destructive, Many of them are popularly called worms, as the cutworm, cankerworm, army worm, cotton worm, silkworm.,
C as in Caterpillar (n.) A plant of the genus Scorpiurus, with pods resembling caterpillars.,
C as in Caterwauled (imp. & p. p.) of Caterwaul,
C as in Caterwauling (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Caterwaul,
C as in Caterwaul (v. i.) To cry as cats in rutting time; to make a harsh, offensive noise.,
C as in Caterwaul (n.) A caterwauling.,
C as in Caterwauling (n.) The cry of cats; a harsh, disagreeable noise or cry like the cry of cats.,
C as in Catery (n.) The place where provisions are deposited.,
C as in Cates (n.) Provisions; food; viands; especially, luxurious food; delicacies; dainties.,
C as in Cat-eyed (a.) Having eyes like a cat; hence, able to see in the dark.,
C as in Catfall (n.) A rope used in hoisting the anchor to the cathead.,
C as in Catfish (n.) A name given in the United States to various species of siluroid fishes; as, the yellow cat (Amiurus natalis); the bind cat (Gronias nigrilabrus); the mud cat (Pilodictic oilwaris), the stone cat (Noturus flavus); the sea cat (Arius felis), etc. This name is also sometimes applied to the wolf fish. See Bullhrad.,

C as in Catgut (n.) A sort of linen or canvas, with wide interstices.,

C as in Cathartin (n.) The bitter, purgative principle of senna. It is a glucoside with the properties of a weak acid; -- called also cathartic acid, and cathartina.,
C as in Cathay (n.) China; -- an old name for the Celestial Empire, said have been introduced by Marco Polo and to be a corruption of the Tartar name for North China (Khitai, the country of the Khitans.),
C as in Cathead (n.) A projecting piece of timber or iron near the bow of vessel, to which the anchor is hoisted and secured.,

C as in Cathedralic (a.) Cathedral.,
C as in Cathedrated (a.) Relating to the chair or office of a teacher.,
C as in Catheretic (n.) A mild kind caustic used to reduce warts and other excrescences.,

C as in Catherine wheel () A revolving piece of fireworks resembling in form the window of the same name.,
C as in Catheter (n.) The name of various instruments for passing along mucous canals, esp. applied to a tubular instrument to be introduced into the bladder through the urethra to draw off the urine.,
C as in Catheterism (n.) Alt. of Catheterization,
C as in Catheterization (n.) The operation of introducing a catheter.,
C as in Catheterized (imp. & p. p.) of Catheterize,
C as in Catheterizing (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Catheterize,
C as in Catheterize (v. t.) To operate on with a catheter.,
C as in Cathetometer (n.) An instrument for the accurate measurement of small differences of height; esp. of the differences in the height of the upper surfaces of two columns of mercury or other fluid, or of the same column at different times. It consists of a telescopic leveling apparatus (d), which slides up or down a perpendicular metallic standard very finely graduated (bb). The telescope is raised or depressed in order to sight the objects or surfaces, and the differences in vertical height are thus shown on the graduated standard.,
C as in Catheti (pl. ) of Cathetus,
C as in Cathetus (n.) One line or radius falling perpendicularly on another; as, the catheti of a right-angled triangle, that is, the two sides that include the right angle.,
C as in Cathode (n.) The part of a voltaic battery by which the electric current leaves substances through which it passes, or the surface at which the electric current passes out of the electrolyte; the negative pole; -- opposed to anode.,
C as in Cathodic (a.) A term applied to the centrifugal, or efferent, course of the nervous influence.,
C as in Cat-hole (n.) One of two small holes astern, above the gunroom ports, through which hawsers may be passed.,
C as in Catholic (a.) Universal or general; as, the catholic faith.,
