C as in Catholicism (n.) The doctrines or faith of the Roman Catholic church, or adherence thereto.,
C as in Catholicity (n.) The state or quality of being catholic; universality.,
C as in Catholicity (n.) Liberality of sentiments; catholicism.,
C as in Catholicity (n.) Adherence or conformity to the system of doctrine held by all parts of the orthodox Christian church; the doctrine so held; orthodoxy.,
C as in Catholicity (n.) Adherence to the doctrines of the church of Rome, or the doctrines themselves.,
C as in Catholicize (v. t. & i.) To make or to become catholic or Roman Catholic.,
C as in Catholicly (adv.) In a catholic manner; generally; universally.,
C as in Catholicness (n.) The quality of being catholic; universality; catholicity.,
C as in Catholicon (n.) A remedy for all diseases; a panacea.,
C as in Catholicos (n.) The spiritual head of the Armenian church, who resides at Etchmiadzin, Russia, and has ecclesiastical jurisdiction over, and consecrates the holy oil for, the Armenians of Russia, Turkey, and Persia, including the Patriarchs of Constantinople, Jerusalem, and Sis.,
C as in Catilinarian (a.) Pertaining to Catiline, the Roman conspirator; resembling Catiline's conspiracy.,
C as in Cation (n.) An electro-positive substance, which in electro-decomposition is evolved at the cathode; -- opposed to anion.,
C as in Catkin (n.) An ament; a species of inflorescence, consisting of a slender axis with many unisexual apetalous flowers along its sides, as in the willow and poplar, and (as to the staminate flowers) in the chestnut, oak, hickory, etc. -- so called from its resemblance to a cat's tail. See Illust. of Ament.,
C as in Catlike (a.) Like a cat; stealthily; noiselessly.,
C as in Catling (n.) A little cat; a kitten.,
C as in Catling (n.) Catgut; a catgut string.,
C as in Catling (n.) A double-edged, sharp-pointed dismembering knife.,
C as in Catlinite (n.) A red clay from the Upper Missouri region, used by the Indians for their pipes.,
C as in Catnip (n.) Alt. of Catmint,
C as in Catmint (n.) A well-know plant of the genus Nepeta (N. Cataria), somewhat like mint, having a string scent, and sometimes used in medicine. It is so called because cats have a peculiar fondness for it.,
C as in Cato-cathartic (n.) A remedy that purges by alvine discharges.,
C as in Catonian (a.) Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the stern old Roman, Cato the Censor; severe; inflexible.,
C as in Cat o' nine tails () See under Cat.,
C as in Catopter (n.) Alt. of Catoptron,
C as in Catoptron (n.) A reflecting optical glass or instrument; a mirror.,
C as in Catoptric (a.) Alt. of Catoptrical,
C as in Catoptrical (a.) Of or pertaining to catoptrics; produced by reflection.,
C as in Catoptrics (n.) That part of optics which explains the properties and phenomena of reflected light, and particularly that which is reflected from mirrors or polished bodies; -- formerly called anacamptics.,
C as in Catoptromancy (n.) A species of divination, which was performed by letting down a mirror into water, for a sick person to look at his face in it. If his countenance appeared distorted and ghastly, it was an ill omen; if fresh and healthy, it was favorable.,
C as in Catopron (n.) See Catopter.,
C as in Catpipe (n.) See Catcall.,
C as in Cat-rigged (a.) Rigged like a catboat.,
C as in Cat-salt (n.) A sort of salt, finely granulated, formed out of the bittern or leach brine.,
C as in Cat's-eye (n.) A variety of quartz or chalcedony, exhibiting opalescent reflections from within, like the eye of a cat. The name is given to other gems affording like effects, esp. the chrysoberyl.,
C as in Cat's-foot (n.) A plant (Nepeta Glechoma) of the same genus with catnip; ground ivy.,
C as in Cat-silver (n.) Mica.,
C as in Catskill period () The closing subdivision of the Devonian age in America. The rocks of this period are well developed in the Catskill mountains, and extend south and west under the Carboniferous formation. See the Diagram under Geology.,
C as in Catsos (pl. ) of Catso,
C as in Catso (n.) A base fellow; a rogue; a cheat.,
C as in Cat's-paw (n.) A light transitory air which ruffles the surface of the water during a calm, or the ripples made by such a puff of air.,
C as in Cat's-paw (n.) A particular hitch or turn in the bight of a rope, into which a tackle may be hooked.,
C as in Cat's-paw (n.) A dupe; a tool; one who, or that which, is used by another as an instrument to a accomplish his purposes.,
C as in Cat's-tail (n.) See Timothy, Cat-tail, Cirrus.,
C as in Catstick (n.) A stick or club employed in the game of ball called cat or tipcat.,
C as in Catstitch (v. t.) To fold and sew down the edge of with a coarse zigzag stitch.,
C as in Catsup (n.) Same as Catchup, and Ketchup.,
C as in Cat-tail (n.) A tall rush or flag (Typha latifolia) growing in marshes, with long, flat leaves, and having its flowers in a close cylindrical spike at the top of the stem. The leaves are frequently used for seating chairs, making mats, etc. See Catkin.,
C as in Cattish (a.) Catlike; feline,
C as in Cattle (n. pl.) Quadrupeds of the Bovine family; sometimes, also, including all domestic quadrupeds, as sheep, goats, horses, mules, asses, and swine.,
C as in Catty (n.) An East Indian Weight of 1 1/3 pounds.,
C as in Caucasian (a.) Of or pertaining to the Caucasus, a mountainous region between the Black and Caspian seas.,
C as in Caucasian (a.) Of or pertaining to the white races of mankind, of whom the people about Mount Caucasus were formerly taken as the type.,
C as in Caucasian (n.) A native or inhabitant of the Caucasus, esp. a Circassian or Georgian.,
C as in Caucasian (n.) A member of any of the white races of mankind.,
C as in Caucus (n.) A meeting, especially a preliminary meeting, of persons belonging to a party, to nominate candidates for public office, or to select delegates to a nominating convention, or to confer regarding measures of party policy; a political primary meeting.,

C as in Celestite (n.) Native strontium sulphate, a mineral so named from its occasional delicate blue color. It occurs crystallized, also in compact massive and fibrous forms.,
C as in Celestine (n.) Alt. of Celestinian,
C as in Celestinian (n.) A monk of the austere branch of the Franciscan Order founded by Celestine V. in the 13th centry.,

C as in Celibacy (n.) The state of being unmarried; single life, esp. that of a bachelor, or of one bound by vows not to marry.,

C as in Celibatist (n.) One who lives unmarried.,
C as in Celidography (n.) A description of apparent spots on the disk of the sun, or on planets.,
C as in Cell (n.) A very small and close apartment, as in a prison or in a monastery or convent; the hut of a hermit.,
C as in Cell (n.) A small religious house attached to a monastery or convent.,
C as in Cell (n.) Any small cavity, or hollow place.,
C as in Cell (n.) The space between the ribs of a vaulted roof.,
C as in Cell (n.) Same as Cella.,
C as in Cell (n.) A jar of vessel, or a division of a compound vessel, for holding the exciting fluid of a battery.,
C as in Cell (n.) One of the minute elementary structures, of which the greater part of the various tissues and organs of animals and plants are composed.,
C as in Celled (imp. & p. p.) of Cell,
C as in Cell (v. t.) To place or inclose in a cell.,
C as in Cella (n.) The part inclosed within the walls of an ancient temple, as distinguished from the open porticoes.,
C as in Cellar (n.) A room or rooms under a building, and usually below the surface of the ground, where provisions and other stores are kept.,
C as in Cellarage (n.) The space or storerooms of a cellar; a cellar.,
C as in Cellarage (n.) Chare for storage in a cellar.,
C as in Cellarer (n.) A steward or butler of a monastery or chapter; one who has charge of procuring and keeping the provisions.,
C as in Cellaret (n.) A receptacle, as in a dining room, for a few bottles of wine or liquor, made in the form of a chest or coffer, or a deep drawer in a sideboard, and usually lined with metal.,
C as in Cellarist (n.) Same as Cellarer.,
C as in Celled (a.) Containing a cell or cells.,
C as in Cellepore (n.) A genus of delicate branching corals, made up of minute cells, belonging to the Bryozoa.,
C as in Celliferous (a.) Bearing or producing cells.,
C as in Cellos (pl. ) of Cello,
C as in Celli (pl. ) of Cello,
C as in Cello (n.) A contraction for Violoncello.,
C as in Cellular (a.) Consisting of, or containing, cells; of or pertaining to a cell or cells.,
C as in Cellulated (a.) Cellular.,
C as in Cellule (n.) A small cell.,
C as in Celluliferous (a.) Bearing or producing little cells.,
C as in Cellulitis (n.) An inflammantion of the cellular or areolar tissue, esp. of that lying immediately beneath the skin.,
C as in Celluloid (n.) A substance composed essentially of gun cotton and camphor, and when pure resembling ivory in texture and color, but variously colored to imitate coral, tortoise shell, amber, malachite, etc. It is used in the manufacture of jewelry and many small articles, as combs, brushes, collars, and cuffs; -- originally called xylonite.,
C as in Cellulose (a.) Consisting of, or containing, cells.,
C as in Cellulose (n.) The substance which constitutes the essential part of the solid framework of plants, of ordinary wood, linen, paper, etc. It is also found to a slight extent in certain animals, as the tunicates. It is a carbohydrate, (C6H10O5)n, isomeric with starch, and is convertible into starches and sugars by the action of heat and acids. When pure, it is a white amorphous mass. See Starch, Granulose, Lignin.,
C as in Celotomy (n.) The act or operation of cutting, to relieve the structure in strangulated hernia.,
C as in Celsiture (n.) Height; altitude.,
C as in Celsius (n.) The Celsius thermometer or scale, so called from Anders Celsius, a Swedish astronomer, who invented it. It is the same as the centigrade thermometer or scale.,
C as in Celt (n.) One of an ancient race of people, who formerly inhabited a great part of Central and Western Europe, and whose descendants at the present day occupy Ireland, Wales, the Highlands of Scotland, and the northern shores of France.,
C as in Celt (n.) A weapon or implement of stone or metal, found in the tumuli, or barrows, of the early Celtic nations.,
C as in Celtiberian (a.) Of or pertaining to the ancient Celtiberia (a district in Spain lying between the Ebro and the Tagus) or its inhabitants the Celtiberi (Celts of the river Iberus).,

C as in Cembalo (n.) An old name for the harpsichord.,
C as in Cement (n.) Any substance used for making bodies adhere to each other, as mortar, glue, etc.,
C as in Cement (n.) A kind of calcined limestone, or a calcined mixture of clay and lime, for making mortar which will harden under water.,
C as in Cement (n.) The powder used in cementation. See Cementation, n., 2.,
C as in Cement (n.) Bond of union; that which unites firmly, as persons in friendship, or men in society.,
C as in Cement (n.) The layer of bone investing the root and neck of a tooth; -- called also cementum.,
C as in Cemented (imp. & p. p.) of Cement,
C as in Cementing (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Cement,
C as in Cement (n.) To unite or cause to adhere by means of a cement.,
C as in Cement (n.) To unite firmly or closely.,

C as in Cemental (a.) Of or pertaining to cement, as of a tooth; as, cemental tubes.,
C as in Cementation (n.) The act or process of cementing.,
C as in Cementation (n.) A process which consists in surrounding a solid body with the powder of other substances, and heating the whole to a degree not sufficient to cause fusion, the physical properties of the body being changed by chemical combination with powder; thus iron becomes steel by cementation with charcoal, and green glass becomes porcelain by cementation with sand.,
C as in Cementatory (a.) Having the quality of cementing or uniting firmly.,
C as in Cementer (n.) A person or thing that cements.,
C as in Cementitious (n.) Of the nature of cement.,
C as in Cemeterial (a.) Of or pertaining to a cemetery.,
C as in Cemeteries (pl. ) of Cemetery,
C as in Cemetery (n.) A place or ground set apart for the burial of the dead; a graveyard; a churchyard; a necropolis.,
C as in Cenanthy (n.) The absence or suppression of the essential organs (stamens and pistil) in a flower.,
C as in Cenation (n.) Meal-taking; dining or supping.,
C as in Cenatory (a.) Of or pertaining to dinner or supper.,
C as in Cenobite (n.) One of a religious order, dwelling in a convent, or a community, in opposition to an anchoret, or hermit, who lives in solitude.,
C as in Cenobitic (a.) Alt. of Cenobitical,
C as in Cenobitical (a.) Of or pertaining to a cenobite.,
C as in Cenobitism (n.) The state of being a cenobite; the belief or practice of a cenobite.,
C as in Cenogamy (n.) The state of a community which permits promiscuous sexual intercourse among its members, as in certain societies practicing communism.,
C as in Cenotaph (n.) An empty tomb or a monument erected in honor of a person who is buried elsewhere.,
C as in Cenotaphy (n.) A cenotaph.,
C as in Cenozoic (a.) Belonging to the most recent division of geological time, including the tertiary, or Age of mammals, and the Quaternary, or Age of man. [Written also caenozoic, cainozoic, kainozoic.] See Geology.,

C as in Cent (n.) A hundred; as, ten per cent, the proportion of ten parts in a hundred.,
C as in Cent (n.) A United States coin, the hundredth part of a dollar, formerly made of copper, now of copper, tin, and zinc.,
C as in Cent (n.) An old game at cards, supposed to be like piquet; -- so called because 100 points won the game.,
C as in Centage (n.) Rate by the hundred; percentage.,
C as in Cental (n.) A weight of one hundred pounds avoirdupois; -- called in many parts of the United States a Hundredweight.,

C as in Centare (n.) A measure of area, the hundredth part of an are; one square meter, or about 1/ square yards.,
C as in Centaur (n.) A fabulous being, represented as half man and half horse.,
C as in Centaur (n.) A constellation in the southern heavens between Hydra and the Southern Cross.,
C as in Centaurea (n.) A large genus of composite plants, related to the thistles and including the cornflower or bluebottle (Centaurea Cyanus) and the star thistle (C. Calcitrapa).,
C as in Centaury (n.) A gentianaceous plant not fully identified. The name is usually given to the Erytheraea Centaurium and the Chlora perfoliata of Europe, but is also extended to the whole genus Sabbatia, and even to the unrelated Centaurea.,

C as in Center (n.) A point equally distant from the extremities of a line, figure, or body, or from all parts of the circumference of a circle; the middle point or place.,
C as in Center (n.) The middle or central portion of anything.,

C as in Center (n.) The earth.,
C as in Center (n.) Those members of a legislative assembly (as in France) who support the existing government. They sit in the middle of the legislative chamber, opposite the presiding officer, between the conservatives or monarchists, who sit on the right of the speaker, and the radicals or advanced republicans who occupy the seats on his left, See Right, and Left.,
C as in Center (n.) A temporary structure upon which the materials of a vault or arch are supported in position until the work becomes self-supporting.,

C as in Centerboard (n.) Alt. of Centreboard,
C as in Centreboard (n.) A movable or sliding keel formed of a broad board or slab of wood or metal which may be raised into a water-tight case amidships, when in shallow water, or may be lowered to increase the area of lateral resistance and prevent leeway when the vessel is beating to windward. It is used in vessels of all sizes along the coast of the United States,

C as in Centinody (n.) A weed with a stem of many joints (Illecebrum verticillatum); also, the Polygonum aviculare or knotgrass.,
C as in Centiped (n.) A species of the Myriapoda; esp. the large, flattened, venomous kinds of the order Chilopoda, found in tropical climates. they are many-jointed, and have a great number of feet.,
C as in Centistere (n.) The hundredth part of a stere, equal to .353 cubic feet.,
C as in Centner (n.) A weight divisible first into a hundred parts, and then into smaller parts.,
C as in Centner (n.) The commercial hundredweight in several of the continental countries, varying in different places from 100 to about 112 pounds.,

C as in Centrolecithal (a.) Having the food yolk placed at the center of the ovum, segmentation being either regular or unequal.,
C as in Centrolinead (n.) An instrument for drawing lines through a point, or lines converging to a center.,
C as in Centrolineal (a.) Converging to a center; -- applied to lines drawn so as to meet in a point or center.,
C as in Centrosome (n.) A peculiar rounded body lying near the nucleus of a cell. It is regarded as the dynamic element by means of which the machinery of cell division is organized.,

C as in Centumvir (n.) One of a court of about one hundred judges chosen to try civil suits. Under the empire the court was increased to 180, and met usually in four sections.,

C as in Cephalanthium (n.) Same as Anthodium.,
C as in Cephalaspis (n.) A genus of fossil ganoid fishes found in the old red sandstone or Devonian formation. The head is large, and protected by a broad shield-shaped helmet prolonged behind into two lateral points.,
C as in Cephalata (n. pl.) A large division of Mollusca, including all except the bivalves; -- so called because the head is distinctly developed. See Illustration in Appendix.,
C as in Cephalate (a.) Having a head.,
C as in Cephalic (a.) Of or pertaining to the head. See the Note under Anterior.,
C as in Cephalic (n.) A medicine for headache, or other disorder in the head.,
C as in Cephalitis (n.) Same as Phrenitis.,
C as in Cephalization (n.) Domination of the head in animal life as expressed in the physical structure; localization of important organs or parts in or near the head, in animal development.,
C as in Cephalo () A combining form denoting the head, of the head, connected with the head; as, cephalosome, cephalopod.,
C as in Cephalocercal (a.) Relating to the long axis of the body.,
C as in Cephaloid (a.) Shaped like the head.,
C as in Cephalology (n.) The science which treats of the head.,
C as in Cephalomere (n.) One of the somites (arthromeres) which make up the head of arthropods.,
C as in Cephalometer (n.) An instrument measuring the dimensions of the head of a fetus during delivery.,
C as in Cephalon (n.) The head.,
C as in Cephalophora (n. pl.) The cephalata.,
C as in Cephalopod (n.) Alt. of Cephalopode,
C as in Cephalopode (n.) One of the Cephalopoda.,
C as in Cephalopoda (n. pl.) The highest class of Mollusca.,
C as in Cephalopodic (a.) Alt. of Cephalopodous,
C as in Cephalopodous (a.) Belonging to, or resembling, the cephalopods.,
C as in Cephaloptera (n.) One of the generic names of the gigantic ray (Manta birostris), known as devilfish and sea devil. It is common on the coasts of South Carolina, Florida, and farther south. Some of them grow to enormous size, becoming twenty feet of more across the body, and weighing more than a ton.,
C as in Cephalosome (n.) The anterior region or head of insects and other arthropods.,
C as in Cephalostyle (n.) The anterior end of the notochord and its bony sheath in the base of cartilaginous crania.,
C as in Cephalothorax (n.) The anterior portion of any one of the Arachnida and higher Crustacea, consisting of the united head and thorax.,
C as in Cephalotome (n.) An instrument for cutting into the fetal head, to facilitate delivery.,
C as in Cephalotomy (n.) Dissection or opening of the head.,
C as in Cephalotomy (n.) Craniotomy; -- usually applied to bisection of the fetal head with a saw.,
C as in Cephalotribe (n.) An obstetrical instrument for performing cephalotripsy.,
C as in Cephalotripsy (n.) The act or operation of crushing the head of a fetus in the womb in order to effect delivery.,
C as in Cephalotrocha (n.) A kind of annelid larva with a circle of cilia around the head.,
C as in Cephalous (a.) Having a head; -- applied chiefly to the Cephalata, a division of mollusks.,
C as in Cepheus (n.) A northern constellation near the pole. Its head, which is in the Milky Way, is marked by a triangle formed by three stars of the fourth magnitude. See Cassiopeia.,
C as in Ceraceous (a.) Having the texture and color of new wax; like wax; waxy.,
C as in Cerago (n.) Beebread.,
C as in Ceramic (a.) Of or pertaining to pottery; relating to the art of making earthenware; as, ceramic products; ceramic ornaments for ceilings.,
C as in Ceramics (n.) The art of making things of baked clay; as pottery, tiles, etc.,
C as in Ceramics (n.) Work formed of clay in whole or in part, and baked; as, vases, urns, etc.,
C as in Cerargyrite (n.) Native silver chloride, a mineral of a white to pale yellow or gray color, darkening on exposure to the light. It may be cut by a knife, like lead or horn (hence called horn silver).,
C as in Cerasin (n.) A white amorphous substance, the insoluble part of cherry gum; -- called also meta-arabinic acid.,
C as in Cerasin (n.) A gummy mucilaginous substance; -- called also bassorin, tragacanthin, etc.,
C as in Cerasinous (a.) Pertaining to, or containing, cerasin.,
C as in Cerasinous (a.) Of a cherry color.,
C as in Cerastes (n.) A genus of poisonous African serpents, with a horny scale over each eye; the horned viper.,
C as in Cerate (n.) An unctuous preparation for external application, of a consistence intermediate between that of an ointment and a plaster, so that it can be spread upon cloth without the use of heat, but does not melt when applied to the skin.,
C as in Cerated (p. a.) Covered with wax.,
C as in Ceratine (a.) Sophistical.,
C as in Ceratobranchia (n. pl.) A group of nudibranchiate Mollusca having on the back papilliform or branched organs serving as gills.,
C as in Ceratobranchial (a.) Pertaining to the bone, or cartilage, below the epibranchial in a branchial arch.,
C as in Ceratobranchial (n.) A ceratobranchial bone, or cartilage.,
C as in Ceratodus (n.) A genus of ganoid fishes, of the order Dipnoi, first known as Mesozoic fossil fishes; but recently two living species have been discovered in Australian rivers. They have lungs so well developed that they can leave the water and breathe in air. In Australia they are called salmon and baramunda. See Dipnoi, and Archipterygium.,
C as in Ceratohyal (a.) Pertaining to the bone, or cartilage, below the epihyal in the hyoid arch.,
C as in Ceratohyal (n.) A ceratohyal bone, or cartilage, which, in man, forms one of the small horns of the hyoid.,
C as in Ceratosaurus (n.) A carnivorous American Jurassic dinosaur allied to the European Megalosaurus. The animal was nearly twenty feet in length, and the skull bears a bony horn core on the united nasal bones. See Illustration in Appendix.,
C as in Ceratospongiae (n. pl.) An order of sponges in which the skeleton consists of horny fibers. It includes all the commercial sponges.,
C as in Ceraunics (n.) That branch of physics which treats of heat and electricity.,
C as in Ceraunoscope (n.) An instrument or apparatus employed in the ancient mysteries to imitate thunder and lightning.,
C as in Cerberean (a.) Of or pertaining to, or resembling, Cerberus.,
C as in Cerberus (n.) A monster, in the shape of a three-headed dog, guarding the entrance into the infernal regions, Hence: Any vigilant custodian or guardian, esp. if surly.,
C as in Cerberus (n.) A genus of East Indian serpents, allied to the pythons; the bokadam.,
C as in Cercal (a.) Of or pertaining to the tail.,
C as in Cercarle (pl. ) of Cercaria,
C as in Cercaria (n.) The larval form of a trematode worm having the shape of a tadpole, with its body terminated by a tail-like appendage.,

C as in Cercarian (n.) One of the Cercariae.,

C as in Cerealia (n. pl.) The cereals.,
C as in Cerealin (n.) A nitrogenous substance closely resembling diastase, obtained from bran, and possessing the power of converting starch into dextrin, sugar, and lactic acid.,
C as in Cerebel (n.) The cerebellum.,
C as in Cerebellar (a.) Alt. of Cerebellous,
C as in Cerebellous (a.) Pertaining to the cerebellum.,
C as in Cerebellums (pl. ) of Cerebellum,
C as in Cerebella (pl. ) of Cerebellum,
C as in Cerebellum (n.) The large lobe of the hind brain in front of and above the medulla; the little brain. It controls combined muscular action. See Brain.,
C as in Cerebral (a.) Of or pertaining to the cerebrum.,
C as in Cerebral (n.) One of a class of lingual consonants in the East Indian languages. See Lingual, n.,
C as in Cerebralism (n.) The doctrine or theory that psychical phenomena are functions or products of the brain only.,
C as in Cerebralist (n.) One who accepts cerebralism.,
C as in Cerebrate (v. i.) To exhibit mental activity; to have the brain in action.,
C as in Cerebration (n.) Action of the brain, whether conscious or unconscious.,
C as in Cerebric (a.) Of, pertaining to, or derived from, the brain.,
C as in Cerebricity (n.) Brain power.,
C as in Cerebriform (a.) Like the brain in form or substance.,
C as in Cerebrifugal (a.) Applied to those nerve fibers which go from the brain to the spinal cord, and so transfer cerebral impulses (centrifugal impressions) outwards.,
C as in Cerebrin (n.) A nonphosphorized, nitrogenous substance, obtained from brain and nerve tissue by extraction with boiling alcohol. It is uncertain whether it exists as such in nerve tissue, or is a product of the decomposition of some more complex substance.,
C as in Cerebripetal (a.) Applied to those nerve fibers which go from the spinal cord to the brain and so transfer sensations (centripetal impressions) from the exterior inwards.,
C as in Cerebritis (n.) Inflammation of the cerebrum.,
C as in Cerebroid (a.) Resembling, or analogous to, the cerebrum or brain.,
C as in Cerebrology (n.) The science which treats of the cerebrum or brain.,
C as in Cerebropathy (n.) A hypochondriacal condition verging upon insanity, occurring in those whose brains have been unduly taxed; -- called also brain fag.,
C as in Cerebroscopy (n.) Examination of the brain for the diagnosis of disease; esp., the act or process of diagnosticating the condition of the brain by examination of the interior of the eye (as with an ophthalmoscope).,
C as in Cerebrose (n.) A sugarlike body obtained by the decomposition of the nitrogenous non-phosphorized principles of the brain.,
C as in Cerebro-spinal (a.) Of or pertaining to the central nervous system consisting of the brain and spinal cord.,
C as in Cerebrums (pl. ) of Cerebrum,
C as in Cerebra (pl. ) of Cerebrum,
C as in Cerebrum (n.) The anterior, and in man the larger, division of the brain; the seat of the reasoning faculties and the will. See Brain.,
C as in Cerecloth (n.) A cloth smeared with melted wax, or with some gummy or glutinous matter.,
C as in Cerement (n.) A cerecloth used for the special purpose of enveloping a dead body when embalmed.,
C as in Cerement (n.) Any shroud or wrapping for the dead.,
C as in Ceremonial (a.) Relating to ceremony, or external rite; ritual; according to the forms of established rites.,
C as in Ceremonial (a.) Observant of forms; ceremonious. [In this sense ceremonious is now preferred.],
C as in Ceremonial (n.) A system of rules and ceremonies, enjoined by law, or established by custom, in religious worship, social intercourse, or the courts of princes; outward form.,
C as in Ceremonial (n.) The order for rites and forms in the Roman Catholic church, or the book containing the rules prescribed to be observed on solemn occasions.,
C as in Ceremonialism (n.) Adherence to external rites; fondness for ceremony.,
C as in Ceremonially (adv.) According to rites and ceremonies; as, a person ceremonially unclean.,
C as in Ceremonialness (n.) Quality of being ceremonial.,
C as in Ceremonious (a.) Consisting of outward forms and rites; ceremonial. [In this sense ceremonial is now preferred.],
C as in Ceremonious (a.) According to prescribed or customary rules and forms; devoted to forms and ceremonies; formally respectful; punctilious.,
C as in Ceremoniously (adv.) In a ceremonious way.,
C as in Ceremoniousness (n.) The quality, or practice, of being ceremonious.,
C as in Ceremonies (pl. ) of Ceremony,
C as in Ceremony (n.) Ar act or series of acts, often of a symbolical character, prescribed by law, custom, or authority, in the conduct of important matters, as in the performance of religious duties, the transaction of affairs of state, and the celebration of notable events; as, the ceremony of crowning a sovereign; the ceremonies observed in consecrating a church; marriage and baptismal ceremonies.,

C as in Ceremony (n.) A ceremonial symbols; an emblem, as a crown, scepter, garland, etc.,
C as in Ceremony (n.) A sign or prodigy; a portent.,

C as in Ceres (n.) The first discovered asteroid.,
C as in Ceresin (n.) A white wax, made by bleaching and purifying ozocerite, and used as a substitute for beeswax.,
C as in Cereus (n.) A genus of plants of the Cactus family. They are natives of America, from California to Chili.,
C as in Cerial (a.) Same as Cerrial.,
C as in Ceriferous (a.) Producing wax.,
C as in Cerin (n.) A waxy substance extracted by alcohol or ether from cork; sometimes applied also to the portion of beeswax which is soluble in alcohol.,
C as in Cerin (n.) A variety of the mineral allanite.,
C as in Cerinthian (n.) One of an ancient religious sect, so called from Cerinthus, a Jew, who attempted to unite the doctrines of Christ with the opinions of the Jews and Gnostics.,
C as in Ceriph (n.) One of the fine lines of a letter, esp. one of the fine cross strokes at the top and bottom of letters.,
C as in Cerise (a.) Cherry-colored; a light bright red; -- applied to textile fabrics, especially silk.,
C as in Cerite (n.) A gastropod shell belonging to the family Cerithiidae; -- so called from its hornlike form.,
C as in Cerite (n.) A mineral of a brownish of cherry-red color, commonly massive. It is a hydrous silicate of cerium and allied metals.,
C as in Cerium (n.) A rare metallic element, occurring in the minerals cerite, allanite, monazite, etc. Symbol Ce. Atomic weight 141.5. It resembles iron in color and luster, but is soft, and both malleable and ductile. It tarnishes readily in the air.,
C as in Cernuous (a.) Inclining or nodding downward; pendulous; drooping; -- said of a bud, flower, fruit, or the capsule of a moss.,
C as in Cero (n.) A large and valuable fish of the Mackerel family, of the genus Scomberomorus. Two species are found in the West Indies and less commonly on the Atlantic coast of the United States, -- the common cero (Scomberomorus caballa), called also kingfish, and spotted, or king, cero (S. regalis).,

C as in Certiorari (n.) A writ issuing out of chancery, or a superior court, to call up the records of a inferior court, or remove a cause there depending, in order that the party may have more sure and speedy justice, or that errors and irregularities may be corrected. It is obtained upon complaint of a party that he has not received justice, or can not have an impartial trial in the inferior court.,

C as in Cestode (n.) One of the Cestoidea.,
C as in Cestoid (a.) Of or pertaining to the Cestoidea.,
C as in Cestoid (n.) One of the Cestoidea.,
C as in Cestoidea (n. pl.) A class of parasitic worms (Platelminthes) of which the tapeworms are the most common examples. The body is flattened, and usually but not always long, and composed of numerous joints or segments, each of which may contain a complete set of male and female reproductive organs. They have neither mouth nor intestine. See Tapeworm.,
C as in Cestoldean (n.) One of the Cestoidea.,
C as in Cestraciont (n.) A shark of the genus Cestracion, and of related genera. The posterior teeth form a pavement of bony plates for crushing shellfish. Most of the species are extinct. The Port Jackson shark and a similar one found in California are living examples.,
C as in Cestraciont (a.) Pertaining to, or characteristic of, the genus Cestracion.,
C as in Cestus (n.) A girdle; particularly that of Aphrodite (or Venus) which gave the wearer the power of exciting love.,
C as in Cestus (n.) A genus of Ctenophora. The typical species (Cestus Veneris) is remarkable for its brilliant iridescent colors, and its long, girdlelike form.,
C as in Cestus (n.) A covering for the hands of boxers, made of leather bands, and often loaded with lead or iron.,

C as in Cetacea (n. pl.) An order of marine mammals, including the whales. Like ordinary mammals they breathe by means of lungs, and bring forth living young which they suckle for some time. The anterior limbs are changed to paddles; the tail flukes are horizontal. There are two living suborders:,

C as in C. G. S. () An abbreviation for Centimeter, Gram, Second. -- applied to a system of units much employed in physical science, based upon the centimeter as the unit of length, the gram as the unit of weight or mass, and the second as the unit of time.,
C as in Chab (n.) The red-bellied wood pecker (Melanerpes Carolinus).,

C as in Cabazite (n.) A mineral occuring in glassy rhombohedral crystals, varying, in color from white to yellow or red. It is essentially a hydrous silicate of alumina and lime. Called also chabasie.,
C as in Chablis (n.) A white wine made near Chablis, a town in France.,
C as in Chablis (n.) a white wine resembling Chablis{1}, but made elsewhere, as in California.,

C as in Chacma (n.) A large species of African baboon (Cynocephalus porcarius); -- called also ursine baboon. [See Illust. of Baboon.],
C as in Chaconne (n.) An old Spanish dance in moderate three-four measure, like the Passacaglia, which is slower. Both are used by classical composers as themes for variations.,
C as in Chad (n.) See Shad.,
C as in Chaetetes (n.) A genus of fossil corals, common in the lower Silurian limestones.,
C as in Chaetiferous (a.) Bearing setae.,
C as in Chaetodont (n.) A marine fish of the family Chaetodontidae. The chaetodonts have broad, compressed bodies, and usually bright colors.,
C as in Chaetodont (a.) Of or pertaining to the Chaetodonts or the family Chaetodontidae.,
C as in Chaetognath (a.) Of or pertaining to the Chaetognatha.,
C as in Chaetognatha (n. pl.) An order of free-swimming marine worms, of which the genus Sagitta is the type. They have groups of curved spines on each side of the head.,
C as in Chaetopod (a.) Pertaining to the Chaetopoda.,
C as in Chaetopod (n.) One of the Chaetopoda.,
C as in Chaetopoda (n. pl.) A very extensive order of Annelida, characterized by the presence of lateral setae, or spines, on most or all of the segments. They are divided into two principal groups: Oligochaeta, including the earthworms and allied forms, and Polychaeta, including most of the marine species.,
C as in Chaetotaxy (n.) The arrangement of bristles on an insect.,

C as in Chain pump () A pump consisting of an endless chain, running over a drum or wheel by which it is moved, and dipping below the water to be raised. The chain has at intervals disks or lifts which fit the tube through which the ascending part passes and carry the water to the point of discharge.,
C as in Chain stitch () An ornamental stitch like the links of a chain; -- used in crocheting, sewing, and embroidery.,
C as in Chain stitch () A stitch in which the looping of the thread or threads forms a chain on the under side of the work; the loop stitch, as distinguished from the lock stitch. See Stitch.,
C as in Chain wheel () A chain pulley, or sprocket wheel.,
C as in Chain wheel () An inversion of the chain pump, by which it becomes a motor driven by water.,
C as in Chainwork (n.) Work looped or linked after the manner of a chain; chain stitch work.,

The prosecution or defense of a suit, whether by furnishing money or personal services, by one who has no legitimate concern therein, in consideration of an agreement that he shall receive, in the event of success, a share of the matter in suit; maintenance with the addition of an agreement to divide the thing in suit. C as in Chancery (n.) In England, formerly, the highest court of judicature next to the Parliament, exercising jurisdiction at law, but chiefly in equity; but under the jurisdiction act of 1873 it became the chancery division of the High Court of Justice, and now exercises jurisdiction only in equity.,
C as in Chancery (n.) In the Unites States, a court of equity; equity; proceeding in equity.,

C as in Charpie (n.) Straight threads obtained by unraveling old linen cloth; -- used for surgical dressings.,
C as in Charqui (n.) Jerked beef; beef cut into long strips and dried in the wind and sun.,
C as in Charr (n.) See 1st Char.,
C as in Charras (n.) The gum resin of the hemp plant (Cannabis sativa). Same as Churrus.,
C as in Charre (n.) See Charge, n., 17.,
C as in Charry (a.) Pertaining to charcoal, or partaking of its qualities.,
C as in Chart (n.) A sheet of paper, pasteboard, or the like, on which information is exhibited, esp. when the information is arranged in tabular form; as, an historical chart.,
C as in Chart (n.) A map; esp., a hydrographic or marine map; a map on which is projected a portion of water and the land which it surrounds, or by which it is surrounded, intended especially for the use of seamen; as, the United States Coast Survey charts; the English Admiralty charts.,
C as in Chart (n.) A written deed; a charter.,
C as in Charted (imp. & p. p.) of Chart,
C as in Chart (v. t.) To lay down in a chart; to map; to delineate; as, to chart a coast.,
C as in Charta (n.) Material on which instruments, books, etc., are written; parchment or paper.,
C as in Charta (n.) A charter or deed; a writing by which a grant is made. See Magna Charta.,
C as in Chartaceous (a.) Resembling paper or parchment; of paper-like texture; papery.,
C as in Charte (n.) The constitution, or fundamental law, of the French monarchy, as established on the restoration of Louis XVIII., in 1814.,
C as in Charter (n.) A written evidence in due form of things done or granted, contracts made, etc., between man and man; a deed, or conveyance.,
C as in Charter (n.) An instrument in writing, from the sovereign power of a state or country, executed in due form, bestowing rights, franchises, or privileges.,
C as in Charter (n.) An act of a legislative body creating a municipal or other corporation and defining its powers and privileges. Also, an instrument in writing from the constituted authorities of an order or society (as the Freemasons), creating a lodge and defining its powers.,
C as in Charter (n.) A special privilege, immunity, or exemption.,
C as in Charter (n.) The letting or hiring a vessel by special contract, or the contract or instrument whereby a vessel is hired or let; as, a ship is offered for sale or charter. See Charter party, below.,

C as in Chartering (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Charter,
C as in Charter (v. t.) To establish by charter.,

C as in Chartered (a.) Granted or established by charter; having, or existing under, a charter; having a privilege by charter.,
C as in Chartered (a.) Hired or let by charter, as a ship.,
C as in Charterer (n.) One who charters; esp. one who hires a ship for a voyage.,
C as in Charterhouse (n.) A well known public school and charitable foundation in the building once used as a Carthusian monastery (Chartreuse) in London.,
C as in Charterist (n.) Same as Chartist.,
C as in Chartism (n.) The principles of a political party in England (1838-48), which contended for universal suffrage, the vote by ballot, annual parliaments, equal electoral districts, and other radical reforms, as set forth in a document called the People's Charter.,
C as in Chartist (n.) A supporter or partisan of chartism.,
C as in Chartless (a.) Without a chart; having no guide.,
C as in Chartless (a.) Not mapped; uncharted; vague.,
C as in Chartographer (n.) Alt. of Chartography,
C as in Chartographic (n.) Alt. of Chartography,
C as in Chartography (n.) Same as Cartographer, Cartographic, Cartography, etc.,
C as in Chartomancy (n.) Divination by written paper or by cards.,
C as in Chartometer (n.) An instrument for measuring charts or maps.,
C as in Chartreuse (n.) A Carthusian monastery; esp. La Grande Chartreuse, mother house of the order, in the mountains near Grenoble, France.,
C as in Chartreuse (n.) An alcoholic cordial, distilled from aromatic herbs; -- made at La Grande Chartreuse.,
C as in Chartreux (n.) A Carthusian.,
C as in Chartulary (n.) See Cartulary.,

C as in Charybdis (n.) A dangerous whirlpool on the coast of Sicily opposite Scylla on the Italian coast. It is personified as a female monster. See Scylla.,

C as in Chase (v. i.) To give chase; to hunt; as, to chase around after a doctor.,
C as in Chase (v.) Vehement pursuit for the purpose of killing or capturing, as of an enemy, or game; an earnest seeking after any object greatly desired; the act or habit of hunting; a hunt.,
C as in Chase (v.) That which is pursued or hunted.,
C as in Chase (v.) An open hunting ground to which game resorts, and which is private properly, thus differing from a forest, which is not private property, and from a park, which is inclosed. Sometimes written chace.,
C as in Chase (v.) A division of the floor of a gallery, marked by a figure or otherwise; the spot where a ball falls, and between which and the dedans the adversary must drive his ball in order to gain a point.,
C as in Chase (n.) A rectangular iron frame in which pages or columns of type are imposed.,
C as in Chase (n.) The part of a cannon from the reenforce or the trunnions to the swell of the muzzle. See Cannon.,
C as in Chase (n.) A groove, or channel, as in the face of a wall; a trench, as for the reception of drain tile.,
C as in Chase (n.) A kind of joint by which an overlap joint is changed to a flush joint, by means of a gradually deepening rabbet, as at the ends of clinker-built boats.,
C as in Chase (v. t.) To ornament (a surface of metal) by embossing, cutting away parts, and the like.,

C as in Chasing (n.) The art of ornamenting metal by means of chasing tools; also, a piece of ornamental work produced in this way.,

C as in Chasuble (n.) The outer vestment worn by the priest in saying Mass, consisting, in the Roman Catholic Church, of a broad, flat, back piece, and a narrower front piece, the two connected over the shoulders only. The back has usually a large cross, the front an upright bar or pillar, designed to be emblematical of Christ's sufferings. In the Greek Church the chasuble is a large round mantle.,

C as in Chat (v. t.) To talk of.,
C as in Chat (n.) Light, familiar talk; conversation; gossip.,
C as in Chat (n.) A bird of the genus Icteria, allied to the warblers, in America. The best known species are the yellow-breasted chat (I. viridis), and the long-tailed chat (I. longicauda). In Europe the name is given to several birds of the family Saxicolidae, as the stonechat, and whinchat.,

C as in Chatterer (n.) A bird of the family Ampelidae -- so called from its monotonous note. The Bohemion chatterer (Ampelis garrulus) inhabits the arctic regions of both continents. In America the cedar bird is a more common species. See Bohemian chatterer, and Cedar bird.,

C as in Check (n.) A word of warning denoting that the king is in danger; such a menace of a player's king by an adversary's move as would, if it were any other piece, expose it to immediate capture. A king so menaced is said to be in check, and must be made safe at the next move.,

C as in Cheese (n.) The flat, circular, mucilaginous fruit of the dwarf mallow (Malva rotundifolia).,
C as in Cheese (n.) A low courtesy; -- so called on account of the cheese form assumed by a woman's dress when she stoops after extending the skirts by a rapid gyration.,

C as in Cheesiness (n.) The quality of being cheesy.,
C as in Cheesy (a.) Having the nature, qualities, taste, form, consistency, or appearance of cheese.,
C as in Cheetah (n.) A species of leopard (Cynaelurus jubatus) tamed and used for hunting in India. The woolly cheetah of South Africa is C. laneus.,

C as in Cheiroptera (n. pl.) An order of mammalia, including the bats, having four toes of each of the anterior limbs elongated and connected by a web, so that they can be used like wings in flying. See Bat.,
C as in Cheiropterous (a.) Belonging to the Cheiroptera, or Bat family.,

C as in Cheiropterygium (n.) The typical pentadactyloid limb of the higher vertebrates.,

C as in Cheirotherium (n.) A genus of extinct animals, so named from fossil footprints rudely resembling impressions of the human hand, and believed to have been made by labyrinthodont reptiles. See Illustration in Appendix.,

C as in Chekmak (n.) A turkish fabric of silk and cotton, with gold thread interwoven.,
C as in Chelae (pl. ) of Chela,
C as in Chela (n.) The pincherlike claw of Crustacea and Arachnida.,
C as in Chelate (a.) Same as Cheliferous.,
C as in Chelerythrine (n.) An alkaloidal principle obtained from the celandine, and named from the red color of its salts. It is a colorless crystalline substance, and acts as an acrid narcotic poison. It is identical with sanguinarine.,
C as in Chelicerae (pl. ) of Chelicera,
C as in Chelicera (n.) One of the anterior pair of mouth organs, terminated by a pincherlike claw, in scorpions and allied Arachnida. They are homologous with the falcers of spiders, and probably with the mandibles of insects.,
C as in Chelidon (n.) The hollow at the flexure of the arm.,
C as in Chelidonic (a.) Of, pertaining to, or derived from, the celandine.,
C as in Chelidonius (n.) A small stone taken from the gizzard of a young swallow. -- anciently worn as a medicinal charm.,
C as in Chelifer (n.) See Book scorpion, under Book.,
C as in Cheliferous (a.) Having cheliform claws, like a crab.,
C as in Cheliform (a.) Having a movable joint or finger closing against a preceding joint or a projecting part of it, so that the whole may be used for grasping, as the claw of a crab; pincherlike.,
C as in Chelone (n.) A genus of hardy perennial flowering plants, of the order Scrophulariaceae, natives of North America; -- called also snakehead, turtlehead, shellflower, etc.,
C as in Chelonia (n. pl.) An order of reptiles, including the tortoises and turtles, peculiar in having a part of the vertebrae, ribs, and sternum united with the dermal plates so as to form a firm shell. The jaws are covered by a horny beak. See Reptilia; also, Illust. in Appendix.,
C as in Chelonian (a.) Of or pertaining to animals of the tortoise kind.,
C as in Chelonian (n.) One of the Chelonia.,
C as in Chelura (n.) A genus of marine amphipod crustacea, which bore into and sometimes destroy timber.,
C as in Chely (n.) A claw. See Chela.,

C as in Chemic (n.) A solution of chloride of lime.,
C as in Chemic (a.) Chemical.,
C as in Chemical (a.) Pertaining to chemistry; characterized or produced by the forces and operations of chemistry; employed in the processes of chemistry; as, chemical changes; chemical combinations.,
C as in Chemical (n.) A substance used for producing a chemical effect; a reagent.,
C as in Chemically (adv.) According to chemical principles; by chemical process or operation.,
C as in Chemiglyphic (a.) Engraved by a voltaic battery.,
C as in Chemiloon (n.) A garment for women, consisting of chemise and drawers united in one.,
C as in Chemise (n.) A shift, or undergarment, worn by women.,
C as in Chemise (n.) A wall that lines the face of a bank or earthwork.,
C as in Chemisette (n.) An under-garment, worn by women, usually covering the neck, shoulders, and breast.,
C as in Chemism (n.) The force exerted between the atoms of elementary substance whereby they unite to form chemical compounds; chemical attaction; affinity; -- sometimes used as a general expression for chemical activity or relationship.,
C as in Chemist (n.) A person versed in chemistry or given to chemical investigation; an analyst; a maker or seller of chemicals or drugs.,
C as in Chemistry (n.) That branch of science which treats of the composition of substances, and of the changes which they undergo in consequence of alterations in the constitution of the molecules, which depend upon variations of the number, kind, or mode of arrangement, of the constituent atoms. These atoms are not assumed to be indivisible, but merely the finest grade of subdivision hitherto attained. Chemistry deals with the changes in the composition and constitution of molecules. See Atom, Molecule.,
C as in Chemistry (n.) An application of chemical theory and method to the consideration of some particular subject; as, the chemistry of iron; the chemistry of indigo.,
C as in Chemistry (n.) A treatise on chemistry.,
C as in Chemitype (n.) One of a number of processes by which an impression from an engraved plate is obtained in relief, to be used for printing on an ordinary printing press.,
C as in Chemolysis (n.) A term sometimes applied to the decomposition of organic substance into more simple bodies, by the use of chemical agents alone.,
C as in Chemosmosis (n.) Chemical action taking place through an intervening membrane.,
C as in Chemosmotic (a.) Pertaining to, or produced by, chemosmosis.,
C as in Chemung period () A subdivision in the upper part of the Devonian system in America, so named from the Chemung River, along which the rocks are well developed. It includes the Portage and Chemung groups or epochs. See the Diagram under Geology.,
C as in Cheng (n.) A chinese reed instrument, with tubes, blown by the mouth.,
C as in Chenille (n.) Tufted cord, of silk or worsted, for the trimming of ladies' dresses, for embroidery and fringes, and for the weft of Chenille rugs.,
C as in Chenomorphae (n. pl.) An order of birds, including the swans, ducks, geese, flamingoes and screamers.,

C as in Cherry (n.) A tree or shrub of the genus Prunus (Which also includes the plum) bearing a fleshy drupe with a bony stone;,
C as in Cherry (n.) The common garden cherry (Prunus Cerasus), of which several hundred varieties are cultivated for the fruit, some of which are, the begarreau, blackheart, black Tartarian, oxheart, morelle or morello, May-duke (corrupted from Medoc in France).,
C as in Cherry (n.) The wild cherry; as, Prunus serotina (wild black cherry), valued for its timber; P. Virginiana (choke cherry), an American shrub which bears astringent fruit; P. avium and P. Padus, European trees (bird cherry).,

C as in Cherry (a.) Like a red cherry in color; ruddy; blooming; as, a cherry lip; cherry cheeks.,

C as in Cherub (n.) A symbolical winged figure of unknown form used in connection with the mercy seat of the Jewish Ark and Temple.,
C as in Cherub (n.) One of a order of angels, variously represented in art. In European painting the cherubim have been shown as blue, to denote knowledge, as distinguished from the seraphim (see Seraph), and in later art the children's heads with wings are generally called cherubs.,
C as in Cherub (n.) A beautiful child; -- so called because artists have represented cherubs as beautiful children.,

C as in Chess (n.) A species of brome grass (Bromus secalinus) which is a troublesome weed in wheat fields, and is often erroneously regarded as degenerate or changed wheat; it bears a very slight resemblance to oats, and if reaped and ground up with wheat, so as to be used for food, is said to produce narcotic effects; -- called also cheat and Willard's bromus.,
C as in Chess-apple (n.) The wild service of Europe (Purus torminalis).,

C as in Chesses (n. pl.) The platforms, consisting of two or more planks doweled together, for the flooring of a temporary military bridge.,

C as in Chigoe (n.) Alt. of Chigre,
C as in Chigre (n.) A species of flea (Pulex penetrans), common in the West Indies and South America, which often attacks the feet or any exposed part of the human body, and burrowing beneath the skin produces great irritation. When the female is allowed to remain and breed, troublesome sores result, which are sometimes dangerous. See Jigger.,

C as in Chilognath (n.) A myriapod of the order Chilognatha.,
C as in Chilognatha (n. pl.) One of the two principal orders of myriapods. They have numerous segments, each bearing two pairs of small, slender legs, which are attached ventrally, near together.,
C as in Chiloma (n.) The tumid upper lip of certain mammals, as of a camel.,
C as in Chilopod (n.) A myriapod of the order Chilopoda.,
C as in Chilopoda (n. pl.) One of the orders of myriapods, including the centipeds. They have a single pair of elongated legs attached laterally to each segment; well developed jaws; and a pair of thoracic legs converted into poison fangs. They are insectivorous, very active, and some species grow to the length of a foot.,
C as in Chilostoma (n. pl.) Alt. of Chilostomata,
C as in Chilostomata (n. pl.) An extensive suborder of marine Bryozoa, mostly with calcareous shells. They have a movable lip and a lid to close the aperture of the cells.,
C as in Chilostomatous (a.) Of or pertaining to the Chilostoma.,
C as in Chiltern Hundreds () A tract of crown land in Buckinghamshire and Oxfordshire, England, to which is attached the nominal office of steward. As members of Parliament cannot resign, when they wish to go out they accept this stewardship, which legally vacates their seats.,
C as in Chimaera (n.) A cartilaginous fish of several species, belonging to the order Holocephali. The teeth are few and large. The head is furnished with appendages, and the tail terminates in a point.,

C as in Chloasma (n.) A cutaneous affection characterized by yellow or yellowish brown pigmented spots.,
C as in Chloral (n.) A colorless oily liquid, CCl3.CHO, of a pungent odor and harsh taste, obtained by the action of chlorine upon ordinary or ethyl alcohol.,
C as in Chloral (n.) Chloral hydrate.,
C as in Chloralamide (n.) A compound of chloral and formic amide used to produce sleep.,
C as in Chloralism (n.) A morbid condition of the system resulting from excessive use of chloral.,
C as in Chloralum (n.) An impure aqueous solution of chloride of aluminium, used as an antiseptic and disinfectant.,
C as in Chloranil (n.) A yellow crystalline substance, C6Cl4.O2, regarded as a derivative of quinone, obtained by the action of chlorine on certain benzene derivatives, as aniline.,

C as in Chloraurate (n.) See Aurochloride.,
C as in Chlorhydric (a.) Same as Hydrochloric.,
C as in Chlorhydrin (n.) One of a class of compounds formed from certain polybasic alcohols (and especially glycerin) by the substitution of chlorine for one or more hydroxyl groups.,
C as in Chloric (a.) Pertaining to, or obtained from, chlorine; -- said of those compounds of chlorine in which this element has a valence of five, or the next to its highest; as, chloric acid, HClO3.,
C as in Chloridate (v. t.) To treat or prepare with a chloride, as a plate with chloride of silver, for the purposes of photography.,
C as in Chloride (n.) A binary compound of chlorine with another element or radical; as, chloride of sodium (common salt).,
C as in Chloridic (a.) Of or pertaining to a chloride; containing a chloride.,
C as in Chloridize (v. t.) See Chloridate.,

C as in Chlorinated (imp. & p. p.) of Chlorinate,
C as in Chlorinating (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Chlorinate,
C as in Chlorinate (v. t.) To treat, or cause to combine, with chlorine.,
C as in Chlorination (n.) The act or process of subjecting anything to the action of chlorine; especially, a process for the extraction of gold by exposure of the auriferous material to chlorine gas.,
C as in Chlorine (n.) One of the elementary substances, commonly isolated as a greenish yellow gas, two and one half times as heavy as air, of an intensely disagreeable suffocating odor, and exceedingly poisonous. It is abundant in nature, the most important compound being common salt. It is powerful oxidizing, bleaching, and disinfecting agent. Symbol Cl. Atomic weight, 35.4.,
C as in Chloriodic (a.) Compounded of chlorine and iodine; containing chlorine and iodine.,
C as in Chloriodine (n.) A compound of chlorine and iodine.,
C as in Chlorite (n.) The name of a group of minerals, usually of a green color and micaceous to granular in structure. They are hydrous silicates of alumina, iron, and magnesia.,
C as in Chlorite (n.) Any salt of chlorous acid; as, chlorite of sodium.,
C as in Chloritic (a.) Pertaining to, or containing, chlorite; as, chloritic sand.,
C as in Chlormethane (n.) A colorless gas, CH3Cl, of a sweet odor, easily condensed to a liquid; -- called also methyl chloride.,
C as in Chloro- () A prefix denoting that chlorine is an ingredient in the substance named.,
C as in Chlorocruorin (n.) A green substance, supposed to be the cause of the green color of the blood in some species of worms.,
C as in Chlorodyne (n.) A patent anodyne medicine, containing opium, chloroform, Indian hemp, etc.,
C as in Chloroform (n.) A colorless volatile liquid, CHCl3, having an ethereal odor and a sweetish taste, formed by treating alcohol with chlorine and an alkali. It is a powerful solvent of wax, resin, etc., and is extensively used to produce anaesthesia in surgical operations; also externally, to alleviate pain.,

C as in Chloropal (n.) A massive mineral, greenish in color, and opal-like in appearance. It is essentially a hydrous silicate of iron.,
C as in Chloropeptic (a.) Of or pertaining to an acid more generally called pepsin-hydrochloric acid.,
C as in Chlorophane (n.) A variety of fluor spar, which, when heated, gives a beautiful emerald green light.,
C as in Chlorophane (n.) The yellowish green pigment in the inner segment of the cones of the retina. See Chromophane.,
C as in Chlorophyll (n.) Literally, leaf green; a green granular matter formed in the cells of the leaves (and other parts exposed to light) of plants, to which they owe their green color, and through which all ordinary assimilation of plant food takes place. Similar chlorophyll granules have been found in the tissues of the lower animals.,
C as in Chloroplastid (n.) A granule of chlorophyll; -- also called chloroleucite.,
C as in Chloroplatinic (a.) See Platinichloric.,
C as in Chlorosis (n.) The green sickness; an anaemic disease of young women, characterized by a greenish or grayish yellow hue of the skin, weakness, palpitation, etc.,
C as in Chlorosis (n.) A disease in plants, causing the flowers to turn green or the leaves to lose their normal green color.,
C as in Chlorotic (a.) Pertaining to, or affected by, chlorosis.,
C as in Chlorous (a.) Of, pertaining to, or derived from, chlorine; -- said of those compounds of chlorine in which this element has a valence of three, the next lower than in chloric compounds; as, chlorous acid, HClO2.,
C as in Chlorous (a.) Pertaining to, or resembling, the electro-negative character of chlorine; hence, electro-negative; -- opposed to basylous or zincous.,

C as in Chough (n.) A bird of the Crow family (Fregilus graculus) of Europe. It is of a black color, with a long, slender, curved bill and red legs; -- also called chauk, chauk-daw, chocard, Cornish chough, red-legged crow. The name is also applied to several allied birds, as the Alpine chough.,
C as in Chouicha (n.) The salmon of the Columbia River or California. See Quinnat.,
C as in Chouka (n.) The Indian four-horned antelope; the chikara.,
C as in Choule (n.) See Jowl.,
C as in Choultry (n.) See Choltry.,
C as in Choused (imp. & p. p.) of Chouse,
C as in Chousing (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Chouse,
C as in Chouse (v. t.) To cheat, trick, defraud; -- followed by of, or out of; as, to chouse one out of his money.,
C as in Chouse (n.) One who is easily cheated; a tool; a simpleton; a gull.,
C as in Chouse (n.) A trick; sham; imposition.,
C as in Chouse (n.) A swindler.,
C as in Chout (n.) An assessment equal to a fourth part of the revenue.,
C as in Chowchow (a.) Consisting of several kinds mingled together; mixed; as, chowchow sweetmeats (preserved fruits put together).,
C as in Chowchow (n.) A kind of mixed pickles.,
C as in Chowder (n.) A dish made of fresh fish or clams, biscuit, onions, etc., stewed together.,
C as in Chowder (n.) A seller of fish.,
C as in Chowder (v. t.) To make a chowder of.,
C as in Chowry (n.) A whisk to keep off files, used in the East Indies.,
C as in Chowter (v. t.) To grumble or mutter like a froward child.,
C as in Choy root () See Chay root.,
C as in Chrematistics (n.) The science of wealth; the science, or a branch of the science, of political economy.,
C as in Chreotechnics (n.) The science of the useful arts, esp. agriculture, manufactures, and commerce.,
C as in Chrestomathic (a.) Teaching what is useful.,
C as in Chrestomathy (n.) A selection of passages, with notes, etc., to be used in acquiring a language; as, a Hebrew chrestomathy.,
C as in Chrism (n.) Olive oil mixed with balm and spices, consecrated by the bishop on Maundy Thursday, and used in the administration of baptism, confirmation, ordination, etc.,
C as in Chrism (n.) The same as Chrisom.,
C as in Chrismal (a.) Of or pertaining to or used in chrism.,
C as in Chrismation (n.) The act of applying the chrism, or consecrated oil.,
C as in Chrismatory (n.) A cruet or vessel in which chrism is kept.,
C as in Chrisom (n.) A white cloth, anointed with chrism, or a white mantle thrown over a child when baptized or christened.,
C as in Chrisom (n.) A child which died within a month after its baptism; -- so called from the chrisom cloth which was used as a shroud for it.,
C as in Christ (n.) The Anointed; an appellation given to Jesus, the Savior. It is synonymous with the Hebrew Messiah.,
C as in Christcross (n.) The mark of the cross, as cut, painted, written, or stamped on certain objects, -- sometimes as the sign of 12 o'clock on a dial.,
C as in Christcross (n.) The beginning and the ending.,
C as in Christcross-row () The alphabet; -- formerly so called, either from the cross usually set before it, or from a superstitious custom, sometimes practiced, of writing it in the form of a cross, by way of a charm.,
C as in Christened (imp. & p. p.) of Christen,
C as in Christening (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Christen,
C as in Christen (v. t.) To baptize and give a Christian name to.,
C as in Christen (v. t.) To give a name; to denominate.,
C as in Christen (v. t.) To Christianize.,
C as in Christen (v. t.) To use for the first time.,
C as in Christendom (n.) The profession of faith in Christ by baptism; hence, the Christian religion, or the adoption of it.,
C as in Christendom (n.) The name received at baptism; or, more generally, any name or appelation.,
C as in Christendom (n.) That portion of the world in which Christianity prevails, or which is governed under Christian institutions, in distinction from heathen or Mohammedan lands.,
C as in Christendom (n.) The whole body of Christians.,
C as in Christian (n.) One who believes, or professes or is assumed to believe, in Jesus Christ, and the truth as taught by Him; especially, one whose inward and outward life is conformed to the doctrines of Christ.,
C as in Christian (n.) One born in a Christian country or of Christian parents, and who has not definitely becomes an adherent of an opposing system.,
C as in Christian (n.) One of a Christian denomination which rejects human creeds as bases of fellowship, and sectarian names. They are congregational in church government, and baptize by immersion. They are also called Disciples of Christ, and Campbellites.,
C as in Christian (n.) One of a sect (called Christian Connection) of open-communion immersionists. The Bible is their only authoritative rule of faith and practice.,
C as in Christian (a.) Pertaining to Christ or his religion; as, Christian people.,
C as in Christian (a.) Pertaining to the church; ecclesiastical; as, a Christian court.,
C as in Christian (a.) Characteristic of Christian people; civilized; kind; kindly; gentle; beneficent.,
C as in Christianism (n.) The Christian religion.,
C as in Christianism (n.) The Christian world; Christendom.,
C as in Christianite (n.) Same as Anorthite.,
C as in Christianite (n.) See Phillipsite.,
C as in Christianity (n.) The religion of Christians; the system of doctrines and precepts taught by Christ.,
C as in Christianity (n.) Practical conformity of one's inward and outward life to the spirit of the Christian religion,
C as in Christianity (n.) The body of Christian believers.,
C as in Christianization (n.) The act or process of converting or being converted to a true Christianity.,
C as in Christianized (imp. & p. p.) of Christianize,

C as in Christianly (adv.) In a manner becoming the principles of the Christian religion.,
C as in Christianly (a.) Christianlike.,
C as in Christianness (n.) Consonance with the doctrines of Christianity.,
C as in Christless (a.) Without faith in Christ; unchristian.,
C as in Christlike (a.) Resembling Christ in character, actions, etc.,
C as in Christly (a.) Christlike.,
C as in Christmas (n.) An annual church festival (December 25) and in some States a legal holiday, in memory of the birth of Christ, often celebrated by a particular church service, and also by special gifts, greetings, and hospitality.,
C as in Christmastide (n.) The season of Christmas.,
C as in Christocentric (a.) Making Christ the center, about whom all things are grouped, as in religion or history; tending toward Christ, as the central object of thought or emotion.,
C as in Christology (n.) A treatise on Christ; that department of theology which treats of the personality, attributes, or life of Christ.,
C as in Christom (n.) See Chrisom.,
C as in Christophany (n.) An appearance of Christ, as to his disciples after the crucifixion.,
C as in Christ's-thorn (n.) One of several prickly or thorny shrubs found in Palestine, especially the Paliurus aculeatus, Zizyphus Spina-Christi, and Z. vulgaris. The last bears the fruit called jujube, and may be considered to have been the most readily obtainable for the Crown of Thorns.,
C as in Chromascope (n.) An instrument for showing the optical effects of color.,
C as in Chromate (n.) A salt of chromic acid.,
C as in Chromatic (a.) Relating to color, or to colors.,
C as in Chromatic (a.) Proceeding by the smaller intervals (half steps or semitones) of the scale, instead of the regular intervals of the diatonic scale.,
C as in Chromatical (a.) Chromatic.,
C as in Chromatically (adv.) In a chromatic manner.,
C as in Chromatics (n.) The science of colors; that part of optics which treats of the properties of colors.,
C as in Chromatin (n.) Tissue which is capable of being stained by dyes.,
C as in Chromatism (n.) The state of being colored, as in the case of images formed by a lens.,
C as in Chromatism (n.) An abnormal coloring of plants.,
C as in Chromatogenous (a.) Producing color.,
C as in Chromatography (n.) A treatise on colors,
C as in Chromatology (n.) A treatise on colors.,
C as in Chromatophore (n.) A contractile cell or vesicle containing liquid pigment and capable of changing its form or size, thus causing changes of color in the translucent skin of such animals as possess them. They are highly developed and numerous in the cephalopods.,
C as in Chromatophore (n.) One of the granules of protoplasm, which in mass give color to the part of the plant containing them.,
C as in Chromatoscope (n.) A reflecting telescope, part of which is made to rotate eccentrically, so as to produce a ringlike image of a star, instead of a point; -- used in studying the scintillation of the stars.,
C as in Chromatosphere (n.) A chromosphere.,
C as in Chromatrope (n.) An instrument for exhibiting certain chromatic effects of light (depending upon the persistence of vision and mixture of colors) by means of rapidly rotating disks variously colored.,
C as in Chromatrope (n.) A device in a magic lantern or stereopticon to produce kaleidoscopic effects.,
C as in Chromatype (n.) A colored photographic picture taken upon paper made sensitive with potassium bichromate or some other salt of chromium.,
C as in Chromatype (n.) The process by which such picture is made.,
C as in Chrome (n.) Same as Chromium.,
C as in Chromic (a.) Pertaining to, or obtained from, chromium; -- said of the compounds of chromium in which it has its higher valence.,
C as in Chromid (n.) One of the Chromidae, a family of fresh-water fishes abundant in the tropical parts of America and Africa. Some are valuable food fishes, as the bulti of the Nile.,
C as in Chromidrosis (n.) Secretion of abnormally colored perspiration.,
C as in Chromism (n.) Same as Chromatism.,
C as in Chromite (n.) A black submetallic mineral consisting of oxide of chromium and iron; -- called also chromic iron.,
C as in Chromite (n.) A compound or salt of chromous hydroxide regarded as an acid.,
C as in Chromium (n.) A comparatively rare element occurring most abundantly in the mineral chromite. Atomic weight 52.5. Symbol Cr. When isolated it is a hard, brittle, grayish white metal, fusible with difficulty. Its chief commercial importance is for its compounds, as potassium chromate, lead chromate, etc., which are brilliantly colored and are used dyeing and calico printing. Called also chrome.,
C as in Chromos (pl. ) of Chromo,
C as in Chromo (n.) A chromolithograph.,
C as in Chromoblast (n.) An embryonic cell which develops into a pigment cell.,
C as in Chromogen () Vegetable coloring matter other than green; chromule.,
C as in Chromogen () Any colored compound, supposed to contain one or more chromophores.,
C as in Chromogenic (a.) Containing, or capable of forming, chromogen; as, chromogenic bacteria.,
C as in Chromograph (n.) An apparatus by which a number of copies of written matter, maps, plans, etc., can be made; -- called also hectograph.,
C as in Chromoleucite (n.) A chromoplastid.,
C as in Chromolithograph (n.) A picture printed in tints and colors by repeated impressions from a series of stones prepared by the lithographic process.,
C as in Chromolithographer (n.) One who is engaged in chromolithography.,
C as in Chromolithographic (a.) Pertaining to, or made by, chromolithography.,
C as in Chromolithography (n.) Lithography adapted to printing in inks of various colors.,
C as in Chromophane (n.) A general name for the several coloring matters, red, green, yellow, etc., present in the inner segments in the cones of the retina, held in solution by fats, and slowly decolorized by light; distinct from the photochemical pigments of the rods of the retina.,
C as in Chromophore (n.) Any chemical group or residue (as NO2; N2; or O2) which imparts some decided color to the compound of which it is an ingredient.,
C as in Chromophotography (n.) The art of producing photographs in colors.,
C as in Chromophotolithograph (n.) A photolithograph printed in colors.,
C as in Chromoplastid (n.) A protoplasmic granule of some other color than green; -- also called chromoleucite.,
C as in Chromosome (n.) One of the minute bodies into which the chromatin of the nucleus is resolved during mitotic cell division; the idant of Weismann.,
C as in Chromosphere (n.) An atmosphere of rare matter, composed principally of incandescent hydrogen gas, surrounding the sun and enveloping the photosphere. Portions of the chromosphere are here and there thrown up into enormous tongues of flame.,
C as in Chromospheric (a.) Of or pertaining to the chromosphere.,
C as in Chromotype (n.) A sheet printed in colors by any process, as a chromolithograph. See Chromolithograph.,
C as in Chromotype (n.) A photographic picture in the natural colors.,
C as in Chromous (a.) Of, pertaining to, or derived from, chromium, when this element has a valence lower than that in chromic compounds.,
C as in Chromule (n.) A general name for coloring matter of plants other than chlorophyll, especially that of petals.,
C as in Chronic (a.) Relating to time; according to time.,
C as in Chronic (a.) Continuing for a long time; lingering; habitual.,
C as in Chronical (a.) Chronic.,
C as in Chronicle (n.) An historical register or account of facts or events disposed in the order of time.,
C as in Chronicle (n.) A narrative of events; a history; a record.,
C as in Chronicle (n.) The two canonical books of the Old Testament in which immediately follow 2 Kings.,
C as in Chronicled (imp. & p. p.) of Chronicle,
C as in Chronicling (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Chronicle,
C as in Chronicle (v. t.) To record in a history or chronicle; to record; to register.,
C as in Chronicler (n.) A writer of a chronicle; a recorder of events in the order of time; an historian.,
C as in Chronique (n.) A chronicle.,
C as in Chronogram (n.) An inscription in which certain numeral letters, made to appear specially conspicuous, on being added together, express a particular date or epoch, as in the motto of a medal struck by Gustavus Adolphus in 1632: ChrIstVs DVX; ergo trIVMphVs.- the capitals of which give, when added as numerals, the sum 1632.,
C as in Chronogram (n.) The record or inscription made by a chronograph.,
C as in Chronogrammatic (a.) Alt. of Chronogrammatical,
C as in Chronogrammatical (a.) Belonging to a chronogram, or containing one.,
C as in Chronogrammatist (n.) A writer of chronograms.,
C as in Chronograph (n.) An instrument for measuring or recording intervals of time, upon a revolving drum or strip of paper moved by clockwork. The action of the stylus or pen is controlled by electricity.,
C as in Chronograph (n.) Same as Chronogram, 1.,
C as in Chronograph (n.) A chronoscope.,
C as in Chronographer (n.) One who writes a chronography; a chronologer.,
C as in Chronographic (a.) Of or pertaining to a chronograph.,
C as in Chronography (n.) A description or record of past time; history.,
C as in Chronologer (n.) Same as Chronologist.,
C as in Chronologic (a.) Alt. of Chronological,
C as in Chronological (a.) Relating to chronology; containing an account of events in the order of time; according to the order of time; as, chronological tables.,
C as in Chronologist (n.) Alt. of Chronologer,
C as in Chronologer (n.) A person who investigates dates of events and transactions; one skilled in chronology.,
C as in Chronologies (pl. ) of Chronology,
C as in Chronology (n.) The science which treats of measuring time by regular divisions or periods, and which assigns to events or transactions their proper dates.,
C as in Chronometer (n.) An instrument for measuring time; a timekeeper.,
C as in Chronometer (n.) A portable timekeeper, with a heavy compensation balance, and usually beating half seconds; -- intended to keep time with great accuracy for use an astronomical observations, in determining longitude, etc.,
C as in Chronometer (n.) A metronome.,
C as in Chronometric (a.) Alt. of Chronometrical,
C as in Chronometrical (a.) Pertaining to a chronometer; measured by a chronometer.,

C as in Chronopher (n.) An instrument signaling the correct time to distant points by electricity.,
C as in Chronoscope (n.) An instrument for measuring minute intervals of time; used in determining the velocity of projectiles, the duration of short-lived luminous phenomena, etc.,

C as in Chrysalis (n.) The pupa state of certain insects, esp. of butterflies, from which the perfect insect emerges. See Pupa, and Aurelia (a).,
C as in Chrysaniline (n.) A yellow substance obtained as a by-product in the manufacture of rosaniline. It dyes silk a fine golden-yellow color.,
C as in Chrysanthemum (n.) A genus of composite plants, mostly perennial, and of many species including the many varieties of garden chrysanthemums (annual and perennial), and also the feverfew and the oxeye daisy.,
C as in Chrysarobin (n.) A bitter, yellow substance forming the essential constituent of Goa powder, and yielding chrysophanic acid proper; hence formerly called also chrysphanic acid.,
C as in Chrysaurin (n.) An orange-colored dyestuff, of artificial production.,
C as in Chryselephantine (a.) Composed of, or adorned with, gold and ivory.,
C as in Chrysene (n.) One of the higher aromatic hydrocarbons of coal tar, allied to naphthalene and anthracene. It is a white crystalline substance, C18H12, of strong blue fluorescence, but generally colored yellow by impurities.,
C as in Chrysoberyl (n.) A mineral, found in crystals, of a yellow to green or brown color, and consisting of aluminia and glucina. It is very hard, and is often used as a gem.,
C as in Chrysochlore (n.) A South African mole of the genus Chrysochloris; the golden mole, the fur of which reflects brilliant metallic hues of green and gold.,
C as in Chrysocolla (n.) A hydrous silicate of copper, occurring massive, of a blue or greenish blue color.,
C as in Chrysogen (n.) A yellow crystalline substance extracted from crude anthracene.,
C as in Chrysography (n.) The art of writing in letters of gold.,
C as in Chrysography (n.) A writing executed in letters of gold.,
C as in Chrysoidine (n.) An artificial, yellow, crystalline dye, C6H5N2.C6H3(NH2)2. Also, one of a group of dyestuffs resembling chrysoidine proper.,
C as in Chrysolite (n.) A mineral, composed of silica, magnesia, and iron, of a yellow to green color. It is common in certain volcanic rocks; -- called also olivine and peridot. Sometimes used as a gem. The name was also early used for yellow varieties of tourmaline and topaz.,
C as in Chrysology (n.) That branch of political economy which relates to the production of wealth.,
C as in Chrysopa (n.) A genus of neuropterous insects. See Lacewing.,
C as in Chrysophane (n.) A glucoside extracted from rhubarb as a bitter, yellow, crystalline powder, and yielding chrysophanic acid on decomposition.,
C as in Chrysophanic (a.) Pertaining to, or derived from, or resembling, chrysophane.,
C as in Chrysoprase (n.) An apple-green variety of chalcedony, colored by nickel. It has a dull flinty luster, and is sometimes used in jewelry.,
C as in Chrysoprasus (n.) See Chrysoprase.,
C as in Chrysosperm (n.) The seed of gold; a means of creating gold.,
C as in Chrysotype (n.) A photographic picture taken upon paper prepared by the use of a sensitive salt of iron and developed by the application of chloride of gold.,
C as in Chrysotype (n.) 2process, invented by Sir J.Herschel.,

C as in Chthonophagy (n.) A disease characterized by an irresistible desire to eat earth, observed in some parts of the southern United States, the West Indies, etc.,
C as in Chub (n.) A species to fresh-water fish of the Cyprinidae or Carp family. The common European species is Leuciscus cephalus; the cheven. In America the name is applied to various fishes of the same family, of the genera Semotilus, Squalius, Ceratichthys, etc., and locally to several very different fishes, as the tautog, black bass, etc.,
