C as in Churn (v. t.) To shake or agitate with violence.,
C as in Churn (v. i.) To perform the operation of churning.,
C as in Churning (n.) The act of one who churns.,
C as in Churning (n.) The quantity of butter made at one operation.,
C as in Churrus (n.) A powerfully narcotic and intoxicating gum resin which exudes from the flower heads, seeds, etc., of Indian hemp.,
C as in Churrworm (n.) An insect that turns about nimbly; the mole cricket; -- called also fan cricket.,
C as in Chuse (v. t.) See Choose.,
C as in Chute (n.) A framework, trough, or tube, upon or through which objects are made to slide from a higher to a lower level, or through which water passes to a wheel.,
C as in Chute (n.) See Shoot.,
C as in Chutney (n.) Alt. of Chutnee,
C as in Chutnee (n.) A warm or spicy condiment or pickle made in India, compounded of various vegetable substances, sweets, acids, etc.,
C as in Chylaceous (a.) Possessed of the properties of chyle; consisting of chyle.,
C as in Chylaqueous (a.) Consisting of chyle much diluted with water; -- said of a liquid which forms the circulating fluid of some inferior animals.,
C as in Chyle (n.) A milky fluid containing the fatty matter of the food in a state of emulsion, or fine mechanical division; formed from chyme by the action of the intestinal juices. It is absorbed by the lacteals, and conveyed into the blood by the thoracic duct.,
C as in Chylifaction (n.) The act or process by which chyle is formed from food in animal bodies; chylification, -- a digestive process.,
C as in Chylifactive (a.) Producing, or converting into, chyle; having the power to form chyle.,
C as in Chyliferous (a.) Transmitting or conveying chyle; as, chyliferous vessels.,
C as in Chylific (a.) Chylifactive.,
C as in Chylification (n.) The formation of chyle. See Chylifaction.,
C as in Chylificatory (a.) Chylifactive.,
C as in Chylify (v. t. & i.) To make chyle of; to be converted into chyle.,
C as in Chylopoetic (a.) Concerned in the formation of chyle; as, the chylopoetic organs.,
C as in Chylous (a.) Consisting of, or similar to, chyle.,
C as in Chyluria (n.) A morbid condition in which the urine contains chyle or fatty matter, giving it a milky appearance.,
C as in Chyme (n.) The pulpy mass of semi-digested food in the small intestines just after its passage from the stomach. It is separated in the intestines into chyle and excrement. See Chyle.,
C as in Chymic () Alt. of Chymistry,
C as in Chymist () Alt. of Chymistry,
C as in Chymistry () See Chemic, Chemist, Chemistry.,
C as in Chymiferous (a.) Bearing or containing chyme.,
C as in Chymification (n.) The conversion of food into chyme by the digestive action of gastric juice.,
C as in Chymify (v. t.) To form into chyme.,
C as in Chymous (a.) Of or pertaining to chyme.,
C as in Chyometer (n.) An instrument for measuring liquids. It consists of a piston moving in a tube in which is contained the liquid, the quantity expelled being indicated by the graduation upon the piston rod.,
C as in Cibarious (a.) Pertaining to food; edible.,
C as in Cibation (n.) The act of taking food.,
C as in Cibation (n.) The process or operation of feeding the contents of the crucible with fresh material.,
C as in Cibol (n.) A perennial alliaceous plant (Allium fistulosum), sometimes called Welsh onion. Its fistular leaves areused in cookery.,
C as in Ciboria (pl. ) of Ciborium,
C as in Ciborium (n.) A canopy usually standing free and supported on four columns, covering the high altar, or, very rarely, a secondary altar.,

C as in Cicadas (pl. ) of Cicada,
C as in Cicadae (pl. ) of Cicada,
C as in Cicada (n.) Any species of the genus Cicada. They are large hemipterous insects, with nearly transparent wings. The male makes a shrill sound by peculiar organs in the under side of the abdomen, consisting of a pair of stretched membranes, acted upon by powerful muscles. A noted American species (C. septendecim) is called the seventeen year locust. Another common species is the dogday cicada.,
C as in Cicala (n.) A cicada. See Cicada.,
C as in Cicatrice (n.) A cicatrix.,
C as in Cicatricial (a.) Relating to, or having the character of, a cicatrix.,
C as in Cicatricle (n.) The germinating point in the embryo of a seed; the point in the yolk of an egg at which development begins.,
C as in Cicatrisive (a.) Tending to promote the formation of a cicatrix; good for healing of a wound.,
C as in Cicatrices (pl. ) of Cicatrix,
C as in Cicatrix (n.) The pellicle which forms over a wound or breach of continuity and completes the process of healing in the latter, and which subsequently contracts and becomes white, forming the scar.,
C as in Cicatrizant (n.) A medicine or application that promotes the healing of a sore or wound, or the formation of a cicatrix.,
C as in Cicatrization (n.) The process of forming a cicatrix, or the state of being cicatrized.,
C as in Cicatrized (imp. & p. p.) of Cicatrize,
C as in Cicatrizing (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Cicatrize,

C as in Cid (n.) Chief or commander; in Spanish literature, a title of Ruy Diaz, Count of Bivar, a champion of Christianity and of the old Spanish royalty, in the 11th century.,
C as in Cid (n.) An epic poem, which celebrates the exploits of the Spanish national hero, Ruy Diaz.,
C as in Cider (n.) The expressed juice of apples. It is used as a beverage, for making vinegar, and for other purposes.,
C as in Ciderist (n.) A maker of cider.,

C as in Cilia (n. pl.) The eyelashes.,
C as in Cilia (n. pl.) Small, generally microscopic, vibrating appendages lining certain organs, as the air passages of the higher animals, and in the lower animals often covering also the whole or a part of the exterior. They are also found on some vegetable organisms. In the Infusoria, and many larval forms, they are locomotive organs.,
C as in Cilia (n. pl.) Hairlike processes, commonly marginal and forming a fringe like the eyelash.,
C as in Cilia (n. pl.) Small, vibratory, swimming organs, somewhat resembling true cilia, as those of Ctenophora.,
C as in Ciliary (a.) Pertaining to the cilia, or eyelashes. Also applied to special parts of the eye itself; as, the ciliary processes of the choroid coat; the ciliary muscle, etc.,
C as in Ciliary (a.) Pertaining to or connected with the cilia in animal or vegetable organisms; as, ciliary motion.,
C as in Ciliata (n. pl.) One of the orders of Infusoria, characterized by having cilia. In some species the cilia cover the body generally, in others they form a band around the mouth.,
C as in Ciliate (a.) Alt. of Ciliated,
C as in Ciliated (a.) Provided with, or surrounded by, cilia; as, a ciliate leaf; endowed with vibratory motion; as, the ciliated epithelium of the windpipe.,

C as in Cilician (n.) A native or inhabitant of Cilicia.,
C as in Cilicious (a.) Made, or consisting, of hair.,

C as in Ciliiform (a.) Having the form of cilia; very fine or slender.,

C as in Cinchona (n.) A genus of trees growing naturally on the Andes in Peru and adjacent countries, but now cultivated in the East Indies, producing a medicinal bark of great value.,
C as in Cinchona (n.) The bark of any species of Cinchona containing three per cent. or more of bitter febrifuge alkaloids; Peruvian bark; Jesuits' bark.,
C as in Cinchonaceous (a.) Allied or pertaining to cinchona, or to the plants that produce it.,
C as in Cinchonic (a.) Belonging to, or obtained from, cinchona.,
C as in Cinchonidine (n.) One of the quinine group of alkaloids, found especially in red cinchona bark. It is a white crystalline substance, C19H22N2O, with a bitter taste and qualities similar to, but weaker than, quinine; -- sometimes called also cinchonidia.,
C as in Cinchonine (n.) One of the quinine group of alkaloids isomeric with and resembling cinchonidine; -- called also cinchonia.,
C as in Cinchonism (n.) A condition produced by the excessive or long-continued use of quinine, and marked by deafness, roaring in the ears, vertigo, etc.,
C as in Cinchonize (v. t.) To produce cinchonism in; to poison with quinine or with cinchona.,
C as in Cincinnati epoch () An epoch at the close of the American lower Silurian system. The rocks are well developed near Cincinnati, Ohio. The group includes the Hudson River and Lorraine shales of New York.,

C as in Cipher (n.) A character [0] which, standing by itself, expresses nothing, but when placed at the right hand of a whole number, increases its value tenfold.,

C as in Cipher (a.) Of the nature of a cipher; of no weight or influence.,

C as in Circulation (n.) The act of passing from place to place or person to person; free diffusion; transmission.,
C as in Circulation (n.) Currency; circulating coin; notes, bills, etc., current for coin.,
C as in Circulation (n.) The extent to which anything circulates or is circulated; the measure of diffusion; as, the circulation of a newspaper.,
C as in Circulation (n.) The movement of the blood in the blood-vascular system, by which it is brought into close relations with almost every living elementary constituent. Also, the movement of the sap in the vessels and tissues of plants.,
C as in Circulative (a.) Promoting circulation; circulating.,
C as in Circulator (n.) One who, or that which, circulates.,
C as in Circulatorious (a.) Travelling from house to house or from town to town; itinerant.,
C as in Circulatory (a.) Circular; as, a circulatory letter.,
C as in Circulatory (a.) Circulating, or going round.,
C as in Circulatory (a.) Subserving the purposes of circulation; as, circulatory organs; of or pertaining to the organs of circulation; as, circulatory diseases.,
C as in Circulatory (n.) A chemical vessel consisting of two portions unequally exposed to the heat of the fire, and with connecting pipes or passages, through which the fluid rises from the overheated portion, and descends from the relatively colder, maintaining a circulation.,

C as in Circumferentor (n.) A surveying instrument, for taking horizontal angles and bearings; a surveyor's compass. It consists of a compass whose needle plays over a circle graduated to 360, and of a horizontal brass bar at the ends of which are standards with narrow slits for sighting, supported on a tripod by a ball and socket joint.,

C as in Circumflex (n.) A character, or accent, denoting in Greek a rise and of the voice on the same long syllable, marked thus [~ or /]; and in Latin and some other languages, denoting a long and contracted syllable, marked [/ or ^]. See Accent, n., 2.,

C as in Circuses (pl. ) of Circus,
C as in Circus (n.) A level oblong space surrounded on three sides by seats of wood, earth, or stone, rising in tiers one above another, and divided lengthwise through the middle by a barrier around which the track or course was laid out. It was used for chariot races, games, and public shows.,
C as in Circus (n.) A circular inclosure for the exhibition of feats of horsemanship, acrobatic displays, etc. Also, the company of performers, with their equipage.,

C as in Cirrhosis (n.) A disease of the liver in which it usually becomes smaller in size and more dense and fibrous in consistence; hence sometimes applied to similar changes in other organs, caused by increase in the fibrous framework and decrease in the proper substance of the organ.,

C as in Cirripedia (n. pl.) An order of Crustacea including the barnacles. When adult, they have a calcareous shell composed of several pieces. From the opening of the shell the animal throws out a group of curved legs, looking like a delicate curl, whence the name of the group. See Anatifa.,

C as in Cisalpine (a.) On the hither side of the Alps with reference to Rome, that is, on the south side of the Alps; -- opposed to transalpine.,
C as in Cisatlantic (a.) On this side of the Atlantic Ocean; -- used of the eastern or the western side, according to the standpoint of the writer.,
C as in Cisco (n.) The Lake herring (Coregonus Artedi), valuable food fish of the Great Lakes of North America. The name is also applied to C. Hoyi, a related species of Lake Michigan.,

C as in Cissoid (n.) A curve invented by Diocles, for the purpose of solving two celebrated problems of the higher geometry; viz., to trisect a plane angle, and to construct two geometrical means between two given straight lines.,
C as in Cist (n.) A box or chest. Specifically: (a) A bronze receptacle, round or oval, frequently decorated with engravings on the sides and cover, and with feet, handles, etc., of decorative castings. (b) A cinerary urn. See Illustration in Appendix.,

C as in Cistercian (n.) A monk of the prolific branch of the Benedictine Order, established in 1098 at Citeaux, in France, by Robert, abbot of Molesme. For two hundred years the Cistercians followed the rule of St. Benedict in all its rigor.,
C as in Cistercian (a.) Of or pertaining to the Cistercians.,

C as in City (n.) A large town.,
C as in City (n.) A corporate town; in the United States, a town or collective body of inhabitants, incorporated and governed by a mayor and aldermen or a city council consisting of a board of aldermen and a common council; in Great Britain, a town corporate, which is or has been the seat of a bishop, or the capital of his see.,
C as in City (n.) The collective body of citizens, or inhabitants of a city.,

C as in Cive (n.) Same as Chive.,
C as in Civet (n.) A substance, of the consistence of butter or honey, taken from glands in the anal pouch of the civet (Viverra civetta). It is of clear yellowish or brownish color, of a strong, musky odor, offensive when undiluted, but agreeable when a small portion is mixed with another substance. It is used as a perfume.,
C as in Civet (n.) The animal that produces civet (Viverra civetta); -- called also civet cat. It is carnivorous, from two to three feet long, and of a brownish gray color, with transverse black bands and spots on the body and tail. It is a native of northern Africa and of Asia. The name is also applied to other species.,
C as in Civet (v. t.) To scent or perfume with civet.,

C as in Clam (v. t.) A bivalve mollusk of many kinds, especially those that are edible; as, the long clam (Mya arenaria), the quahog or round clam (Venus mercenaria), the sea clam or hen clam (Spisula solidissima), and other species of the United States. The name is said to have been given originally to the Tridacna gigas, a huge East Indian bivalve.,

C as in Clavicle (n.) The collar bone, which is joined at one end to the scapula, or shoulder blade, and at the other to the sternum, or breastbone. In man each clavicle is shaped like the letter /, and is situated just above the first rib on either side of the neck. In birds the two clavicles are united ventrally, forming the merrythought, or wishbone.,

C as in Clay (n.) A soft earth, which is plastic, or may be molded with the hands, consisting of hydrous silicate of aluminium. It is the result of the wearing down and decomposition, in part, of rocks containing aluminous minerals, as granite. Lime, magnesia, oxide of iron, and other ingredients, are often present as impurities.,

C as in Click (n.) A kind of articulation used by the natives of Southern Africa, consisting in a sudden withdrawal of the end or some other portion of the tongue from a part of the mouth with which it is in contact, whereby a sharp, clicking sound is produced. The sounds are four in number, and are called cerebral, palatal, dental, and lateral clicks or clucks, the latter being the noise ordinarily used in urging a horse forward.,

C as in Clinometric (a.) Pertaining to the oblique crystalline forms, or to solids which have oblique angles between the axes; as, the clinometric systems.,

C as in Clione (n.) A genus of naked pteropods. One species (Clione papilonacea), abundant in the Arctic Ocean, constitutes a part of the food of the Greenland whale. It is sometimes incorrectly called Clio.,

C as in Clock (n.) A machine for measuring time, indicating the hour and other divisions by means of hands moving on a dial plate. Its works are moved by a weight or a spring, and it is often so constructed as to tell the hour by the stroke of a hammer on a bell. It is not adapted, like the watch, to be carried on the person.,

C as in Clumps (n.) A game in which questions are asked for the purpose of enabling the questioners to discover a word or thing previously selected by two persons who answer the questions; -- so called because the players take sides in two "clumps" or groups, the "clump" which guesses the word winning the game.,

C as in Coagulate (v. i.) To undergo coagulation.,
C as in Coagulated (a.) Changed into, or contained in, a coagulum or a curdlike mass; curdled.,
C as in Coagulation (n.) The change from a liquid to a thickened, curdlike, insoluble state, not by evaporation, but by some kind of chemical reaction; as, the spontaneous coagulation of freshly drawn blood; the coagulation of milk by rennet, or acid, and the coagulation of egg albumin by heat. Coagulation is generally the change of an albuminous body into an insoluble modification.,
C as in Coagulation (n.) The substance or body formed by coagulation.,
C as in Coagulative (a.) Having the power to cause coagulation; as, a coagulative agent.,
C as in Coagulator (n.) That which causes coagulation.,
C as in Coagulatory (a.) Serving to coagulate; produced by coagulation; as, coagulatory effects.,

C as in Cocaine (n.) A powerful alkaloid, C17H21NO4, obtained from the leaves of coca. It is a bitter, white, crystalline substance, and is remarkable for producing local insensibility to pain.,

C as in Coccinella (n.) A genus of small beetles of many species. They and their larvae feed on aphids or plant lice, and hence are of great benefit to man. Also called ladybirds and ladybugs.,

C as in Cockatoo (n.) A bird of the Parrot family, of the subfamily Cacatuinae, having a short, strong, and much curved beak, and the head ornamented with a crest, which can be raised or depressed at will. There are several genera and many species; as the broad-crested (Plictolophus, / Cacatua, cristatus), the sulphur-crested (P. galeritus), etc. The palm or great black cockatoo of Australia is Microglossus aterrimus.,
C as in Cockatrice (n.) A fabulous serpent whose breath and look were said to be fatal. See Basilisk.,
C as in Cockatrice (n.) A representation of this serpent. It has the head, wings, and legs of a bird, and tail of a serpent.,

C as in Cocoa () Alt. of Cocoa palm,
C as in Cocoa palm () A palm tree producing the cocoanut (Cocos nucifera). It grows in nearly all tropical countries, attaining a height of sixty or eighty feet. The trunk is without branches, and has a tuft of leaves at the top, each being fifteen or twenty feet in length, and at the base of these the nuts hang in clusters; the cocoanut tree.,
C as in Cocoa (n.) A preparation made from the seeds of the chocolate tree, and used in making, a beverage; also the beverage made from cocoa or cocoa shells.,
C as in Cocoanut (n.) The large, hard-shelled nut of the cocoa palm. It yields an agreeable milky liquid and a white meat or albumen much used as food and in making oil.,
C as in Cocobolo (n.) Alt. of Cocobolas,
C as in Cocobolas (n.) A very beautiful and hard wood, obtained in the West India Islands. It is used in cabinetmaking, for the handles of tools, and for various fancy articles.,
C as in Cocoon (n.) An oblong case in which the silkworm lies in its chrysalis state. It is formed of threads of silk spun by the worm just before leaving the larval state. From these the silk of commerce is prepared.,

C as in Cocoon (n.) The case of silk made by spiders to protect their eggs.,

C as in Coelenterata (n. pl.) A comprehensive group of Invertebrata, mostly marine, comprising the Anthozoa, Hydrozoa, and Ctenophora. The name implies that the stomach and body cavities are one. The group is sometimes enlarged so as to include the sponges.,

C as in Coerced (imp. & p. p.) of Coerce,
C as in Coercing (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Coerce,
C as in Coerce (v. t.) To restrain by force, especially by law or authority; to repress; to curb.,
C as in Coerce (v. t.) To compel or constrain to any action; as, to coerce a man to vote for a certain candidate.,
C as in Coerce (v. t.) To compel or enforce; as, to coerce obedience.,
C as in Coercible (a.) Capable of being coerced.,
C as in Coercion (n.) The act or process of coercing.,
C as in Coercion (n.) The application to another of either physical or moral force. When the force is physical, and cannot be resisted, then the act produced by it is a nullity, so far as concerns the party coerced. When the force is moral, then the act, though voidable, is imputable to the party doing it, unless he be so paralyzed by terror as to act convulsively. At the same time coercion is not negatived by the fact of submission under force. "Coactus volui" (I consented under compulsion) is the condition of mind which, when there is volition forced by coercion, annuls the result of such coercion.,
C as in Coercitive (a.) Coercive.,
C as in Coercive (a.) Serving or intended to coerce; having power to constrain.,
C as in Coerulignone (n.) A bluish violet, crystalline substance obtained in the purification of crude wood vinegar. It is regarded as a complex quinone derivative of diphenyl; -- called also cedriret.,

C as in Coessentiality (n.) Participation of the same essence.,

C as in Coleopter (n.) One of the Coleoptera.,
C as in Coleoptera (n. pl.) An order of insects having the anterior pair of wings (elytra) hard and horny, and serving as coverings for the posterior pair, which are membranous, and folded transversely under the others when not in use. The mouth parts form two pairs of jaws (mandibles and maxillae) adapted for chewing. Most of the Coleoptera are known as beetles and weevils.,
C as in Coleopteral (a.) Alt. of Coleopterous,
C as in Coleopterous (a.) Having wings covered with a case or sheath; belonging to the Coleoptera.,

C as in Collar (n.) A colored ring round the neck of a bird or mammal.,
C as in Collar (n.) A ring or round flange upon, surrounding, or against an object, and used for restraining motion within given limits, or for holding something to its place, or for hiding an opening around an object; as, a collar on a shaft, used to prevent endwise motion of the shaft; a collar surrounding a stovepipe at the place where it enters a wall. The flanges of a piston and the gland of a stuffing box are sometimes called collars.,
C as in Collar (n.) An eye formed in the bight or bend of a shroud or stay to go over the masthead; also, a rope to which certain parts of rigging, as dead-eyes, are secured.,
C as in Collar (n.) A curb, or a horizontal timbering, around the mouth of a shaft.,
C as in Collared (imp. & p. p.) of Collar,
C as in Collaring (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Collar,
C as in Collar (v. t.) To seize by the collar.,
C as in Collar (v. t.) To put a collar on.,
C as in Collar bone () The clavicle.,
C as in Collards (n. pl.) Young cabbage, used as "greens"; esp. a kind cultivated for that purpose; colewort.,
C as in Collared (a.) Wearing a collar.,
C as in Collared (a.) Wearing a collar; -- said of a man or beast used as a bearing when a collar is represented as worn around the neck or loins.,
C as in Collared (a.) Rolled up and bound close with a string; as, collared beef. See To collar beef, under Collar, v. t.,

C as in Colorado beetle () A yellowish beetle (Doryphora decemlineata), with ten longitudinal, black, dorsal stripes. It has migrated eastwards from its original habitat in Colorado, and is very destructive to the potato plant; -- called also potato beetle and potato bug. See Potato beetle.,
C as in Colorado group () A subdivision of the cretaceous formation of western North America, especially developed in Colorado and the upper Missouri region.,

C as in Colt (n.) A young, foolish fellow.,

C as in Coluber (n.) A genus of harmless serpents.,
C as in Colubrine (a.) like or related to snakes of the genus Coluber.,
C as in Colubrine (a.) Like a snake; cunning; crafty.,
C as in Colugo (n.) A peculiar East Indian mammal (Galleopithecus volans), having along the sides, connecting the fore and hind limbs, a parachutelike membrane, by means of which it is able to make long leaps, like the flying squirrel; -- called also flying lemur.,
C as in Columba (n.) See Calumba.,
C as in Columbae (n. pl.) An order of birds, including the pigeons.,

C as in Columbary (n.) A dovecote; a pigeon house.,
C as in Columbate (n.) A salt of columbic acid; a niobate. See Columbium.,
C as in Columbatz fly () See Buffalo fly, under Buffalo.,
C as in Columbella (n.) A genus of univalve shells, abundant in tropical seas. Some species, as Columbella mercatoria, were formerly used as shell money.,
C as in Columbia (n.) America; the United States; -- a poetical appellation given in honor of Columbus, the discoverer.,
C as in Columbiad (n.) A form of seacoast cannon; a long, chambered gun designed for throwing shot or shells with heavy charges of powder, at high angles of elevation.,
C as in Columbian (a.) Of or pertaining to the United States, or to America.,
C as in Columbic (a.) Pertaining to, or containing, columbium or niobium; niobic.,
C as in Columbic (a.) Pertaining to, or derived from, the columbo root.,
C as in Columbier (n.) See Colombier.,
C as in Columbiferous (a.) Producing or containing columbium.,
C as in Columbin (n.) A white, crystalline, bitter substance. See Calumbin.,
C as in Columbine (a.) Of or pertaining to a dove; dovelike; dove-colored.,
C as in Columbine (n.) A plant of several species of the genus Aquilegia; as, A. vulgaris, or the common garden columbine; A. Canadensis, the wild red columbine of North America.,
C as in Columbine (n.) The mistress or sweetheart of Harlequin in pantomimes.,
C as in Columbite (n.) A mineral of a black color, submetallic luster, and high specific specific gravity. It is a niobate (or columbate) of iron and manganese, containing tantalate of iron; -- first found in New England.,
C as in Columbium (n.) A rare element of the vanadium group, first found in a variety of the mineral columbite occurring in Connecticut, probably at Haddam. Atomic weight 94.2. Symbol Cb or Nb. Now more commonly called niobium.,
C as in Columbo (n.) See Calumba.,
C as in Columella (n.) An axis to which a carpel of a compound pistil may be attached, as in the case of the geranium; or which is left when a pod opens.,
C as in Columella (n.) A columnlike axis in the capsules of mosses.,
C as in Columella (n.) A term applied to various columnlike parts; as, the columella, or epipterygoid bone, in the skull of many lizards; the columella of the ear, the bony or cartilaginous rod connecting the tympanic membrane with the internal ear.,
C as in Columella (n.) The upright pillar in the axis of most univalve shells.,
C as in Columella (n.) The central pillar or axis of the calicles of certain corals.,
C as in Columelliform (a.) Shaped like a little column, or columella.,
C as in Column (n.) A kind of pillar; a cylindrical or polygonal support for a roof, ceiling, statue, etc., somewhat ornamented, and usually composed of base, shaft, and capital. See Order.,
C as in Column (n.) Anything resembling, in form or position, a column in architecture; an upright body or mass; a shaft or obelisk; as, a column of air, of water, of mercury, etc.; the Column Vendome; the spinal column.,
C as in Column (n.) A body of troops formed in ranks, one behind the other; -- contradistinguished from line. Compare Ploy, and Deploy.,
C as in Column (n.) A small army.,
C as in Column (n.) A number of ships so arranged as to follow one another in single or double file or in squadrons; -- in distinction from "line", where they are side by side.,
C as in Column (n.) A perpendicular set of lines, not extending across the page, and separated from other matter by a rule or blank space; as, a column in a newspaper.,
C as in Column (n.) A perpendicular line of figures.,

C as in Columnarity (n.) The state or quality of being columnar.,
C as in Columnated (a.) Having columns; as, columnated temples.,
C as in Columned (a.) Having columns.,
C as in Columniation (n.) The employment or arrangement of columns in a structure.,
C as in Colures (pl. ) of Colure,
C as in Colure (n.) One of two great circles intersecting at right angles in the poles of the equator. One of them passes through the equinoctial points, and hence is denominated the equinoctial colure; the other intersects the equator at the distance of 90 from the former, and is called the solstitial colure.,
C as in Colies (pl. ) of Coly,
C as in Coly (n.) Any bird of the genus Colius and allied genera. They inhabit Africa.,
C as in Colza (n.) A variety of cabbage (Brassica oleracea), cultivated for its seeds, which yield an oil valued for illuminating and lubricating purposes; summer rape.,
C as in Com- () A prefix from the Latin preposition cum, signifying with, together, in conjunction, very, etc. It is used in the form com- before b, m, p, and sometimes f, and by assimilation becomes col- before l, cor- before r, and con- before any consonant except b, h, l, m, p, r, and w. Before a vowel com- becomes co-; also before h, w, and sometimes before other consonants.,
C as in Coma (n.) A state of profound insensibility from which it is difficult or impossible to rouse a person. See Carus.,
C as in Coma (n.) The envelope of a comet; a nebulous covering, which surrounds the nucleus or body of a comet.,
C as in Coma (n.) A tuft or bunch, -- as the assemblage of branches forming the head of a tree; or a cluster of bracts when empty and terminating the inflorescence of a plant; or a tuft of long hairs on certain seeds.,
C as in Comanches (n. pl.) A warlike, savage, and nomadic tribe of the Shoshone family of Indians, inhabiting Mexico and the adjacent parts of the United States; -- called also Paducahs. They are noted for plundering and cruelty.,
C as in Comart (n.) A covenant.,
C as in Comate (a.) Encompassed with a coma, or bushy appearance, like hair; hairy.,
C as in Co-mate (n.) A companion.,
C as in Comatose (a.) Relating to, or resembling, coma; drowsy; lethargic; as, comatose sleep; comatose fever.,
C as in Comatous (a.) Comatose.,
C as in Comatula (n.) A crinoid of the genus Antedon and related genera. When young they are fixed by a stem. When adult they become detached and cling to seaweeds, etc., by their dorsal cirri; -- called also feather stars.,
C as in Comatulid (n.) Any crinoid of the genus Antedon or allied genera.,

C as in Comet (n.) A member of the solar system which usually moves in an elongated orbit, approaching very near to the sun in its perihelion, and receding to a very great distance from it at its aphelion. A comet commonly consists of three parts: the nucleus, the envelope, or coma, and the tail; but one or more of these parts is frequently wanting. See Illustration in Appendix.,
C as in Cometarium (n.) An instrument, intended to represent the revolution of a comet round the sun.,
C as in Cometary (a.) Pertaining to, or resembling, a comet.,

C as in Commendam (n.) A vacant living or benefice commended to a cleric (usually a bishop) who enjoyed the revenue until a pastor was provided. A living so held was said to be held in commendam. The practice was abolished by law in 1836.,

A French theory of government which holds that commune should be a kind of independent state, and the national government a confederation of such states, having only limited powers. It is advocated by advanced French republicans; but it should not be confounded with communism.,

C as in Commute (v. t.) To exchange; to put or substitute something else in place of, as a smaller penalty, obligation, or payment, for a greater, or a single thing for an aggregate; hence, to lessen; to diminish; as, to commute a sentence of death to one of imprisonment for life; to commute tithes; to commute charges for fares.,

C as in Comparative (a.) Of or pertaining to comparison.,
C as in Comparative (a.) Proceeding from, or by the method of, comparison; as, the comparative sciences; the comparative anatomy.,
C as in Comparative (a.) Estimated by comparison; relative; not positive or absolute, as compared with another thing or state.,
C as in Comparative (a.) Expressing a degree greater or less than the positive degree of the quality denoted by an adjective or adverb. The comparative degree is formed from the positive by the use of -er, more, or less; as, brighter, more bright, or less bright.,
C as in Comparative (n.) The comparative degree of adjectives and adverbs; also, the form by which the comparative degree is expressed; as, stronger, wiser, weaker, more stormy, less windy, are all comparatives.,
C as in Comparative (n.) An equal; a rival; a compeer.,
C as in Comparative (n.) One who makes comparisons; one who affects wit.,
C as in Comparatively (adv.) According to estimate made by comparison; relatively; not positively or absolutely.,
C as in Comparator (n.) An instrument or machine for comparing anything to be measured with a standard measure; -- applied especially to a machine for comparing standards of length.,
C as in Compared (imp. & p. p.) of Compare,
C as in Comparing (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Compare,
C as in Compare (v. t.) To examine the character or qualities of, as of two or more persons or things, for the purpose of discovering their resemblances or differences; to bring into comparison; to regard with discriminating attention.,
C as in Compare (v. t.) To represent as similar, for the purpose of illustration; to liken.,
C as in Compare (v. t.) To inflect according to the degrees of comparison; to state positive, comparative, and superlative forms of; as, most adjectives of one syllable are compared by affixing "- er" and "-est" to the positive form; as, black, blacker, blackest; those of more than one syllable are usually compared by prefixing "more" and "most", or "less" and "least", to the positive; as, beautiful, more beautiful, most beautiful.,
C as in Compare (v. i.) To be like or equal; to admit, or be worthy of, comparison; as, his later work does not compare with his earlier.,
C as in Compare (v. i.) To vie; to assume a likeness or equality.,
C as in Compare (n.) Comparison.,
C as in Compare (n.) Illustration by comparison; simile.,
C as in Compare (v. t.) To get; to procure; to obtain; to acquire,
C as in Comparer (n.) One who compares.,
C as in Comparison (n.) The act of comparing; an examination of two or more objects with the view of discovering the resemblances or differences; relative estimate.,
C as in Comparison (n.) The state of being compared; a relative estimate; also, a state, quality, or relation, admitting of being compared; as, to bring a thing into comparison with another; there is no comparison between them.,
C as in Comparison (n.) That to which, or with which, a thing is compared, as being equal or like; illustration; similitude.,
C as in Comparison (n.) The modification, by inflection or otherwise, which the adjective and adverb undergo to denote degrees of quality or quantity; as, little, less, least, are examples of comparison.,
C as in Comparison (n.) A figure by which one person or thing is compared to another, or the two are considered with regard to some property or quality, which is common to them both; e.g., the lake sparkled like a jewel.,

C as in Concertina (n.) A small musical instrument on the principle of the accordion. It is a small elastic box, or bellows, having free reeds on the inside, and keys and handles on the outside of each of the two hexagonal heads.,
C as in Concertino (n.) A piece for one or more solo instruments with orchestra; -- more concise than the concerto.,
C as in Concertion (n.) Act of concerting; adjustment.,
C as in Concertmeister (n.) The head violinist or leader of the strings in an orchestra; the sub-leader of the orchestra; concert master.,
C as in Concertos (pl. ) of Concerto,
C as in Concerto (n.) A composition (usually in symphonic form with three movements) in which one instrument (or two or three) stands out in bold relief against the orchestra, or accompaniment, so as to display its qualities or the performer's skill.,
C as in Concession (n.) The act of conceding or yielding; usually implying a demand, claim, or request, and thus distinguished from giving, which is voluntary or spontaneous.,
C as in Concession (n.) A thing yielded; an acknowledgment or admission; a boon; a grant; esp. a grant by government of a privilege or right to do something; as, a concession to build a canal.,

C as in Conch (n.) A name applied to various marine univalve shells; esp. to those of the genus Strombus, which are of large size. S. gigas is the large pink West Indian conch. The large king, queen, and cameo conchs are of the genus Cassis. See Cameo.,
C as in Conch (n.) In works of art, the shell used by Tritons as a trumpet.,
C as in Conch (n.) One of the white natives of the Bahama Islands or one of their descendants in the Florida Keys; -- so called from the commonness of the conch there, or because they use it for food.,
C as in Conch (n.) See Concha, n.,
C as in Conch (n.) The external ear. See Concha, n., 2.,
C as in Concha (n.) The plain semidome of an apse; sometimes used for the entire apse.,
C as in Concha (n.) The external ear; esp. the largest and deepest concavity of the external ear, surrounding the entrance to the auditory canal.,
C as in Conchal (a.) Pertaining to the concha, or external ear; as, the conchal cartilage.,
C as in Conchifer (n.) One of the Conchifera.,
C as in Conchifera (n. pl.) That class of Mollusca which includes the bivalve shells; the Lamellibranchiata. See Mollusca.,

C as in Conchiform (a.) Shaped like one half of a bivalve shell; shell-shaped.,
C as in Conchinine (n.) See Quinidine.,
C as in Conchite (n.) A fossil or petrified conch or shell.,
C as in Conchitic (a.) Composed of shells; containing many shells.,
C as in Conchoid (n.) A curve, of the fourth degree, first made use of by the Greek geometer, Nicomedes, who invented it for the purpose of trisecting an angle and duplicating the cube.,
C as in Conchoidal (a.) Having elevations or depressions in form like one half of a bivalve shell; -- applied principally to a surface produced by fracture.,
C as in Conchological (a.) Pertaining to, or connected with, conchology.,
C as in Conchologist (n.) One who studies, or is versed in, conchology.,
C as in Conchology (n.) The science of Mollusca, and of the shells which they form; malacology.,

Such were Hagar and Keturah, the concubines of Abraham; and such concubines were allowed by the Roman laws. Their children were not heirs of their father.,

C as in Condensation (n.) The act or process of reducing, by depression of temperature or increase of pressure, etc., to another and denser form, as gas to the condition of a liquid or steam to water.,
C as in Condensation (n.) A rearrangement or concentration of the different constituents of one or more substances into a distinct and definite compound of greater complexity and molecular weight, often resulting in an increase of density, as the condensation of oxygen into ozone, or of acetone into mesitylene.,
C as in Condensative (a.) Having the property of condensing.,
C as in Condensed (imp. & p. p.) of Condense,
C as in Condensing (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Condense,
C as in Condense (v. t.) To make more close, compact, or dense; to compress or concentrate into a smaller compass; to consolidate; to abridge; to epitomize.,
C as in Condense (v. t.) To reduce into another and denser form, as by cold or pressure; as, to condense gas into a liquid form, or steam into water.,
C as in Condense (v. i.) To become more compact; to be reduced into a denser form.,
C as in Condense (v. i.) To combine or unite (as two chemical substances) with or without separation of some unimportant side products.,
C as in Condense (v. i.) To undergo polymerization.,
C as in Condense (a.) Condensed; compact; dense.,
C as in Condenser (n.) One who, or that which, condenses.,
C as in Condenser (n.) An instrument for condensing air or other elastic fluids, consisting of a cylinder having a movable piston to force the air into a receiver, and a valve to prevent its escape.,
C as in Condenser (n.) An instrument for concentrating electricity by the effect of induction between conducting plates separated by a nonconducting plate.,
C as in Condenser (n.) A lens or mirror, usually of short focal distance, used to concentrate light upon an object.,
C as in Condenser (n.) An apparatus for receiving and condensing the volatile products of distillation to a liquid or solid form, by cooling.,
C as in Condenser (n.) An apparatus, separate from the cylinder, in which the exhaust steam is condensed by the action of cold water or air. See Illust. of Steam engine.,
C as in Condensible (a.) Capable of being condensed; as, a gas condensible to a liquid by cold.,

C as in Condition (n.) That which must exist as the occasion or concomitant of something else; that which is requisite in order that something else should take effect; an essential qualification; stipulation; terms specified.,
C as in Condition (n.) A clause in a contract, or agreement, which has for its object to suspend, to defeat, or in some way to modify, the principal obligation; or, in case of a will, to suspend, revoke, or modify a devise or bequest. It is also the case of a future uncertain event, which may or may not happen, and on the occurrence or non-occurrence of which, the accomplishment, recission, or modification of an obligation or testamentary disposition is made to depend.,

C as in Cone (n.) A solid of the form described by the revolution of a right-angled triangle about one of the sides adjacent to the right angle; -- called also a right cone. More generally, any solid having a vertical point and bounded by a surface which is described by a straight line always passing through that vertical point; a solid having a circle for its base and tapering to a point or vertex.,
C as in Cone (n.) Anything shaped more or less like a mathematical cone; as, a volcanic cone, a collection of scoriae around the crater of a volcano, usually heaped up in a conical form.,
C as in Cone (n.) The fruit or strobile of the Coniferae, as of the pine, fir, cedar, and cypress. It is composed of woody scales, each one of which has one or two seeds at its base.,

C as in Conine (n.) A powerful and very poisonous vegetable alkaloid found in the hemlock (Conium maculatum) and extracted as a colorless oil, C8H17N, of strong repulsive odor and acrid taste. It is regarded as a derivative of piperidine and likewise of one of the collidines. It occasions a gradual paralysis of the motor nerves. Called also coniine, coneine, conia, etc. See Conium, 2.,
C as in Coniroster (n.) One of the Conirostres.,
C as in Conirostral (a.) Belonging to the Conirostres.,
C as in Conirostres (n. pl.) A tribe of perching birds, including those which have a strong conical bill, as the finches.,

C as in Conistra (n.) Originally, a part of the palestra, or gymnasium among the Greeks; either the place where sand was stored for use in sprinkling the wrestlers, or the wrestling ground itself. Hence, a part of the orchestra of the Greek theater.,
C as in Conite (n.) A magnesian variety of dolomite.,
C as in Conium (n.) A genus of biennial, poisonous, white-flowered, umbelliferous plants, bearing ribbed fruit ("seeds") and decompound leaves.,
C as in Conium (n.) The common hemlock (Conium maculatum, poison hemlock, spotted hemlock, poison parsley), a roadside weed of Europe, Asia, and America, cultivated in the United States for medicinal purpose. It is an active poison. The leaves and fruit are used in medicine.,

C as in Contraband (n.) A negro slave, during the Civil War, escaped to, or was brought within, the Union lines. Such slave was considered contraband of war.,

C as in Contraband (v. t.) To import illegally, as prohibited goods; to smuggle.,
C as in Contraband (v. t.) To declare prohibited; to forbid.,
C as in Contrabandism (n.) Traffic in contraband goods; smuggling.,
C as in Contrabandist (n.) One who traffics illegally; a smuggler.,
C as in Contrabass (n.) Double bass; -- applied to any instrument of the same deep range as the stringed double bass; as, the contrabass ophicleide; the contrabass tuba or bombardon.,
C as in Contrabasso (n.) The largest kind of bass viol. See Violone.,

C as in Contraction (n.) The shortening of a word, or of two words, by the omission of a letter or letters, or by reducing two or more vowels or syllables to one; as, ne'er for never; can't for can not; don't for do not; it's for it is.,

C as in Convention (v. i.) An extraordinary assembly of the parkiament or estates of the realm, held without the king's writ, -- as the assembly which restored Charles II. to the throne, and that which declared the throne to be abdicated by James II.,
C as in Convention (v. i.) An agreement or contract less formal than, or preliminary to, a treaty; an informal compact, as between commanders of armies in respect to suspension of hostilities, or between states; also, a formal agreement between governments or sovereign powers; as, a postal convention between two governments.,
C as in Conventional (a.) Formed by agreement or compact; stipulated.,
C as in Conventional (a.) Growing out of, or depending on, custom or tacit agreement; sanctioned by general concurrence or usage; formal.,
C as in Conventional (a.) Based upon tradition, whether religious and historical or of artistic rules.,
C as in Conventional (a.) Abstracted; removed from close representation of nature by the deliberate selection of what is to be represented and what is to be rejected; as, a conventional flower; a conventional shell. Cf. Conventionalize, v. t.,
C as in Conventionalism (n.) That which is received or established by convention or arbitrary agreement; that which is in accordance with the fashion, tradition, or usage.,
C as in Conventionalism (n.) The principles or practice of conventionalizing. See Conventionalize, v. t.,
C as in Conventionalist (n.) One who adheres to a convention or treaty.,
C as in Conventionalist (n.) One who is governed by conventionalism.,
C as in Conventionalities (pl. ) of Conventionality,
C as in Conventionality (n.) The state of being conventional; adherence to social formalities or usages; that which is established by conventional use; one of the customary usages of social life.,
C as in Conventionalization (n.) The act of making conventional.,
C as in Conventionalization (n.) The state of being conventional.,
C as in Conventionalized (imp. & p. p.) of Conventionalizw,
C as in Conventionalizing (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Conventionalizw,
C as in Conventionalizw (v. t.) To make conventional; to bring under the influence of, or cause to conform to, conventional rules; to establish by usage.,
C as in Conventionalizw (v. t.) To represent by selecting the important features and those which are expressible in the medium employed, and omitting the others.,
C as in Conventionalizw (v. t.) To represent according to an established principle, whether religious or traditional, or based upon certain artistic rules of supposed importance.,
C as in Conventionalize (v. i.) To make designs in art, according to conventional principles. Cf. Conventionalize, v. t., 2.,

C as in Converse (a.) Turned about; reversed in order or relation; reciprocal; as, a converse proposition.,
C as in Converse (n.) A proposition which arises from interchanging the terms of another, as by putting the predicate for the subject, and the subject for the predicate; as, no virtue is vice, no vice is virtue.,
C as in Converse (n.) A proposition in which, after a conclusion from something supposed has been drawn, the order is inverted, making the conclusion the supposition or premises, what was first supposed becoming now the conclusion or inference. Thus, if two sides of a sides of a triangle are equal, the angles opposite the sides are equal; and the converse is true, i.e., if these angles are equal, the two sides are equal.,
C as in Conversely (adv.) In a converse manner; with change of order or relation; reciprocally.,
C as in Converser (n.) One who engages in conversation.,
C as in Conversible (a.) Capable of being converted or reversed.,
C as in Conversion (n.) The act of turning or changing from one state or condition to another, or the state of being changed; transmutation; change.,
C as in Conversion (n.) The act of changing one's views or course, as in passing from one side, party, or from of religion to another; also, the state of being so changed.,
C as in Conversion (n.) An appropriation of, and dealing with the property of another as if it were one's own, without right; as, the conversion of a horse.,
C as in Conversion (n.) The act of interchanging the terms of a proposition, as by putting the subject in the place of the predicate, or the contrary.,
C as in Conversion (n.) A change or reduction of the form or value of a proposition; as, the conversion of equations; the conversion of proportions.,
C as in Conversion (n.) A change of front, as a body of troops attacked in the flank.,
C as in Conversion (n.) A change of character or use, as of smoothbore guns into rifles.,
C as in Conversion (n.) A spiritual and moral change attending a change of belief with conviction; a change of heart; a change from the service of the world to the service of God; a change of the ruling disposition of the soul, involving a transformation of the outward life.,

C as in Convert (n.) A person who is converted from one opinion or practice to another; a person who is won over to, or heartily embraces, a creed, religious system, or party, in which he has not previously believed; especially, one who turns from the controlling power of sin to that of holiness, or from unbelief to Christianity.,
C as in Convert (n.) A lay friar or brother, permitted to enter a monastery for the service of the house, but without orders, and not allowed to sing in the choir.,
C as in Convertend (n.) Any proposition which is subject to the process of conversion; -- so called in its relation to itself as converted, after which process it is termed the converse. See Converse, n. (Logic).,
C as in Converter (n.) One who converts; one who makes converts.,
C as in Converter (n.) A retort, used in the Bessemer process, in which molten cast iron is decarburized and converted into steel by a blast of air forced through the liquid metal.,

C as in Coordination (n.) The act of coordinating; the act of putting in the same order, class, rank, dignity, etc.; as, the coordination of the executive, the legislative, and the judicial authority in forming a government; the act of regulating and combining so as to produce harmonious results; harmonious adjustment; as, a coordination of functions.,

C as in Copaiva (n.) A more or less viscid, yellowish liquid, the bitter oleoresin of several species of Copaifera, a genus of trees growing in South America and the West Indies. It is stimulant and diuretic, and is much used in affections of the mucous membranes; -- called also balsam of copaiba.,

To surround and inclose; to coop up; to put into an inclosed space; -- primarily used with reference to securing horses and cattle in an inclosure of wagons while traversing the plains, but in the Southwestern United States now colloquially applied to the capturing, securing, or penning of anything.,

It is the hardest substance found native, next to the diamond.,

C as in Cosmos (n.) The universe or universality of created things; -- so called from the order and harmony displayed in it.,
C as in Cosmos (n.) The theory or description of the universe, as a system displaying order and harmony.,
C as in Cosmosphere (n.) An apparatus for showing the position of the earth, at any given time, with respect to the fixed stars. It consist of a hollow glass globe, on which are depicted the stars and constellations, and within which is a terrestrial globe.,
C as in Cosmotheism (n.) Same as Pantheism.,
C as in Cosmothetic (a.) Assuming or positing the actual existence or reality of the physical or external world.,
C as in Cosovereign (n.) A joint sovereign.,
C as in Coss (n.) A Hindoo measure of distance, varying from one and a half to two English miles.,
C as in Coss (n.) A thing (only in phrase below).,
C as in Cossack (n.) One of a warlike, pastoral people, skillful as horsemen, inhabiting different parts of the Russian empire and furnishing valuable contingents of irregular cavalry to its armies, those of Little Russia and those of the Don forming the principal divisions.,
C as in Cossas (n.) Plain India muslin, of various qualities and widths.,
C as in Cosset (n.) A lamb reared without the aid of the dam. Hence: A pet, in general.,
C as in Cosset (v. t.) To treat as a pet; to fondle.,
C as in Cossic (a.) Alt. of Cossical,
C as in Cossical (a.) Of or relating to algebra; as, cossic numbers, or the cossic art.,

C as in Costardmonger (n.) A costermonger.,
C as in Costate (a.) Alt. of Costated,
C as in Costated (a.) Having ribs, or the appearance of ribs; (Bot.) having one or more longitudinal ribs.,
C as in Costean (v. i.) To search after lodes. See Costeaning.,
C as in Costeaning (n.) The process by which miners seek to discover metallic lodes. It consist in sinking small pits through the superficial deposits to the solid rock, and then driving from one pit to another across the direction of the vein, in such manner as to cross all the veins between the two pits.,
C as in Costellate (a.) Finely ribbed or costated.,
C as in Coster (n.) One who hawks about fruit, green vegetables, fish, etc.,
C as in Costermonger (n.) An apple seller; a hawker of, or dealer in, any kind of fruit or vegetables; a fruiterer.,
C as in Costiferous (a.) Rib-bearing, as the dorsal vertebrae.,
C as in Costive (a.) Retaining fecal matter in the bowels; having too slow a motion of the bowels; constipated.,
C as in Costive (a.) Reserved; formal; close; cold.,
C as in Costive (a.) Dry and hard; impermeable; unyielding.,
C as in Costively (adv.) In a costive manner.,
C as in Costiveness (n.) An unnatural retention of the fecal matter of the bowels; constipation.,
C as in Costiveness (n.) Inability to express one's self; stiffness.,
C as in Costless (a.) Costing nothing.,

C as in Costly (a.) Gorgeous; sumptuous.,
C as in Costmary (n.) A garden plant (Chrysanthemum Balsamita) having a strong balsamic smell, and nearly allied to tansy. It is used as a pot herb and salad plant and in flavoring ale and beer. Called also alecost.,
C as in Costotome (n.) An instrument (chisel or shears) to cut the ribs and open the thoracic cavity, in post-mortem examinations and dissections.,
C as in Costrel (n.) A bottle of leather, earthenware, or wood, having ears by which it was suspended at the side.,
C as in Costume (n.) Dress in general; esp., the distinctive style of dress of a people, class, or period.,

C as in Cottar (n.) A cottager; a cottier.,
C as in Cotter (n.) A piece of wood or metal, commonly wedge-shaped, used for fastening together parts of a machine or structure. It is driven into an opening through one or all of the parts. [See Illust.] In the United States a cotter is commonly called a key.,
C as in Cotter (n.) A toggle.,
C as in Cotter (v. t.) To fasten with a cotter.,
C as in Cottier (n.) In Great Britain and Ireland, a person who hires a small cottage, with or without a plot of land. Cottiers commonly aid in the work of the landlord's farm.,
C as in Cottise (n.) A diminutive of the bendlet, containing one half its area or one quarter the area of the bend. When a single cottise is used alone it is often called a cost. See also Couple-close.,
C as in Cottised (a.) Set between two cottises, -- said of a bend; or between two barrulets, -- said of a bar or fess.,
C as in Cottoid (a.) Like a fish of the genus Cottus.,
C as in Cottoid (n.) A fish belonging to, or resembling, the genus Cottus. See Sculpin.,
C as in Cottolene (n.) A product from cotton-seed, used as lard.,
C as in Cotton (n.) A soft, downy substance, resembling fine wool, consisting of the unicellular twisted hairs which grow on the seeds of the cotton plant. Long-staple cotton has a fiber sometimes almost two inches long; short-staple, from two thirds of an inch to an inch and a half.,
C as in Cotton (n.) The cotton plant. See Cotten plant, below.,

C as in Coulomb (n.) The standard unit of quantity in electrical measurements. It is the quantity of electricity conveyed in one second by the current produced by an electro-motive force of one volt acting in a circuit having a resistance of one ohm, or the quantity transferred by one ampere in one second. Formerly called weber.,
C as in Coulter (n.) Same as Colter.,
C as in Coulterneb (n.) The puffin.,
C as in Coumaric (a.) Relating to, derived from, or like, the Dipterix odorata, a tree of Guiana.,
C as in Coumarin (n.) The concrete essence of the tonka bean, the fruit of Dipterix (formerly Coumarouna) odorata and consisting essentially of coumarin proper, which is a white crystalline substance, C9H6O2, of vanilla-like odor, regarded as an anhydride of coumaric acid, and used in flavoring. Coumarin in also made artificially.,

C as in Counter (adv.) The after part of a vessel's body, from the water line to the stern, -- below and somewhat forward of the stern proper.,
C as in Counter (adv.) Same as Contra. Formerly used to designate any under part which served for contrast to a principal part, but now used as equivalent to counter tenor.,

C as in Counter brace () A brace, in a framed structure, which resists a strain of a character opposite to that which a main brace is designed to receive.,

C as in Counterchanging (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Counterchange,
C as in Counterchange (v. t.) To give and receive; to cause to change places; to exchange.,
C as in Counterchange (v. t.) To checker; to diversify, as in heraldic counterchanging. See Counterchaged, a., 2.,
C as in Counterchange (n.) Exchange; reciprocation.,
C as in Counterchanged (a.) Exchanged.,
C as in Counterchanged (a.) Having the tinctures exchanged mutually; thus, if the field is divided palewise, or and azure, and cross is borne counterchanged, that part of the cross which comes on the azure side will be or, and that on the or side will be azure.,
C as in Countercharge (n.) An opposing charge.,
C as in Countercharmed (imp. & p. p.) of Countercharm,
C as in Countercharming (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Countercharm,
C as in Countercharm (v. t.) To destroy the effect of a charm upon.,
C as in Countercharm (n.) That which has the power of destroying the effect of a charm.,

C as in Counterchecking (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Countercheck,
C as in Countercheck (v. t.) To oppose or check by some obstacle; to check by a return check.,
C as in Countercheck (n.) A check; a stop; a rebuke, or censure to check a reprover.,
C as in Countercheck (n.) Any force or device designed to restrain another restraining force; a check upon a check.,
C as in Counterclaim (n.) A claim made by a person as an offset to a claim made on him.,
C as in Counter-compony (a.) See Compony.,
C as in Counter-couchant (a.) Lying down, with their heads in opposite directions; -- said of animals borne in a coat of arms.,

C as in Countercurrent (n.) A current running in an opposite direction to the main current.,

C as in Counterfaisance (n.) See Counterfesance.,
C as in Counterfeit (adv.) Representing by imitation or likeness; having a resemblance to something else; portrayed.,
C as in Counterfeit (adv.) Fabricated in imitation of something else, with a view to defraud by passing the false copy for genuine or original; as, counterfeit antiques; counterfeit coin.,
C as in Counterfeit (adv.) Assuming the appearance of something; false; spurious; deceitful; hypocritical; as, a counterfeit philanthropist.,
C as in Counterfeit (n.) That which resembles or is like another thing; a likeness; a portrait; a counterpart.,
C as in Counterfeit (n.) That which is made in imitation of something, with a view to deceive by passing the false for the true; as, the bank note was a counterfeit.,
C as in Counterfeit (n.) One who pretends to be what he is not; one who personates another; an impostor; a cheat.,
C as in Counterfeited (imp. & p. p.) of Counterfeit,
C as in Counterfeiting (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Counterfeit,
C as in Counterfeit (v. t.) To imitate, or put on a semblance of; to mimic; as, to counterfeit the voice of another person.,
C as in Counterfeit (v. t.) To imitate with a view to deceiving, by passing the copy for that which is original or genuine; to forge; as, to counterfeit the signature of another, coins, notes, etc.,
C as in Counterfeit (v. i.) To carry on a deception; to dissemble; to feign; to pretend.,
C as in Counterfeit (v. i.) To make counterfeits.,
C as in Counterfeiter (n.) One who counterfeits; one who copies or imitates; especially, one who copies or forges bank notes or coin; a forger.,
C as in Counterfeiter (n.) One who assumes a false appearance or semblance; one who makes false pretenses.,
C as in Counterfeitly (adv.) By forgery; falsely.,
C as in Counterfesance (a.) The act of forging; forgery.,
C as in Counterfleury (a.) Counterflory.,
C as in Counterflory (a.) Adorned with flowers (usually fleurs-de-lis) so divided that the tops appear on one side and the bottoms on the others; -- said of any ordinary.,
C as in Counterfoil (n.) That part of a tally, formerly in the exchequer, which was kept by an officer in that court, the other, called the stock, being delivered to the person who had lent the king money on the account; -- called also counterstock.,
C as in Counterfoil (n.) The part of a writing (as the stub of a bank check) in which are noted the main particulars contained in the corresponding part, which has been issued.,
C as in Counterforce (n.) An opposing force.,
C as in Counterfort (n.) A kind of buttress of masonry to strengthen a revetment wall.,
C as in Counterfort (n.) A spur or projection of a mountain.,
C as in Countergage (n.) An adjustable gage, with double points for transferring measurements from one timber to another, as the breadth of a mortise to the place where the tenon is to be made.,
C as in Counterguard (n.) A low outwork before a bastion or ravelin, consisting of two lines of rampart parallel to the faces of the bastion, and protecting them from a breaching fire.,
C as in Counterirritant (n.) Alt. of Counterirritation,
C as in Counterirritation (n.) See Counter irritant, etc., under Counter, a.,
C as in Counterirritate (v. t.) To produce counter irritation in; to treat with one morbid process for the purpose of curing another.,

C as in Countermarch (n.) A marching back; retrocession.,
C as in Countermarch (n.) An evolution by which a body of troops change front or reverse the direction of march while retaining the same men in the front rank; also, a movement by which the rear rank becomes the front one, either with or without changing the right to the left.,
C as in Countermarch (n.) A change of measures; alteration of conduct.,
C as in Countermark (n.) A mark or token added to those already existing, in order to afford security or proof; as, an additional or special mark put upon a package of goods belonging to several persons, that it may not be opened except in the presence of all; a mark added to that of an artificer of gold or silver work by the Goldsmiths' Company of London, to attest the standard quality of the gold or silver; a mark added to an ancient coin or medal, to show either its change of value or that it was taken from an enemy.,
C as in Countermark (n.) An artificial cavity made in the teeth of horses that have outgrown their natural mark, to disguise their age.,
C as in Countermark (v. t.) To apply a countermark to; as, to countermark silverware; to countermark a horse's teeth.,
C as in Countermine (n.) An underground gallery excavated to intercept and destroy the mining of an enemy.,
C as in Countermine (n.) A stratagem or plot by which another sratagem or project is defeated.,

C as in Counterpane (n.) A coverlet for a bed, -- originally stitched or woven in squares or figures.,
C as in Counterpane (n.) A duplicate part or copy of an indenture, deed, etc., corresponding with the original; -- now called counterpart.,
C as in Counterpart (n.) A part corresponding to another part; anything which answers, or corresponds, to another; a copy; a duplicate; a facsimile.,
C as in Counterpart (n.) One of two corresponding copies of an instrument; a duplicate.,
C as in Counterpart (n.) A person who closely resembles another.,
C as in Counterpart (n.) A thing may be applied to another thing so as to fit perfectly, as a seal to its impression; hence, a thing which is adapted to another thing, or which supplements it; that which serves to complete or complement anything; hence, a person or thing having qualities lacking in another; an opposite.,

C as in Coupe-gorge (n.) Any position giving the enemy such advantage that the troops occupying it must either surrender or be cut to pieces.,

C as in Course (n.) The act of moving from one point to another; progress; passage.,
C as in Course (n.) The ground or path traversed; track; way.,
C as in Course (n.) Motion, considered as to its general or resultant direction or to its goal; line progress or advance.,
C as in Course (n.) Progress from point to point without change of direction; any part of a progress from one place to another, which is in a straight line, or on one direction; as, a ship in a long voyage makes many courses; a course measured by a surveyor between two stations; also, a progress without interruption or rest; a heat; as, one course of a race.,

C as in Course (n.) Customary or established sequence of events; recurrence of events according to natural laws.,
C as in Course (n.) Method of procedure; manner or way of conducting; conduct; behavior.,
C as in Course (n.) A series of motions or acts arranged in order; a succession of acts or practices connectedly followed; as, a course of medicine; a course of lectures on chemistry.,
C as in Course (n.) The succession of one to another in office or duty; order; turn.,
C as in Course (n.) That part of a meal served at one time, with its accompaniments.,
C as in Course (n.) A continuous level range of brick or stones of the same height throughout the face or faces of a building.,

C as in Coursing (n.) The pursuit or running game with dogs that follow by sight instead of by scent.,
C as in Court (n.) An inclosed space; a courtyard; an uncovered area shut in by the walls of a building, or by different building; also, a space opening from a street and nearly surrounded by houses; a blind alley.,
C as in Court (n.) The residence of a sovereign, prince, nobleman, or ether dignitary; a palace.,
C as in Court (n.) The collective body of persons composing the retinue of a sovereign or person high in authority; all the surroundings of a sovereign in his regal state.,
C as in Court (n.) Any formal assembling of the retinue of a sovereign; as, to hold a court.,
C as in Court (n.) Attention directed to a person in power; conduct or address designed to gain favor; courtliness of manners; civility; compliment; flattery.,
C as in Court (n.) The hall, chamber, or place, where justice is administered.,
C as in Court (n.) The persons officially assembled under authority of law, at the appropriate time and place, for the administration of justice; an official assembly, legally met together for the transaction of judicial business; a judge or judges sitting for the hearing or trial of causes.,
C as in Court (n.) A tribunal established for the administration of justice.,
C as in Court (n.) The judge or judges; as distinguished from the counsel or jury, or both.,
C as in Court (n.) The session of a judicial assembly.,
C as in Court (n.) Any jurisdiction, civil, military, or ecclesiastical.,
C as in Court (n.) A place arranged for playing the game of tennis; also, one of the divisions of a tennis court.,

C as in Courting (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Court,

C as in Court (v. t.) To invite by attractions; to allure; to attract.,
C as in Court (v. i.) To play the lover; to woo; as, to go courting.,
C as in Court-baron (n.) An inferior court of civil jurisdiction, attached to a manor, and held by the steward; a baron's court; -- now fallen into disuse.,
C as in Courtbred (a.) Bred, or educated, at court; polished; courtly.,
C as in Court-craft (n.) The artifices, intrigues, and plottings, at courts.,
C as in Court-cupboard (n.) A movable sideboard or buffet, on which plate and other articles of luxury were displayed on special ocasions.,
C as in Courteous (a.) Of courtlike manners; pertaining to, or expressive of, courtesy; characterized by courtesy; civil; obliging; well bred; polite; affable; complaisant.,
C as in Courteously (adv.) In a courteous manner.,
C as in Courteousness (n.) The quality of being courteous; politeness; courtesy.,

C as in Courter (n.) One who courts; one who plays the lover, or who solicits in marriage; one who flatters and cajoles.,
C as in Courtesan (n.) A woman who prostitutes herself for hire; a prostitute; a harlot.,
C as in Courtesanship (n.) Harlotry.,
C as in Courtesies (pl. ) of Courtesy,
C as in Courtesy (n.) Politeness; civility; urbanity; courtliness.,
C as in Courtesy (n.) An act of civility or respect; an act of kindness or favor performed with politeness.,
C as in Courtesy (n.) Favor or indulgence, as distinguished from right; as, a title given one by courtesy.,
C as in Courtesy (n.) An act of civility, respect, or reverence, made by women, consisting of a slight depression or dropping of the body, with bending of the knees.,
C as in Courtesied (imp. & p. p.) of Courtesy,
C as in Courtesying (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Courtesy,

C as in Courtesy (v. t.) To treat with civility.,

C as in Courtehouse (n.) A county town; -- so called in Virginia and some others of the Southern States.,
C as in Courtier (n.) One who is in attendance at the court of a prince; one who has an appointment at court.,
C as in Courtier (n.) One who courts or solicits favor; one who flatters.,
C as in Courtiery (n.) The manners of a courtier; courtliness.,
C as in Court-leet (n.) A court of record held once a year, in a particular hundred, lordship, or manor, before the steward of the leet.,
C as in Courtlike (a.) After the manner of a court; elegant; polite; courtly.,
C as in Courtliness (n.) The quality of being courtly; elegance or dignity of manners.,
C as in Courtling (n.) A sycophantic courtier.,

C as in Couscous (n.) A kind of food used by the natives of Western Africa, made of millet flour with flesh, and leaves of the baobab; -- called also lalo.,

C as in Cousin (n.) One collaterally related more remotely than a brother or sister; especially, the son or daughter of an uncle or aunt.,
C as in Cousin (n.) A title formerly given by a king to a nobleman, particularly to those of the council. In English writs, etc., issued by the crown, it signifies any earl.,
C as in Cousin (n.) Allied; akin.,
C as in Cousinage (n.) Relationship; kinship.,
C as in Cousin-german (n.) A first cousin. See Note under Cousin, 1.,

C as in Cousinry (n.) A body or collection of cousins; the whole number of persons who stand in the relation of cousins to a given person or persons.,
C as in Cousinship (n.) The relationship of cousins; state of being cousins; cousinhood.,
C as in Coussinet (n.) A stone placed on the impost of a pier for receiving the first stone of an arch.,
C as in Coussinet (n.) That part of the Ionic capital between the abacus and quarter round, which forms the volute.,
C as in Couteau (n.) A knife; a dagger.,
C as in Couth (imp. & p. p.) Could; was able; knew or known; understood.,
C as in Couvade (n.) A custom, among certain barbarous tribes, that when a woman gives birth to a child her husband takes to his bed, as if ill.,
C as in Covariant (n.) A function involving the coefficients and the variables of a quantic, and such that when the quantic is lineally transformed the same function of the new variables and coefficients shall be equal to the old function multiplied by a factor. An invariant is a like function involving only the coefficients of the quantic.,

C as in Cowberry (n.) A species of Vaccinium (V. Vitis-idaea), which bears acid red berries which are sometimes used in cookery; -- locally called mountain cranberry.,
C as in Cowbird (n.) The cow blackbird (Molothrus ater), an American starling. Like the European cuckoo, it builds no nest, but lays its eggs in the nests of other birds; -- so called because frequently associated with cattle.,
C as in Cowblakes (n. pl.) Dried cow dung used as fuel.,
C as in Cowboy (n.) A cattle herder; a drover; specifically, one of an adventurous class of herders and drovers on the plains of the Western and Southwestern United States.,
C as in Cowboy (n.) One of the marauders who, in the Revolutionary War infested the neutral ground between the American and British lines, and committed depredations on the Americans.,
C as in Cowcatxjer (n.) A strong inclined frame, usually of wrought-iron bars, in front of a locomotive engine, for catching or throwing off obstructions on a railway, as cattle; the pilot.,

C as in Cowslip (n.) A common flower in England (Primula veris) having yellow blossoms and appearing in early spring. It is often cultivated in the United States.,
C as in Cowslip (n.) In the United States, the marsh marigold (Caltha palustris), appearing in wet places in early spring and often used as a pot herb. It is nearer to a buttercup than to a true cowslip. See Illust. of Marsh marigold.,
C as in Cowslipped (a.) Adorned with cowslips.,

C as in Crannoge (n.) One of the stockaded islands in Scotland and Ireland which in ancient times were numerous in the lakes of both countries. They may be regarded as the very latest class of prehistoric strongholds, reaching their greatest development in early historic times, and surviving through the Middle Ages. See also Lake dwellings, under Lake.,

C as in Crawfish (n.) Alt. of Crayfish,
C as in Crayfish (n.) Any crustacean of the family Astacidae, resembling the lobster, but smaller, and found in fresh waters. Crawfishes are esteemed very delicate food both in Europe and America. The North American species are numerous and mostly belong to the genus Cambarus. The blind crawfish of the Mammoth Cave is Cambarus pellucidus. The common European species is Astacus fluviatilis.,
C as in Crawford (n.) A Crawford peach; a well-known freestone peach, with yellow flesh, first raised by Mr. William Crawford, of New Jersey.,

The side of an account on which are entered all items reckoned as values received from the party or the category named at the head of the account; also, any one, or the sum, of these items; -- the opposite of debit; as, this sum is carried to one's credit, and that to his debit; A has several credits on the books of B.,

C as in Creeper (n.) A small bird of the genus Certhia, allied to the wrens. The brown or common European creeper is C. familiaris, a variety of which (var. Americana) inhabits America; -- called also tree creeper and creeptree. The American black and white creeper is Mniotilta varia.,

C as in Creosote (n.) Wood-tar oil; an oily antiseptic liquid, of a burning smoky taste, colorless when pure, but usually colored yellow or brown by impurity or exposure. It is a complex mixture of various phenols and their ethers, and is obtained by the distillation of wood tar, especially that of beechwood.,

C as in Crescent (n.) The emblem of the Turkish Empire, adopted after the taking of Constantinople.,
C as in Crescent (n.) Any one of three orders of knighthood; the first instituted by Charles I., king of Naples and Sicily, in 1268; the second by Rene of Anjou, in 1448; and the third by the Sultan Selim III., in 1801, to be conferred upon foreigners to whom Turkey might be indebted for valuable services.,
