C as in Critic (n.) One skilled in judging of the merits of literary or artistic works; a connoisseur; an adept; hence, one who examines literary or artistic works, etc., and passes judgment upon them; a reviewer.,
C as in Critic (n.) One who passes a rigorous or captious judgment; one who censures or finds fault; a harsh examiner or judge; a caviler; a carper.,
C as in Critic (n.) The art of criticism.,
C as in Critic (n.) An act of criticism; a critique.,
C as in Critic (a.) Of or pertaining to critics or criticism; critical.,
C as in Critic (v. i.) To criticise; to play the critic.,
C as in Critical (n.) Qualified to criticise, or pass judgment upon, literary or artistic productions.,
C as in Critical (n.) Pertaining to criticism or the critic's art; of the nature of a criticism; accurate; as, critical knowledge; a critical dissertation.,
C as in Critical (n.) Inclined to make nice distinctions, or to exercise careful judgment and selection; exact; nicely judicious.,
C as in Critical (n.) Inclined to criticise or find fault; fastidious; captious; censorious; exacting.,
C as in Critical (n.) Characterized by thoroughness and a reference to principles, as becomes a critic; as, a critical analysis of a subject.,
C as in Critical (n.) Pertaining to, or indicating, a crisis, turning point, or specially important juncture; important as regards consequences; hence, of doubtful issue; attended with risk; dangerous; as, the critical stage of a fever; a critical situation.,
C as in Critically (adv.) In a critical manner; with nice discernment; accurately; exactly.,
C as in Critically (adv.) At a crisis; at a critical time; in a situation, place, or condition of decisive consequence; as, a fortification critically situated.,
C as in Criticalness (n.) The state or quality of being critical, or of occurring at a critical time.,
C as in Criticalness (n.) Accuracy in examination or decision; exactness.,
C as in Criticaster (n.) A contemptible or vicious critic.,
C as in Criticisable (a.) Capable of being criticised.,
C as in Criticised (imp. & p. p.) of Criticise,
C as in Criticising (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Criticise,
C as in Criticise (v. t.) To examine and judge as a critic; to pass literary or artistic judgment upon; as, to criticise an author; to criticise a picture.,
C as in Criticise (v. t.) To express one's views as to the merit or demerit of; esp., to animadvert upon; to find fault with; as, to criticise conduct.,
C as in Criticise (v. i.) To act as a critic; to pass literary or artistic judgment; to play the critic; -- formerly used with on or upon.,
C as in Criticise (v. i.) To discuss the merits or demerits of a thing or person; esp., to find fault.,
C as in Criticiser (n.) One who criticises; a critic.,
C as in Criticism (n.) The rules and principles which regulate the practice of the critic; the art of judging with knowledge and propriety of the beauties and faults of a literary performance, or of a production in the fine arts; as, dramatic criticism.,
C as in Criticism (n.) The act of criticising; a critical judgment passed or expressed; a critical observation or detailed examination and review; a critique; animadversion; censure.,
C as in Critique (n.) The art of criticism.,
C as in Critique (n.) A critical examination or estimate of a work of literature or art; a critical dissertation or essay; a careful and through analysis of any subject; a criticism; as, Kant's "Critique of Pure Reason.",
C as in Critique (n.) A critic; one who criticises.,
C as in Critique (v.) To criticise or pass judgment upon.,
C as in Crizzel (n.) A kind of roughness on the surface of glass, which clouds its transparency.,
C as in Croaked (imp. & p. p.) of Croak,
C as in Croaking (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Croak,
C as in Croak (v. i.) To make a low, hoarse noise in the throat, as a frog, a raven, or a crow; hence, to make any hoarse, dismal sound.,
C as in Croak (v. i.) To complain; especially, to grumble; to forebode evil; to utter complaints or forebodings habitually.,
C as in Croak (v. t.) To utter in a low, hoarse voice; to announce by croaking; to forebode; as, to croak disaster.,
C as in Croak (n.) The coarse, harsh sound uttered by a frog or a raven, or a like sound.,
C as in Croaker (n.) One who croaks, murmurs, grumbles, or complains unreasonably; one who habitually forebodes evil.,
C as in Croaker (n.) A small American fish (Micropogon undulatus), of the Atlantic coast.,
C as in Croaker (n.) An American fresh-water fish (Aplodinotus grunniens); -- called also drum.,
C as in Croaker (n.) The surf fish of California.,
C as in Croat (n.) A native of Croatia, in Austria; esp., one of the native Slavic race.,
C as in Croat (n.) An irregular soldier, generally from Croatia.,
C as in Croatian (a.) Of or pertaining to Croatia.,
C as in Croatian (n.) A Croat.,
C as in Crocein (n.) A name given to any one of several yellow or scarlet dyestuffs of artificial production and complex structure. In general they are diazo and sulphonic acid derivatives of benzene and naphthol.,
C as in Croceous (a.) Of, pertaining to, or like, saffron; deep reddish yellow.,
C as in Crocetin (n.) A dyestuff, obtained from the Chinese crocin, which produces a brilliant yellow.,
C as in Croche (n.) A little bud or knob at the top of a deer's antler.,
C as in Crochet (n.) A kind of knitting done by means of a hooked needle, with worsted, silk, or cotton; crochet work. Commonly used adjectively.,
C as in Crocheted (imp. & p. p.) of Crochet,
C as in Crocheting (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Crochet,
C as in Crochet (v. t. & i.) To knit with a crochet needle or hook; as, to crochet a shawl.,
C as in Crociary (n.) One who carries the cross before an archbishop.,
C as in Crocidolite (n.) A mineral occuring in silky fibers of a lavender blue color. It is related to hornblende and is essentially a silicate of iron and soda; -- called also blue asbestus. A silicified form, in which the fibers penetrating quartz are changed to oxide of iron, is the yellow brown tiger-eye of the jewelers.,
C as in Crocin (n.) The coloring matter of Chinese yellow pods, the fruit of Gardenia grandiflora.,
C as in Crocin (n.) A red powder (called also polychroite), which is made from the saffron (Crocus sativus). See Polychroite.,
C as in Crock (n.) The loose black particles collected from combustion, as on pots and kettles, or in a chimney; soot; smut; also, coloring matter which rubs off from cloth.,
C as in Crocked (imp. & p. p.) of Crock,
C as in Crocking (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Crock,
C as in Crock (v. t.) To soil by contact, as with soot, or with the coloring matter of badly dyed cloth.,
C as in Crock (v. i.) To give off crock or smut.,
C as in Crock (n.) A low stool.,
C as in Crock (n.) Any piece of crockery, especially of coarse earthenware; an earthen pot or pitcher.,
C as in Crock (v. t.) To lay up in a crock; as, to crock butter.,
C as in Crocker (n.) A potter.,
C as in Crockery (n.) Earthenware; vessels formed of baked clay, especially the coarser kinds.,
C as in Crocket (n.) An ornament often resembling curved and bent foliage, projecting from the sloping edge of a gable, spire, etc.,
C as in Crocket (n.) A croche, or knob, on the top of a stag's antler.,
C as in Crocketed (a.) Ornamented with crockets.,
C as in Crocketing (n.) Ornamentation with crockets.,
C as in Crocky (a.) Smutty.,
C as in Crocodile (n.) A large reptile of the genus Crocodilus, of several species. They grow to the length of sixteen or eighteen feet, and inhabit the large rivers of Africa, Asia, and America. The eggs, laid in the sand, are hatched by the sun's heat. The best known species is that of the Nile (C. vulgaris, or C. Niloticus). The Florida crocodile (C. Americanus) is much less common than the alligator and has longer jaws. The name is also sometimes applied to the species of other related genera, as the gavial and the alligator.,
C as in Crocodile (n.) A fallacious dilemma, mythically supposed to have been first used by a crocodile.,
C as in Crocodilia (n. pl.) An order of reptiles including the crocodiles, gavials, alligators, and many extinct kinds.,
C as in Crocodilian (a.) Like, or pertaining to, the crocodile; characteristic of the crocodile.,
C as in Crocodilian (n.) One of the Crocodilia.,
C as in Crocodility (n.) A caption or sophistical mode of arguing.,
C as in Crocoisite (n.) Same as Crocoite.,
C as in Crocoite (n.) Lead chromate occuring in crystals of a bright hyacinth red color; -- called also red lead ore.,
C as in Croconate (n.) A salt formed by the union of croconic acid with a base.,
C as in Croconic (a.) Of, pertaining to, or resembling saffron; having the color of saffron; as, croconic acid.,
C as in Croconic (a.) Pertaining to, or derived from, croconic acid.,
C as in Crocose (n.) A white crystalline sugar, metameric with glucose, obtained from the coloring matter of saffron.,
C as in Crocus (n.) A genus of iridaceous plants, with pretty blossoms rising separately from the bulb or corm. C. vernus is one of the earliest of spring-blooming flowers; C. sativus produces the saffron, and blossoms in the autumn.,
C as in Crocus (n.) A deep yellow powder; the oxide of some metal calcined to a red or deep yellow color; esp., the oxide of iron (Crocus of Mars or colcothar) thus produced from salts of iron, and used as a polishing powder.,
C as in Croesus (n.) A king of Lydia who flourished in the 6th century b. c., and was renowned for his vast wealth; hence, a common appellation for a very rich man; as, he is a veritable Croesus.,
C as in Croft (n.) A small, inclosed field, adjoining a house; a small farm.,
C as in Crofter (n.) One who rents and tills a small farm or helding; as, the crofters of Scotland.,
C as in Crefting (n.) Croftland.,
C as in Crefting (n.) Exposing linen to the sun, on the grass, in the process of bleaching.,
C as in Croftland (n.) Land of superior quality, on which successive crops are raised.,
C as in Crois (n.) See Cross, n.,
C as in Croisade (n.) Alt. of Croisado,
C as in Croisado (n.) A holy war; a crusade.,
C as in Croise (n.) A pilgrim bearing or wearing a cross.,
C as in Croise (n.) A crusader.,
C as in Croissante (a.) Terminated with crescent; -- said of a cross the ends of which are so terminated.,
C as in Croker (n.) A cultivator of saffron; a dealer in saffron.,
C as in Croma (n.) A quaver.,
C as in Cromlech (n.) A monument of rough stones composed of one or more large ones supported in a horizontal position upon others. They are found chiefly in countries inhabited by the ancient Celts, and are of a period anterior to the introduction of Christianity into these countries.,
C as in Cromorna (n.) A certain reed stop in the organ, of a quality of tone resembling that of the oboe.,
C as in Crone (n.) An old ewe.,
C as in Crone (n.) An old woman; -- usually in contempt.,
C as in Crone (n.) An old man; especially, a man who talks and acts like an old woman.,

C as in Cronet (n.) The coronet of a horse.,
C as in Cronian (a.) Saturnian; -- applied to the North Polar Sea.,

C as in Cronies (pl. ) of Crony,
C as in Crony (n.) A crone.,

C as in Crookedly (adv.) In a curved or crooked manner; in a perverse or untoward manner.,
C as in Crookedness (n.) The condition or quality of being crooked; hence, deformity of body or of mind; deviation from moral rectitude; perverseness.,
C as in Crooken (v. t.) To make crooked.,
C as in Crookes tube () A vacuum tube in which the exhaustion is carried to a very high degree, with the production of a distinct class of effects; -- so called from W. Crookes who introduced it.,

C as in Cross (n.) A gibbet, consisting of two pieces of timber placed transversely upon one another, in various forms, as a T, or +, with the horizontal piece below the upper end of the upright, or as an X. It was anciently used in the execution of criminals.,
C as in Cross (n.) The sign or mark of the cross, made with the finger, or in ink, etc., or actually represented in some material; the symbol of Christ's death; the ensign and chosen symbol of Christianity, of a Christian people, and of Christendom.,
C as in Cross (n.) Affiction regarded as a test of patience or virtue; trial; disappointment; opposition; misfortune.,
C as in Cross (n.) A piece of money stamped with the figure of a cross, also, that side of such a piece on which the cross is stamped; hence, money in general.,
C as in Cross (n.) An appendage or ornament or anything in the form of a cross; a badge or ornamental device of the general shape of a cross; hence, such an ornament, even when varying considerably from that form; thus, the Cross of the British Order of St. George and St. Michael consists of a central medallion with seven arms radiating from it.,
C as in Cross (n.) A monument in the form of a cross, or surmounted by a cross, set up in a public place; as, a market cross; a boundary cross; Charing Cross in London.,
C as in Cross (n.) A common heraldic bearing, of which there are many varieties. See the Illustration, above.,
C as in Cross (n.) The crosslike mark or symbol used instead of a signature by those unable to write.,
C as in Cross (n.) Church lands.,
C as in Cross (n.) A line drawn across or through another line.,
C as in Cross (n.) A mixing of breeds or stock, especially in cattle breeding; or the product of such intermixture; a hybrid of any kind.,
C as in Cross (n.) An instrument for laying of offsets perpendicular to the main course.,
C as in Cross (n.) A pipe-fitting with four branches the axes of which usually form's right angle.,
C as in Cross (a.) Not parallel; lying or falling athwart; transverse; oblique; intersecting.,
C as in Cross (a.) Not accordant with what is wished or expected; interrupting; adverse; contrary; thwarting; perverse.,
C as in Cross (a.) Characterized by, or in a state of, peevishness, fretfulness, or ill humor; as, a cross man or woman.,

C as in Crossbar (n.) A transverse bar or piece, as a bar across a door, or as the iron bar or stock which passes through the shank of an anchor to insure its turning fluke down.,

C as in Crossbeam (n.) A girder.,
C as in Crossbeam (n.) A beam laid across the bitts, to which the cable is fastened when riding at anchor.,
C as in Cross-bearer (n.) A subdeacon who bears a cross before an archbishop or primate on solemn occasions.,
C as in Crossbill () A bill brought by a defendant, in an equity or chancery suit, against the plaintiff, respecting the matter in question in that suit.,
C as in Crossbill (n.) A bird of the genus Loxia, allied to the finches. Their mandibles are strongly curved and cross each other; the crossbeak.,
C as in Cross-birth (n.) Any preternatural labor, in which the body of the child lies across the pelvis of the mother, so that the shoulder, arm, or trunk is the part first presented at the mouth of the uterus.,
C as in Crossbite (n.) A deception; a cheat.,
C as in Crossbite (b. t.) To deceive; to trick; to gull.,
C as in Crossbones (n. pl.) A representation of two of the leg bones or arm bones of a skeleton, laid crosswise, often surmounted with a skull, and serving as a symbol of death.,
C as in Crossbow (n.) A weapon, used in discharging arrows, formed by placing a bow crosswise on a stock.,
C as in Crossbower (n.) A crossbowman.,
C as in Crossbowman (n.) One who shoots with a crossbow. See Arbalest.,
C as in Crossbred (a.) Produced by mixing distinct breeds; mongrel.,
C as in Crossbreed (n.) A breed or an animal produced from parents of different breeds; a new variety, as of plants, combining the qualities of two parent varieties or stocks.,
C as in Crossbreed (n.) Anything partaking of the natures of two different things; a hybrid.,
C as in Cross-bun (n.) A bun or cake marked with a cross, and intended to be eaten on Good Friday.,

C as in Crosshead (n.) A beam or bar across the head or end of a rod, etc., or a block attached to it and carrying a knuckle pin; as the solid crosspiece running between parallel slides, which receives motion from the piston of a steam engine and imparts it to the connecting rod, which is hinged to the crosshead.,

C as in Cross-question (v. t.) To cross-examine; to subject to close questioning.,
C as in Cross-reading (n.) The reading of the lines of a newspaper directly across the page, instead of down the columns, thus producing a ludicrous combination of ideas.,
C as in Crossroad (n.) A road that crosses another; an obscure road intersecting or avoiding the main road.,
C as in Crossrow (n.) The alphabet; -- called also Christcross-row.,
C as in Crossrow (n.) A row that crosses others.,
C as in Crossruff (n.) The play in whist where partners trump each a different suit, and lead to each other for that purpose; -- called also seesaw.,
C as in Cross-spale (n.) Alt. of Cross-spall,
C as in Cross-spall (n.) One of the temporary wooden braces, placed horizontally across a frame to hold it in position until the deck beams are in; a cross-pawl.,
C as in Cross-springer (n.) One of the ribs in a groined arch, springing from the corners in a diagonal direction. [See Illustr. of Groined vault.],
C as in Cross-staff (n.) An instrument formerly used at sea for taking the altitudes of celestial bodies.,
C as in Cross-staff (n.) A surveyor's instrument for measuring offsets.,
C as in Cross-stitch (n.) A form of stitch, where the stitches are diagonal and in pairs, the thread of one stitch crossing that of the other.,
C as in Cross-stone (n.) See Harmotome, and Staurotide.,
C as in Cross-tail (n.) A bar connecting the ends of the side rods or levers of a backaction or side-lever engine.,
C as in Cross-tie (n.) A sleeper supporting and connecting the rails, and holding them in place.,
C as in Cross-tining (n.) A mode of harrowing crosswise, or transversely to the ridges.,
C as in Crosstrees (n. pl.) Pieces of timber at a masthead, to which are attached the upper shrouds. At the head of lower masts in large vessels, they support a semicircular platform called the "top.",
C as in Cross-vaulting (n.) Vaulting formed by the intersection of two or more simple vaults.,
C as in Crossway (n.) See Crossroad.,
C as in Cross-week (n.) Rogation week, when the cross was borne in processions.,
C as in Crosswise (adv.) In the form of a cross; across; transversely.,
C as in Crosswort (n.) A name given to several inconspicuous plants having leaves in whorls of four, as species of Crucianella, Valantia, etc.,

C as in Croton bug () A small, active, winged species of cockroach (Ectobia Germanica), the water bug. It is common aboard ships, and in houses in cities, esp. in those with hot-water pipes.,
C as in Crotonic (a.) Of or pertaining to, or derived from, a plant of the genus Croton, or from croton oil.,
C as in Crotonine (n.) A supposed alkaloid obtained from croton oil by boiling it with water and magnesia, since found to be merely a magnesia soap of the oil.,
C as in Crotonylene (n.) A colorless, volatile, pungent liquid, C4H6, produced artificially, and regarded as an unsaturated hydrocarbon of the acetylene series, and analogous to crotonic acid.,

C as in Croup (n.) An inflammatory affection of the larynx or trachea, accompanied by a hoarse, ringing cough and stridulous, difficult breathing; esp., such an affection when associated with the development of a false membrane in the air passages (also called membranous croup). See False croup, under False, and Diphtheria.,

C as in Cryohydrate (n.) A substance, as salt, ammonium chloride, etc., which crystallizes with water of crystallization only at low temperatures, or below the freezing point of water.,
C as in Cryolite (n.) A fluoride of sodium and aluminum, found in Greenland, in white cleavable masses; -- used as a source of soda and alumina.,
C as in Cryophorus (n.) An instrument used to illustrate the freezing of water by its own evaporation. The ordinary form consists of two glass bulbs, connected by a tube of the same material, and containing only a quantity of water and its vapor, devoid of air. The water is in one of the bulbs, and freezes when the other is cooled below 32 Fahr.,

C as in Crystal (n.) The regular form which a substance tends to assume in solidifying, through the inherent power of cohesive attraction. It is bounded by plane surfaces, symmetrically arranged, and each species of crystal has fixed axial ratios. See Crystallization.,
C as in Crystal (n.) The material of quartz, in crystallization transparent or nearly so, and either colorless or slightly tinged with gray, or the like; -- called also rock crystal. Ornamental vessels are made of it. Cf. Smoky quartz, Pebble; also Brazilian pebble, under Brazilian.,

C as in Crystallite (n.) A minute mineral form like those common in glassy volcanic rocks and some slags, not having a definite crystalline outline and not referable to any mineral species, but marking the first step in the crystallization process. According to their form crystallites are called trichites, belonites, globulites, etc.,
C as in Crystallizable (a.) Capable of being crystallized; that may be formed into crystals.,
C as in Crystallization (n.) The act or process by which a substance in solidifying assumes the form and structure of a crystal, or becomes crystallized.,
C as in Crystallization (n.) The body formed by crystallizing; as, silver on precipitation forms arborescent crystallizations.,

C as in Cucking stool () A kind of chair formerly used for punishing scolds, and also dishonest tradesmen, by fastening them in it, usually in front of their doors, to be pelted and hooted at by the mob, but sometimes to be taken to the water and ducked; -- called also a castigatory, a tumbrel, and a trebuchet; and often, but not so correctly, a ducking stool.,

C as in Curari (n.) A black resinoid extract prepared by the South American Indians from the bark of several species of Strychnos (S. toxifera, etc.). It sometimes has little effect when taken internally, but is quickly fatal when introduced into the blood, and used by the Indians as an arrow poison.,

C as in Cut (v. t.) To separate the parts of with, or as with, a sharp instrument; to make an incision in; to gash; to sever; to divide.,
C as in Cut (v. t.) To sever and cause to fall for the purpose of gathering; to hew; to mow or reap.,
C as in Cut (v. t.) To sever and remove by cutting; to cut off; to dock; as, to cut the hair; to cut the nails.,
C as in Cut (v. t.) To castrate or geld; as, to cut a horse.,
C as in Cut (v. t.) To form or shape by cutting; to make by incision, hewing, etc.; to carve; to hew out.,
C as in Cut (v. t.) To wound or hurt deeply the sensibilities of; to pierce; to lacerate; as, sarcasm cuts to the quick.,
C as in Cut (v. t.) To intersect; to cross; as, one line cuts another at right angles.,
C as in Cut (v. t.) To refuse to recognize; to ignore; as, to cut a person in the street; to cut one's acquaintance.,
C as in Cut (v. t.) To absent one's self from; as, to cut an appointment, a recitation. etc.,
C as in Cut (v. i.) To do the work of an edged tool; to serve in dividing or gashing; as, a knife cuts well.,
C as in Cut (v. i.) To admit of incision or severance; to yield to a cutting instrument.,
C as in Cut (v. i.) To perform the operation of dividing, severing, incising, intersecting, etc.; to use a cutting instrument.,
C as in Cut (v. i.) To make a stroke with a whip.,
C as in Cut (v. i.) To interfere, as a horse.,
C as in Cut (v. i.) To move or make off quickly.,
C as in Cut (v. i.) To divide a pack of cards into two portion to decide the deal or trump, or to change the order of the cards to be dealt.,
C as in Cut (n.) An opening made with an edged instrument; a cleft; a gash; a slash; a wound made by cutting; as, a sword cut.,
C as in Cut (n.) A stroke or blow or cutting motion with an edged instrument; a stroke or blow with a whip.,
C as in Cut (n.) That which wounds the feelings, as a harsh remark or criticism, or a sarcasm; personal discourtesy, as neglecting to recognize an acquaintance when meeting him; a slight.,
C as in Cut (n.) A notch, passage, or channel made by cutting or digging; a furrow; a groove; as, a cut for a railroad.,
C as in Cut (n.) The surface left by a cut; as, a smooth or clear cut.,
C as in Cut (n.) A portion severed or cut off; a division; as, a cut of beef; a cut of timber.,
C as in Cut (n.) An engraved block or plate; the impression from such an engraving; as, a book illustrated with fine cuts.,
C as in Cut (n.) The act of dividing a pack cards.,
C as in Cut (n.) The right to divide; as, whose cut is it?,
C as in Cut (n.) Manner in which a thing is cut or formed; shape; style; fashion; as, the cut of a garment.,
C as in Cut (n.) A common work horse; a gelding.,
C as in Cut (n.) The failure of a college officer or student to be present at any appointed exercise.,
C as in Cut (n.) A skein of yarn.,
C as in Cut (a.) Gashed or divided, as by a cutting instrument.,
C as in Cut (a.) Formed or shaped as by cutting; carved.,
C as in Cut (a.) Overcome by liquor; tipsy.,
C as in Cutaneous (a.) Of pertaining to the skin; existing on, or affecting, the skin; as, a cutaneous disease; cutaneous absorption; cutaneous respiration.,
C as in Cutaway (a.) Having a part cut off or away; having the corners rounded or cut away.,
C as in Cutch (n.) See Catechu.,
C as in Cutch (n.) See Cultch.,
C as in Cutchery (n.) A hindoo hall of justice.,
C as in Cute (a.) Clever; sharp; shrewd; ingenious; cunning.,
C as in Cuteness (n.) Acuteness; cunning.,
C as in Cutgrass () A grass with leaves having edges furnished with very minute hooked prickles, which form a cutting edge; one or more species of Leersia.,
C as in Cuticle (n.) The scarfskin or epidermis. See Skin.,
C as in Cuticle (n.) The outermost skin or pellicle of a plant, found especially in leaves and young stems.,
C as in Cuticle (n.) A thin skin formed on the surface of a liquid.,
C as in Cuticular (a.) Pertaining to the cuticle, or external coat of the skin; epidermal.,
C as in Cutin (n.) The substance which, added to the material of a cell wall, makes it waterproof, as in cork.,
C as in Cutinization (n.) The conversion of cell walls into a material which repels water, as in cork.,
C as in Cutinize (v. t. & i.) To change into cutin.,
C as in Cutis (n.) See Dermis.,
C as in Cutlasses (pl. ) of Cutlass,
C as in Cutlass (n.) A short, heavy, curving sword, used in the navy. See Curtal ax.,
C as in Cutler (n.) One who makes or deals in cutlery, or knives and other cutting instruments.,
C as in Cutlery (n.) The business of a cutler.,
C as in Cutlery (n.) Edged or cutting instruments, collectively.,
C as in Cutlet (n.) A piece of meat, especially of veal or mutton, cut for broiling.,
C as in Cutling (n.) The art of making edged tools or cutlery.,
C as in Cut-off (n.) That which cuts off or shortens, as a nearer passage or road.,
C as in Cut-off (n.) The valve gearing or mechanism by which steam is cut off from entering the cylinder of a steam engine after a definite point in a stroke, so as to allow the remainder of the stroke to be made by the expansive force of the steam already let in. See Expansion gear, under Expansion.,
C as in Cut-off (n.) Any device for stopping or changing a current, as of grain or water in a spout.,
C as in Cutose (n.) A variety of cellulose, occuring as a fine transparent membrane covering the aerial organs of plants, and forming an essential ingredient of cork; by oxidation it passes to suberic acid.,
C as in Cut-out (n.) A species of switch for changing the current from one circuit to another, or for shortening a circuit.,
C as in Cut-out (n.) A device for breaking or separating a portion of circuit.,
C as in Cutpurse (n.) One who cuts purses for the sake of stealing them or their contents (an act common when men wore purses fastened by a string to their girdles); one who steals from the person; a pickpocket,
C as in Cutter (n.) One who cuts; as, a stone cutter; a die cutter; esp., one who cuts out garments.,
C as in Cutter (n.) That which cuts; a machine or part of a machine, or a tool or instrument used for cutting, as that part of a mower which severs the stalk, or as a paper cutter.,
C as in Cutter (n.) A fore tooth; an incisor.,
C as in Cutter (n.) A boat used by ships of war.,
C as in Cutter (n.) A fast sailing vessel with one mast, rigged in most essentials like a sloop. A cutter is narrower end deeper than a sloop of the same length, and depends for stability on a deep keel, often heavily weighted with lead.,
C as in Cutter (n.) A small armed vessel, usually a steamer, in the revenue marine service; -- also called revenue cutter.,
C as in Cutter (n.) A small, light one-horse sleigh.,
C as in Cutter (n.) An officer in the exchequer who notes by cutting on the tallies the sums paid.,
C as in Cutter (n.) A ruffian; a bravo; a destroyer.,
C as in Cutter (n.) A kind of soft yellow brick, used for facework; -- so called from the facility with which it can be cut.,
C as in Cutthroat (n.) One who cuts throats; a murderer; an assassin.,
C as in Cutthroat (a.) Murderous; cruel; barbarous.,
C as in Cutting (n.) The act or process of making an incision, or of severing, felling, shaping, etc.,
C as in Cutting (n.) Something cut, cut off, or cut out, as a twig or scion cut off from a stock for the purpose of grafting or of rooting as an independent plant; something cut out of a newspaper; an excavation cut through a hill or elsewhere to make a way for a railroad, canal, etc.; a cut.,
C as in Cutting (a.) Adapted to cut; as, a cutting tool.,
C as in Cutting (a.) Chilling; penetrating; sharp; as, a cutting wind.,
C as in Cutting (a.) Severe; sarcastic; biting; as, a cutting reply.,
C as in Cuttingly (adv.) In a cutting manner.,
C as in Cuttle (n.) A knife.,
C as in Cuttle (n.) Alt. of Cuttlefish,
C as in Cuttlefish (n.) A cephalopod of the genus Sepia, having an internal shell, large eyes, and ten arms furnished with denticulated suckers, by means of which it secures its prey. The name is sometimes applied to dibranchiate cephalopods generally.,
C as in Cuttlefish (n.) A foul-mouthed fellow.,
C as in Cuttle bone () The shell or bone of cuttlefishes, used for various purposes, as for making polishing powder, etc.,
C as in Cuttoo plate () A hood over the end of a wagon wheel hub to keep dirt away from the axle.,
C as in Cytty (a.) Short; as, a cutty knife; a cutty sark.,
C as in Cutty (n.) A short spoon.,
C as in Cutty (n.) A short tobacco pipe.,
C as in Cutty (n.) A light or unchaste woman.,
C as in Cuttystool (n.) A low stool,
C as in Cuttystool (n.) A seat in old Scottish churches, where offenders were made to sit, for public rebuke by the minister.,
C as in Cutwal (n.) The chief police officer of a large city.,
C as in Cutwater (n.) The fore part of a ship's prow, which cuts the water.,
C as in Cutwater (n.) A starling or other structure attached to the pier of a bridge, with an angle or edge directed up stream, in order better to resist the action of water, ice, etc.; the sharpened upper end of the pier itself.,
C as in Cutwater (n.) A sea bird of the Atlantic (Rhynchops nigra); -- called also black skimmer, scissorsbill, and razorbill. See Skimmer.,
C as in Cutwork (n.) An ancient term for embroidery, esp. applied to the earliest form of lace, or to that early embroidery on linen and the like, from which the manufacture of lace was developed.,
C as in Cutworm (n.) A caterpillar which at night eats off young plants of cabbage, corn, etc., usually at the ground. Some kinds ascend fruit trees and eat off the flower buds. During the day, they conceal themselves in the earth. The common cutworms are the larvae of various species of Agrotis and related genera of noctuid moths.,
C as in Cuvette (n.) A pot, bucket, or basin, in which molten plate glass is carried from the melting pot to the casting table.,
C as in Cuvette (n.) A cunette.,
C as in Cuvette (n.) A small vessel with at least two flat and transparent sides, used to hold a liquid sample to be analysed in the light path of a spectrometer.,
C as in Cyamelide (n.) A white amorphous substance, regarded as a polymeric modification of isocyanic acid.,
C as in Cyamellone (n.) A complex derivative of cyanogen, regarded as an acid, and known chiefly in its salts; -- called also hydromellonic acid.,
C as in Cyanate (n.) A salt of cyanic acid.,
C as in Cyanaurate (n.) See Aurocyanide.,
C as in Cyanean (a.) Having an azure color.,
C as in Cyanic (a.) Pertaining to, or containing, cyanogen.,
C as in Cyanic (a.) Of or pertaining to a blue color.,
C as in Cyanide (n.) A compound formed by the union of cyanogen with an element or radical.,
C as in Cyanin (n.) The blue coloring matter of flowers; -- called also anthokyan and anthocyanin.,
C as in Cyanine (n.) One of a series of artificial blue or red dyes obtained from quinoline and lepidine and used in calico printing.,
C as in Cyanite (n.) A mineral occuring in thin-bladed crystals and crystalline aggregates, of a sky-blue color. It is a silicate of aluminium.,
C as in Cyanogen (n.) A colorless, inflammable, poisonous gas, C2N2, with a peach-blossom odor, so called from its tendency to form blue compounds; obtained by heating ammonium oxalate, mercuric cyanide, etc. It is obtained in combination, forming an alkaline cyanide when nitrogen or a nitrogenous compound is strongly ignited with carbon and soda or potash. It conducts itself like a member of the halogen group of elements, and shows a tendency to form complex compounds. The name is also applied to the univalent radical, CN (the half molecule of cyanogen proper), which was one of the first compound radicals recognized.,
C as in Cyanometer (n.) An instrument for measuring degress of blueness.,
C as in Cyanopathy (n.) A disease in which the body is colored blue in its surface, arising usually from a malformation of the heart, which causes an imperfect arterialization of the blood; blue jaundice.,
C as in Cyanophyll (n.) A blue coloring matter supposed by some to be one of the component parts of chlorophyll.,
C as in Cyanosed (a.) Rendered blue, as the surface of the body, from cyanosis or deficient a/ration of the blood.,
C as in Cyanosis (n.) A condition in which, from insufficient a/ration of the blood, the surface of the body becomes blue. See Cyanopathy.,
C as in Cyanosite (n.) Native sulphate of copper. Cf. Blue vitriol, under Blue.,
C as in Cyanotic (a.) Relating to cyanosis; affected with cyanosis; as, a cyanotic patient; having the hue caused by cyanosis; as, a cyanotic skin.,
C as in Cyanotype (n.) A photographic picture obtained by the use of a cyanide.,
C as in Cyanurate (n.) A salt of cyanuric acid.,
C as in Cyanuret (n.) A cyanide.,
C as in Cyanuric (a.) Pertaining to, or derived from, cyanic and uric acids.,
C as in Cyanuric acid () an organic acid, C3O3N3H3, first obtained by heating uric acid or urea, and called pyrouric acid; afterwards obtained from isocyanic acid. It is a white crystalline substance, odorless and almost tasteless; -- called also tricarbimide.,
C as in Cyathiform (a.) In the form of a cup, a little widened at the top.,
C as in Cyatholith (n.) A kind of coccolith, which in shape resembles a minute cup widened at the top, and varies in size from / to / of an inch.,
C as in Cyathophylloid (a.) Like, or pertaining to, the family Cyathophyllidae.,
C as in Cyathophylloid (n.) A fossil coral of the family Cyathophyllidae; sometimes extended to fossil corals of other related families belonging to the group Rugosa; -- also called cup corals. Thay are found in paleozoic rocks.,
C as in Cycad (n.) Any plant of the natural order Cycadaceae, as the sago palm, etc.,
C as in Cycadaceous (a.) Pertaining to, or resembling, an order of plants like the palms, but having exogenous wood. The sago palm is an example.,
C as in Cycas (n.) A genus of trees, intermediate in character between the palms and the pines. The pith of the trunk of some species furnishes a valuable kind of sago.,
C as in Cyclamen (n.) A genus of plants of the Primrose family, having depressed rounded corms, and pretty nodding flowers with the petals so reflexed as to point upwards, whence it is called rabbits' ears. It is also called sow bread, because hogs are said to eat the corms.,
C as in Cyclamin (n.) A white amorphous substance, regarded as a glucoside, extracted from the corm of Cyclamen Europaeum.,
C as in Cyclas (n.) A long gown or surcoat (cut off in front), worn in the Middle Ages. It was sometimes embroidered or interwoven with gold. Also, a rich stuff from which the gown was made.,
C as in Cycle (n.) An imaginary circle or orbit in the heavens; one of the celestial spheres.,
C as in Cycle (n.) An interval of time in which a certain succession of events or phenomena is completed, and then returns again and again, uniformly and continually in the same order; a periodical space of time marked by the recurrence of something peculiar; as, the cycle of the seasons, or of the year.,
C as in Cycle (n.) An age; a long period of time.,
C as in Cycle (n.) An orderly list for a given time; a calendar.,
C as in Cycle (n.) The circle of subjects connected with the exploits of the hero or heroes of some particular period which have served as a popular theme for poetry, as the legend of Arthur and the knights of the Round Table, and that of Charlemagne and his paladins.,
C as in Cycle (n.) One entire round in a circle or a spire; as, a cycle or set of leaves.,
C as in Cycle (n.) A bicycle or tricycle, or other light velocipede.,
C as in Cycled (imp. & p. p.) of Cycle,
C as in Cycling (p. pr. & vb. n.) of Cycle,
C as in Cycle (v. i.) To pass through a cycle of changes; to recur in cycles.,
C as in Cycle (v. i.) To ride a bicycle, tricycle, or other form of cycle.,
C as in Cyclic (a.) Alt. of Cyclical,
C as in Cyclical (a.) Of or pertaining to a cycle or circle; moving in cycles; as, cyclical time.,
C as in Cyclide (n.) A surface of the fourth degree, having certain special relations to spherical surfaces. The tore or anchor ring is one of the cyclides.,
C as in Cycling (n.) The act, art, or practice, of riding a cycle, esp. a bicycle or tricycle.,
C as in Cyclist (n.) A cycler.,
C as in Cyclo- () A combining form meaning circular, of a circle or wheel.,
C as in Cyclobranchiate (a.) Having the gills around the margin of the body, as certain limpets.,
C as in Cycloganoid (a.) Of or pertaining to the Cycloganoidei.,
C as in Cycloganoid (n.) One of the Cycloganoidei.,
C as in Cycloganoidei (n. pl.) An order of ganoid fishes, having cycloid scales. The bowfin (Amia calva) is a living example.,
C as in Cyclograph (n.) See Arcograph.,
C as in Cycloid (n.) A curve generated by a point in the plane of a circle when the circle is rolled along a straight line, keeping always in the same plane.,
C as in Cycloid (a.) Of or pertaining to the Cycloidei.,
C as in Cycloid (n.) One of the Cycloidei.,
C as in Cycloidal (a.) Pertaining to, or resembling, a cycloid; as, the cycloidal space is the space contained between a cycloid and its base.,
C as in Cycloidei (n. pl.) An order of fishes, formerly proposed by Agassiz, for those with thin, smooth scales, destitute of marginal spines, as the herring and salmon. The group is now regarded as artificial.,
C as in Cycloidian (a. & n.) Same as 2d and 3d Cycloid.,
C as in Cyclometer (n.) A contrivance for recording the revolutions of a wheel, as of a bicycle.,
C as in Cyclometry (n.) The art of measuring circles.,
C as in Cyclone (n.) A violent storm, often of vast extent, characterized by high winds rotating about a calm center of low atmospheric pressure. This center moves onward, often with a velocity of twenty or thirty miles an hour.,
C as in Cyclonic (a.) Pertaining to a cyclone.,
C as in Cyclop (n.) See Note under Cyclops, 1.,
C as in Cyclopean (a.) Pertaining to the Cyclops; characteristic of the Cyclops; huge; gigantic; vast and rough; massive; as, Cyclopean labors; Cyclopean architecture.,
C as in Cyclopedia (n.) Alt. of Cyclopaedia,
C as in Cyclopaedia (n.) The circle or compass of the arts and sciences (originally, of the seven so-called liberal arts and sciences); circle of human knowledge. Hence, a work containing, in alphabetical order, information in all departments of knowledge, or on a particular department or branch; as, a cyclopedia of the physical sciences, or of mechanics. See Encyclopedia.,
C as in Cyclopedic (a.) Belonging to the circle of the sciences, or to a cyclopedia; of the nature of a cyclopedia; hence, of great range, extent, or amount; as, a man of cyclopedic knowledge.,
C as in Cyclopedist (n.) A maker of, or writer for, a cyclopedia.,
C as in Cyclopic (a.) Pertaining to the Cyclops; Cyclopean.,
C as in Cyclops (n. sing. & pl.) One of a race of giants, sons of Neptune and Amphitrite, having but one eye, and that in the middle of the forehead. They were fabled to inhabit Sicily, and to assist in the workshops of Vulcan, under Mt. Etna.,
C as in Cyclops (n. sing. & pl.) A genus of minute Entomostraca, found both in fresh and salt water. See Copepoda.,
C as in Cyclops (n. sing. & pl.) A portable forge, used by tinkers, etc.,
C as in Cyclorama (n.) A pictorial view which is extended circularly, so that the spectator is surrounded by the objects represented as by things in nature. The realistic effect is increased by putting, in the space between the spectator and the picture, things adapted to the scene represented, and in some places only parts of these objects, the completion of them being carried out pictorially.,
C as in Cycloscope (n.) A machine for measuring at any moment velocity of rotation, as of a wheel of a steam engine.,
C as in Cyclosis (n.) The circulation or movement of protoplasmic granules within a living vegetable cell.,
C as in Cyclostomata (n. pl.) Alt. of Cyclostoma,
C as in Cyclostoma (n. pl.) A division of Bryozoa, in which the cells have circular apertures.,
C as in Cyclostome (a.) Alt. of Cyclostomous,
C as in Cyclostomous (a.) Pertaining to the Cyclostomi.,
C as in Cyclostomi (n. pl.) A glass of fishes having a suckerlike mouth, without jaws, as the lamprey; the Marsipobranchii.,
C as in Cyclostylar (a.) Relating to a structure composed of a circular range of columns, without a core or building within.,
C as in Cyclostyle (n.) A contrivance for producing manifold copies of writing or drawing. The writing or drawing is done with a style carrying a small wheel at the end which makes minute punctures in the paper, thus converting it into a stencil. Copies are transferred with an inked roller.,
C as in Cyder (n.) See Cider.,
C as in Cydonin (n.) A peculiar mucilaginous substance extracted from the seeds of the quince (Cydonia vulgaris), and regarded as a variety of amylose.,
C as in Cygnet (n.) A young swan.,
C as in Cygnus (n.) A constellation of the northern hemisphere east of, or following, Lyra; the Swan.,
C as in Cylinder (n.) A solid body which may be generated by the rotation of a parallelogram round one its sides; or a body of rollerlike form, of which the longitudinal section is oblong, and the cross section is circular.,
C as in Cylinder (n.) The space inclosed by any cylindrical surface. The space may be limited or unlimited in length.,
C as in Cylinder (n.) Any hollow body of cylindrical form,
C as in Cylinder (n.) The chamber of a steam engine in which the piston is moved by the force of steam.,
C as in Cylinder (n.) The barrel of an air or other pump.,
C as in Cylinder (n.) The revolving platen or bed which produces the impression or carries the type in a cylinder press.,
C as in Cylinder (n.) The bore of a gun; the turning chambered breech of a revolver.,
C as in Cylinder (n.) The revolving square prism carrying the cards in a Jacquard loom.,
C as in Cylindraceous (a.) Cylindrical, or approaching a cylindrical form.,
C as in Cylindric (a.) Alt. of Cylindrical,
C as in Cylindrical (a.) Having the form of a cylinder, or of a section of its convex surface; partaking of the properties of the cylinder.,
C as in Cylindrically (adv.) In the manner or shape of a cylinder; so as to be cylindrical.,
C as in Cylindricity (n.) The quality or condition of being cylindrical.,
C as in Cylindriform (a.) Having the form of a cylinder.,
C as in Cylindroid (n.) A solid body resembling a right cylinder, but having the bases or ends elliptical.,
C as in Cylindroid (n.) A certain surface of the third degree, described by a moving straight line; -- used to illustrate the motions of a rigid body and also the forces acting on the body.,
C as in Cylindrometric (a.) Belonging to a scale used in measuring cylinders.,
C as in Cyma (n.) A member or molding of the cornice, the profile of which is wavelike in form.,
C as in Cyma (n.) A cyme. See Cyme.,
C as in Cymar (n.) A slight covering; a scarf. See Simar.,
C as in Cymatium (n.) A capping or crowning molding in classic architecture.,
C as in Cymbal (n.) A musical instrument used by the ancients. It is supposed to have been similar to the modern kettle drum, though perhaps smaller.,
C as in Cymbal (n.) A musical instrument of brass, shaped like a circular dish or a flat plate, with a handle at the back; -- used in pairs to produce a sharp ringing sound by clashing them together.,
C as in Cymbal (n.) A musical instrument used by gypsies and others, made of steel wire, in a triangular form, on which are movable rings.,
C as in Cymbalist (n.) A performer upon cymbals.,
C as in Cymbiform (a.) Shaped like a boat; (Bot.) elongated and having the upper surface decidedly concave, as the glumes of many grasses.,
C as in Cymbium (n.) A genus of marine univalve shells; the gondola.,
C as in Cyme (n.) A flattish or convex flower cluster, of the centrifugal or determinate type, differing from a corymb chiefly in the order of the opening of the blossoms.,
C as in Cymene (n.) A colorless, liquid, combustible hydrocarbon, CH3.C6H4.C3H7, of pleasant odor, obtained from oil of cumin, oil of caraway, carvacrol, camphor, etc.; -- called also paracymene, and formerly camphogen.,
C as in Cymenol (n.) See Carvacrol.,
C as in Cymidine (n.) A liquid organic base, C10H13.NH2, derived from cymene.,
C as in Cymiferous (a.) Producing cymes.,
C as in Cymling (n.) Alt. of Cymbling,
C as in Cymbling (n.) A scalloped or "pattypan" variety of summer squash.,
C as in Cymogene (n.) A highly volatile liquid, condensed by cold and pressure from the first products of the distillation of petroleum; -- used for producing low temperatures.,
C as in Cymoid (a.) Having the form of a cyme.,
C as in Cymophane (n.) See Chrysoberyl.,
C as in Cymophanous (a.) Having a wavy, floating light; opalescent; chatoyant.,
C as in Cymose (a.) Alt. of Cymous,
C as in Cymous (a.) Having the nature of a cyme, or derived from a cyme; bearing, or pertaining to, a cyme or cymes.,
C as in Cymric (a.) Welsh.,
C as in Cymric (n.) The Welsh language.,
C as in Cymry (n.) A collective term for the Welsh race; -- so called by themselves .,
C as in Cymule (n.) A small cyme, or one of very few flowers.,
C as in Cynanche (n.) Any disease of the tonsils, throat, or windpipe, attended with inflammation, swelling, and difficulty of breathing and swallowing.,
C as in Cynanthropy (n.) A kind of madness in which men fancy themselves changed into dogs, and imitate the voice and habits of that animal.,
C as in Cynarctomachy (n.) Bear baiting with a dog.,
C as in Cynarrhodium (n.) A fruit like that of the rose, consisting of a cup formed of the calyx tube and receptacle, and containing achenes.,
C as in Cynegetics (n.) The art of hunting with dogs.,
C as in Cynic (a.) Alt. of Cynical,
C as in Cynical (a.) Having the qualities of a surly dog; snarling; captious; currish.,
C as in Cynical (a.) Pertaining to the Dog Star; as, the cynic, or Sothic, year; cynic cycle.,
C as in Cynical (a.) Belonging to the sect of philosophers called cynics; having the qualities of a cynic; pertaining to, or resembling, the doctrines of the cynics.,
C as in Cynical (a.) Given to sneering at rectitude and the conduct of life by moral principles; disbelieving in the reality of any human purposes which are not suggested or directed by self-interest or self-indulgence; as, a cynical man who scoffs at pretensions of integrity; characterized by such opinions; as, cynical views of human nature.,
C as in Cynic (n.) One of a sect or school of philosophers founded by Antisthenes, and of whom Diogenes was a disciple. The first Cynics were noted for austere lives and their scorn for social customs and current philosophical opinions. Hence the term Cynic symbolized, in the popular judgment, moroseness, and contempt for the views of others.,
C as in Cynic (n.) One who holds views resembling those of the Cynics; a snarler; a misanthrope; particularly, a person who believes that human conduct is directed, either consciously or unconsciously, wholly by self-interest or self-indulgence, and that appearances to the contrary are superficial and untrustworthy.,
C as in Cynically (adv.) In a cynical manner.,
C as in Cynicalness (n.) The quality of being cynical.,
C as in Cynicism (n.) The doctrine of the Cynics; the quality of being cynical; the mental state, opinions, or conduct, of a cynic; morose and contemptuous views and opinions.,
C as in Cynoidea (n. pl.) A division of Carnivora, including the dogs, wolves, and foxes.,
C as in Cynorexia (n.) A voracious appetite, like that of a starved dog.,
C as in Cynosural (a.) Of or pertaining to a cynosure.,
C as in Cynosure (n.) The constellation of the Lesser Bear, to which, as containing the polar star, the eyes of mariners and travelers were often directed.,
C as in Cynosure (n.) That which serves to direct.,
C as in Cynosure (n.) Anything to which attention is strongly turned; a center of attraction.,
C as in Cyon (n.) See Cion, and Scion.,
C as in Cyperaceous (a.) Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a large family of plants of which the sedge is the type.,
C as in Cyperus (n.) A large genus of plants belonging to the Sedge family, and including the species called galingale, several bulrushes, and the Egyptian papyrus.,
C as in Cypher (n. & v.) See Cipher.,
C as in Cyphonautes (n.) The free-swimming, bivalve larva of certain Bryozoa.,
C as in Cyphonism (n.) A punishment sometimes used by the ancients, consisting in the besmearing of the criminal with honey, and exposing him to insects. It is still in use among some Oriental nations.,
C as in Cypraea (n.) A genus of mollusks, including the cowries. See Cowrie.,
C as in Cypres (n.) A rule for construing written instruments so as to conform as nearly to the intention of the parties as is consistent with law.,
C as in Cypresses (pl. ) of Cypress,
C as in Cypress (n.) A coniferous tree of the genus Cupressus. The species are mostly evergreen, and have wood remarkable for its durability.,
C as in Cyprian (a.) Belonging to Cyprus.,
C as in Cyprian (a.) Of, pertaining, or conducing to, lewdness.,
C as in Cyprian (n.) A native or inhabitant of Cyprus, especially of ancient Cyprus; a Cypriot.,
C as in Cyprian (n.) A lewd woman; a harlot.,
C as in Cyprine (a.) Of or pertaining to the cypress.,
C as in Cyprine (a.) Cyprinoid.,
C as in Cyprinodont (n.) One of the Cyprinodontidae, a family of fishes including the killifishes or minnows. See Minnow.,
C as in Cyprinoid (a.) Like the carp (Cyprinus).,
C as in Cyprinoid (n.) One of the Cyprinidae, or Carp family, as the goldfish, barbel, etc.,
C as in Cypriot (n.) A native or inhabitant of Cyprus.,
C as in Cypripedium (n.) A genus of orchidaceous plants including the lady's slipper.,
C as in Cyprides (pl. ) of Cypris,
C as in Cypris (n.) A genus of small, bivalve, fresh-water Crustacea, belonging to the Ostracoda; also, a member of this genus.,
C as in Cyprus (n.) A thin, transparent stuff, the same as, or corresponding to, crape. It was either white or black, the latter being most common, and used for mourning.,
C as in Cypruslawn (n.) Same as Cyprus.,
C as in Cypsela (n.) A one-seeded, one-celled, indehiscent fruit; an achene with the calyx tube adherent.,
C as in Cypseliform (a.) Like or belonging to the swifts (Cypselidae.),
C as in Cyrenaic (a.) Pertaining to Cyrenaica, an ancient country of northern Africa, and to Cyrene, its principal city; also, to a school of philosophy founded by Aristippus, a native of Cyrene.,
C as in Cyrenaic (n.) A native of Cyrenaica; also, a disciple of the school of Aristippus. See Cyrenian, n.,
C as in Cyrenian (a.) Pertaining to Cyrene, in Africa; Cyrenaic.,
C as in Cyrenian (n.) A native or inhabitant of Cyrene.,
C as in Cyrenian (n.) One of a school of philosophers, established at Cyrene by Aristippus, a disciple of Socrates. Their doctrines were nearly the same as those of the Epicureans.,
C as in Cyriologic (a.) Relating to capital letters.,
C as in Cyrtostyle (n.) A circular projecting portion.,
C as in Cyst (n.) A pouch or sac without opening, usually membranous and containing morbid matter, which is accidentally developed in one of the natural cavities or in the substance of an organ.,
C as in Cyst (n.) In old authors, the urinary bladder, or the gall bladder.,
C as in Cyst (n.) One of the bladders or air vessels of certain algae, as of the great kelp of the Pacific, and common rockweeds (Fuci) of our shores.,
C as in Cyst (n.) A small capsule or sac of the kind in which many immature entozoans exist in the tissues of living animals; also, a similar form in Rotifera, etc.,
C as in Cyst (n.) A form assumed by Protozoa in which they become saclike and quiescent. It generally precedes the production of germs. See Encystment.,
C as in Cysted (a.) Inclosed in a cyst.,
C as in Cystic (a.) Having the form of, or living in, a cyst; as, the cystic entozoa.,
C as in Cystic (a.) Containing cysts; cystose; as, cystic sarcoma.,
C as in Cystic (a.) Pertaining to, or contained in, a cyst; esp., pertaining to, or contained in, either the urinary bladder or the gall bladder.,
C as in Cysticerce (n.) Alt. of Cysticercus,
C as in Cysticercus (n.) The larval form of a tapeworm, having the head and neck of a tapeworm attached to a saclike body filled with fluid; -- called also bladder worm, hydatid, and measle (as, pork measle).,
C as in Cysticule (n.) An appendage of the vestibular ear sac of fishes.,
C as in Cystid (n.) One of the Cystidea.,
C as in Cystidea (n. pl.) An order of Crinoidea, mostly fossils of the Paleozoic rocks. They were usually roundish or egg-shaped, and often unsymmetrical; some were sessile, others had short stems.,
C as in Cystidean (n.) One of the Cystidea.,
C as in Cystine (n.) A white crystalline substance, C3H7NSO2, containing sulphur, occuring as a constituent of certain rare urinary calculi, and occasionally found as a sediment in urine.,
C as in Cystis (n.) A cyst. See Cyst.,
C as in Cystitis (n.) Inflammation of the bladder.,
C as in Cystocarp (n.) A minute vesicle in a red seaweed, which contains the reproductive spores.,
C as in Cystocele (n.) Hernia in which the urinary bladder protrudes; vesical hernia.,
C as in Cystoid (n.) Alt. of Cystoidean,
C as in Cystoidean (n.) Same as Cystidean.,
C as in Cystoidea (n.) Same as Cystidea.,
C as in Cystolith (n.) A concretion of mineral matter within a leaf or other part of a plant.,
C as in Cystolith (n.) A urinary calculus.,
C as in Cystolithic (a.) Relating to stone in the bladder.,
C as in Cystoplast (n.) A nucleated cell having an envelope or cell wall, as a red blood corpuscle or an epithelial cell; a cell concerned in growth.,
C as in Cystose (a.) Containing, or resembling, a cyst or cysts; cystic; bladdery.,
C as in Cystotome (n.) A knife or instrument used in cystotomy.,
C as in Cystotomy (n.) The act or practice of opening cysts; esp., the operation of cutting into the bladder, as for the extraction of a calculus.,
C as in Cytherean (a.) Pertaining to the goddess Venus.,
C as in Cytoblast (n.) The nucleus of a cell; the germinal or active spot of a cellule, through or in which cell development takes place.,
C as in Cytoblastema (n.) See Protoplasm.,
C as in Cytococci (pl. ) of Cytococcus,
C as in Cytococcus (n.) The nucleus of the cytula or parent cell.,
C as in Cytode (n.) A nonnucleated mass of protoplasm, the supposed simplest form of independent life differing from the amoeba, in which nuclei are present.,
C as in Cytogenesis (n.) Development of cells in animal and vegetable organisms. See Gemmation, Budding, Karyokinesis; also Cell development, under Cell.,
C as in Cytogenic (a.) Alt. of Cytogenetic,
C as in Cytogenetic (a.) Of or pertaining to cytogenesis or cell development.,
C as in Cytogenous (a.) Producing cells; -- applied esp. to lymphatic, or adenoid, tissue.,
C as in Cytogeny (n .) Cell production or development; cytogenesis.,
C as in Cytoid (a.) Cell-like; -- applied to the corpuscles of lymph, blood, chyle, etc.,
C as in Cytoplasm (n.) The substance of the body of a cell, as distinguished from the karyoplasma, or substance of the nucleus.,
C as in Cytula (n.) The fertilized egg cell or parent cell, from the development of which the child or other organism is formed.,
C as in Czar (n.) A king; a chief; the title of the emperor of Russia.,
C as in Czarevna (n.) The title of the wife of the czarowitz.,
C as in Czarina (n.) The title of the empress of Russia.,
C as in Czarinian (a.) Of or pertaining to the czar or the czarina; czarish.,
C as in Czarish (a.) Of or pertaining to the czar.,
C as in Czarowitzes (pl. ) of Czarowitz,
C as in Czarowitz (n.) The title of the eldest son of the czar of Russia.,
C as in Czech (n.) One of the Czechs.,
C as in Czech (n.) The language of the Czechs (often called Bohemian), the harshest and richest of the Slavic languages.,
C as in Czechic (a.) Of or pertaining to the Czechs.,
C as in Czechs (n. pl.) The most westerly branch of the great Slavic family of nations, numbering now more than 6,000,000, and found principally in Bohemia and Moravia.,
